headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day everyone, and welcome today's Sempra Energy Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference. Just as a reminder, today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Rick Vaccari. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day everyone, and welcome today's Sempra Energy Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference. Just as a reminder, today's call is being recorded. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. Rick Vaccari. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to Sempra Energy's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Financial Presentation. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. Here in San Diego are several mem
componenttext:
Good morning and welcome to Sempra Energy's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Financial Presentation. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. 
Here in San Diego are several members of our management team. Debbie Reed, Chairman and CEO; Mark Snell, President; Joe Householder, Chief Financial Officer; Martha Wyrsch, General Counsel; Trevor Mihalik, Chief Accounting Officer; Dennis Arriola, Chief Executive Officer of SoCalGas; Jeff Martin, Chief Executive Officer of SDG&E; and Octávio Simões, President of Sempra LNG. 
Before starting, I would like to remind everyone that we will be discussing forward-looking statements on this call within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. The factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially are discussed in the company's most recent 10-K filed with the SEC. It's important to note that all of the earnings per share amounts in our presentation are shown on a diluted basis, and we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the presentation slides that accompany this call and to Table A in our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings press release for a reconciliation to GAAP measures. 
I'd also like to note that the forward-looking statements contained in this presentation speak only as of today, February 26, 2016, and the company does not assume any obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements in the future. 
With that, please turn to Slide 4 and let me hand the call over to Debbie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. Before discussing the quarter, I would like to say a few words about the natural gas leak at our Aliso Canyon storage facility. On February 18, the Division of Oil, Gas and Geothermal Resources, or DOGGR, confirmed that the leaking well was
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. Before discussing the quarter, I would like to say a few words about the natural gas leak at our Aliso Canyon storage facility. On February 18, the Division of Oil, Gas and Geothermal Resources, or DOGGR, confirmed that the leaking well was permanently sealed. Our focus since the beginning has been safely stopping the leak, reducing the order from the well, reducing the amount of natural gas being emitted into the environment, working cooperatively with agencies and elected officials, and supporting local residents including providing temporary housing and air filtration systems. Now that we have stopped the leak, an independent investigation of the root cause will be conducted. I want to emphasize that providing safe and reliable service to our customers is the highest priority for SoCalGas. We will continue to work with our regulators and customers to ensure our path ahead reflects these values. 
Later, I will provide more information on Aliso Canyon and Dennis and Martha are also here to address your questions. 
Turning to our financial performance. In 2015, we had very strong results and exceeded our adjusted earnings guidance. This morning, we reported full year earnings of $5.37 per share or $5.21 per share on an adjusted basis. Our 2015 results were driven largely by growth in operating earnings at our California Utilities and Sempra International.
In addition, our board approved an increase in the 2016 dividend to $3.02 per share. This payout represents an 8% annual increase and provides dividend growth that more closely aligns with the 11% annual increase in our 2015 adjusted earnings. Moreover, we are targeting annual dividend increases of 8% to 9% over the next several years to better align our dividend growth with our projected EPS growth. Our dividend strategy is underpinned by confidence in our future cash flows and supports our commitment to return capital to our shareholders.
Regarding 2016 earnings. We have updated our assumptions and are providing an adjusted EPS guidance range of $4.80 per share to $5.20 per share. When compared with the 2015 results, we forecast a higher effective tax rate for 2016. In part, this is due to a large number of benefits recorded last year that related to the resolution of tax matters. 
Also, as we move into the new GRC cycle at our California Utilities, we will now be providing an estimated $60 million of repair allowance tax benefits to ratepayers as part of the standard rate case true up. In our 2016 adjusted guidance, we assumed that we retain all repair allowance benefits for tax years preceding our new GRC. Key updates and comparisons to the 2016 guidance we provided at last year's analyst conference reflects several other factors, notably, we include our best estimate of the GRC decision for the California Utilities based on our settlement agreement, as well as new market assumptions for commodities and foreign exchange rates that have changed considerably since last year. Additionally, our adjusted guidance range now includes approximately $20 million to $25 million of estimated LNG development expense. 
Regarding transactions we announced last year that were added into our base plan, such as the potential PEMEX acquisition and new renewable contract, we expect the earnings impact to largely occur in 2017 and beyond. 
Please note that our proposed GRC settlement agreement is subject to CPUC approval and we do not anticipate receiving a final decision until the second quarter. 
We have moved our analyst conference to May in order to incorporate an expected final GRC decision. And we'll provide you with our business unit guidance and longer-term projections at that time. Overall, we are well-positioned to achieve our long-term strategy of providing earnings growth that is twice that of the average utility, but with a moderate risk profile. Combined with strong anticipated growth in the dividend, we are focused on providing top-tier shareholder return. 
Now please turn to Slide 5. This slide summarizes the key assumptions included in our 2016 adjusted EPS guidance. And we'll briefly discuss each item and you can find additional detail in the appendix. 
First, as I mentioned earlier, this year, we include development cost for our LNG and liquefaction in related infrastructure opportunities. In 2015, we had about $10 million of similar expense that was excluded from adjusted guidance due to uncertainty about the nature and timing of these costs. Given progress on the projects, and our estimates and the spin rate and the amounts capitalized and shared with partners, we now include a 2016 after-tax expense of roughly $0.08 to $0.10 per share. Please note, however, that the vast majority of planned expense is targeted for Port Arthur and related infrastructure as we have already incurred most of the upfront cost for Cameron expansion. Going forward, we will be sharing cost for Port Arthur with our partner Woodside. We will nevertheless monitor our progress in securing market commitments and other needed approvals to advance the project. To the extent our progress is slower than expected, we will adjust our spending accordingly.
Next, we have seen a significant decline in natural gas price forecast over the past year. Specifically, the Cal border 2016 forward curve has fallen from $3.60 in our prior guidance to $2.60 on our new adjusted guidance. The impact from this assumption is a reduction in earnings of approximately $0.05 to $0.07 per share that is associated with the LNG marketing contract from our ICA Import Facility in Mexico. 
Third, we reduced projected earnings from the TDM power plant due to the lower power places and lower expected capacity revenue. This month, IEnova decided to hold the asset for sale. The sale would complete our exit from merchant generation and allow IEnova to deploy capital in projects that provide more stable earnings. 
While we project approximately $0.04 to $0.06 per share of reduced earnings associated with TDM, we do not consider any potential gain or loss from the sale in our adjusted guidance. 
Moving to parent. We assumed that we will use dividends from Mexico to participate in a potential IEnova equity offering. We forecast a 2016 earnings benefit from lower repatriation tax expense of between $0.08 and $0.10 per share. Offsetting this impact is an estimated $0.04 per share after tax of higher interest expense to fund projects in our base plan. 
Next, like natural gas prices, we have seen exchange rate forecasts move significantly over the past year. Relative to our previous guidance, our current forecast is for the dollar to strengthen in 2016 by an additional 20% against the Chilean currency and by an additional 13% against the Peruvian currency. Projected earnings are reduced by roughly $0.09 to $0.11 per share as a result of translating South American earnings into dollars.
In Mexico, we have not previously forecast the impact of foreign currency effects. We now include in our adjusted guidance a reduction in tax expense associated with peso depreciation during 2016. Based upon the forward curve at year end, we estimate this benefit to be approximately $0.05 to $0.07 per share. 
With regard to IEnova's acquisition of PEMEX, it's ownership and their share joint venture, Mexico's Competition Commission has required PEMEX to competitively auction 2 assets included in the original transaction. IEnova is negotiating changes to the original agreement with PEMEX that will reflect the auction outcome among other things. Our adjusted guidance assumes that the transaction moves forward with the same assets enclosed in the second quarter of the 2016. Based on this timing, we assume an estimated $0.02 of accretion this year. Our adjusted guidance excludes however any potential gain associated with a remeasurement of our investment in the joint venture.
In our renewables business, we incorporate new forecast for wind resource and availability that reduced earnings by approximately $0.02 per share. However, our base plan now includes 328 megawatts of additional projects announced last year that are under construction. Given that these projects are expected to be in operation by the end of 2016, we expect to see the full earnings impact beginning in 2017.
Finally, for the California Utilities, our prior guidance was based on a very conservative assumption that revenues would be based on our current attrition mechanism with no further adjustment. Our new adjusted guidance range includes projected earnings that more closely align with the GRC settlement agreement and our best estimate of the outcome given the record in the preceding. 
Now let's go to Slide 6 for a business update, beginning with the California Utilities. In our general rate case, we are currently expecting to see a proposed decision in March and to receive a final decision in the second quarter. As you recall, we reached a multiparty settlement agreement with major parties in the case. Until we get a final GRC position, we will record revenues based upon the authorized revenue requirement in 2015. When we receive the final decision, we will make an adjustment to reflect the retroactive earnings back to January 1, 2016. 
Turning to Aliso Canyon. We have received confirmation from DOGGR, the California agency responsible for regulating gas storage, that the leaking well has been permanently sealed. We have approximately 15 BCF of natural gas in the storage field and the field is stable. Moving forward, an independent engineering firm has been selected by DOGGR and the CPUC to investigate the root cause of the leak. While we do not know how long this process will take, we will cooperate on the investigation and share publicly available data.
Consistent with new rules under development, we are implementing enhanced leak detection and well inspection activities. We are also working cooperatively with all of the agencies involved to determine a path forward for the facility which is regarded as integral to the reliability of the electric grid in California. 
Reflecting the most up-to-date information, which primarily includes revised temporary relocation and well drilling expenses, we now estimate the total cost for amounts paid and those forecast to be paid to be approximately $330 million. Of this amount, approximately 90% is for the temporary relocation program, cost to address the leak and attempts to stop or reduce the emission. The remaining amount includes, among other items, the value of lost gas and estimated cost to mitigate the GHG emissions. For the estimate, we assume that the relocation period for the majority of residents ended on February 25, as agreed upon with the City of Los Angeles. We have concluded, it is probable that we will receive insurance recovery for the total amount less retention of $325 million.
Beyond this estimate, we cannot predict all of the potential categories or total amount of future costs that we may incur as a result of the leak. We have at least 4 types of insurance policies that provide an excess of $1 billion in insurance coverage. Based upon what we know today, and subject to various policy limits, exclusions and conditions, we believe that our insurance should also cover the following categories not included in our estimates, costs associated with litigation and claims by nearby residents and businesses, and in some circumstances, depending upon their nature and matter of assessment, fines and penalties. I refer you to our 10-K for further detail. 
Please turn to Slide 7. In Mexico, CFE is tendering several more gas pipelines. IEnova submitted a bid for 1 pipeline earlier this month, is in process of submitting a bid for second and is preparing to submit a third bid in March. According to CFE estimates, the 3 pipelines represent an investment opportunity of almost $2 billion and we expect award dates to occur in March and April. 
This spring, IEnova is also preparing to participate in Mexico's first auction, a renewable energy certificate. IEnova is looking at potential fuller opportunities and may submit a bid to expand the ESJ wind facility with its joint venture partner Intergen. The CFE will be the initial offtaker under 15 to 20-year contracts and total awards could amount to 2,500 megawatts of new power generation.
In our LNG business, there have been 2 noteworthy developments, our Cameron expansion project received its FERC environmental assessment on February 12 and we expect to receive the FERC permit in the second quarter. Though current market conditions are not ideal, Cameron Train 4 is a better competitive offering for long-term buyers. Based on recent meetings with potential customers, we are bypassing the Memorandum of Understanding stage and are in negotiations for definitive 20-year sales and purchase agreements. While a sales and purchase agreement will take longer to execute than an MoU, we are targeting the second half of 2016 for announcing customer agreements needed to launch the project. This approach provides us with greater certainty on project commitments prior to incurring large capital expenditures.
For Port Arthur, yesterday, we signed a joint develop agreement with Woodside Petroleum that outlines development rules in the potential project. In addition to how we will share cost and market capacity, the agreement provides a framework for how we will work together technically to design a cost competitive plant. 
Last month, I was in Australia, meeting with the CEO and senior management of Woodside. And we shared a view that Port Arthur has good market prospects post 2020. Before moving on, remember that we have not incorporated additional LNG or other growth projects in our guidance. We are actively working on development opportunities across our businesses that could provide upside to both our near-term and long-term projections. 
With that, please turn to Slide 8 and Joe will discuss our financial results. Joe?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Earlier this morning, we reported fourth quarter earnings of $369 million. On an adjusted basis, we reported fourth quarter earnings of $370 million or $1.47 per share. Adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter exclude $3 million of expenses
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. Earlier this morning, we reported fourth quarter earnings of $369 million. On an adjusted basis, we reported fourth quarter earnings of $370 million or $1.47 per share. Adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter exclude $3 million of expenses related to the development of our proposed LNG liquefaction projects. In addition, in October 2015, an agreement was reached with the SONGS insurance provider for a $400 million payment associated with the failure of the replacement theme generators. Of this amount, SDG&E share was $80 million. After reimbursement of legal fees and an allocation of $75 million of net proceeds to the rate payers, our fourth quarter adjusted earnings exclude a $2 million after-tax adjustment to the loss on the SONGS plant closure. 
Full year 2015 earnings totaled $1,349,000,000 or $5.37 per share. This compares to 2014 earnings of $1,161,000,000 or $4.63 per share. On an adjusted basis, 2015 earnings were $5.21 per share. Year-over-year, adjusted earnings grew 11%.
Individual financial results for each of our businesses can be found in the section of our presentation entitled Business Unit Earnings. 
I will address the key drivers for our consolidated quarterly results now on Slide 9. Compared to the prior year, fourth quarter earnings include a $48 million seasonality impact that increased earnings at SoCalGas. Recall that applying seasonality to earnings at SoCalGas does not affect full year results. Instead, this fourth quarter variance offset seasonality impacts during the first 3 quarters of the year.
At parent, we recorded $21 million of lower tax expense, primarily related to favorable resolution of income tax matters and reduced repatriation of dividends from Mexico. The lower tax expense at parent, along with lower effective tax rates at the California Utilities, were primary reasons why we exceeded our revised 2015 adjusted guidance that we gave on our third quarter call.
Third, SoCalGas recorded $16 million of higher earnings due to higher CPUC base margin, net of operating expenses. Then offsetting these factors was $18 million of lower tax expense in South America in 2014 as a result to Peruvian tax reform. 
Now let's conclude, so please turn to Slide 10. Overall, we delivered strong financial results in 2015 and exceeded our adjusted guidance. Solid growth in operating earnings and confidence in our long-term cash flows supported our decision to raise the 2016 dividend. In order to better align over future dividend growth with projected EPS growth, we are now targeting annual dividend increases of 8% to 9% over the next several years.
Looking ahead over the next 5 years, we continue to anticipate earnings growth around twice the level of our utility sector average. Combined with the strong dividend growth, we aim to provide top-tier total shareholder returns. 
With that, we will conclude our prepared remarks and stop to take any questions you may have.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Debbie, I know that it's not -- in the normal course you usually don't update your 5-year earnings growth forecast until the Analyst Day. But can I take from your comments early in your presentation that you still feel like the -- on the mental building blocks in the prior 5-year plan that drove the earnings growth you articulated last February are still substantially in place?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I think that's an excellent way to put it, actually. If I look at the fundamental building blocks, as you know, our business is based upon long-term contracted and utility assets. And when we lay out our growth rate. The key things that are driving
componenttext: Greg, I think that's an excellent way to put it, actually. If I look at the fundamental building blocks, as you know, our business is based upon long-term contracted and utility assets. And when we lay out our growth rate. The key things that are driving our growth longer term are our Cameron 1 through 3 which are progressing on schedule, on budget and we expect that to come online in 2018, as we've outlined before. Our Mexican pipelines are now, all except for 3 of them, are actually in operation that are contracted. And so, that is going quite well. And then our utility businesses. And the fundamentals of our utility businesses, as you can see from last year's earnings, are very strong. And we would anticipate getting a rate case decision soon. And one reason we want to hold off providing any numeric guidance is we want to get that rate case decision and then be able to go through, as we always do with you, at the analyst meetings, the detail. The other thing that I would just comment on is that in our board felt that there is great visibility to our growth. And since its long-term contracted in utility, they were very comfortable setting an 8% to 9% target for dividend increases over the next several years. And I think that is a really strong statement in our sector to be able to grow your dividend at that kind of rate.

componenttext: That's correct. As we look that is, we told you last March that under the rate case process, that when we go through the rate case process, that there would be a true up on this repairs allowance, and that's approximately $60 million. So our earnings will be reduced for that going into 2016 at our utilities. But then we've reached this rate case settlement. And then we've laid out kind of our guidance for 2016, our assumptions are in a ranges that something similar to the rate case settlement would be adopted. And that's what we would anticipate.

But, so just on the long-term growth rate, so you have 2 data points today, we have twice the utility average and we have 8% to 9% dividend growth that better aligns with long-term earnings growth. Is it fair to say the 8% to 9% is not a view of your long-term earnings growth?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's fair to say. I mean, I'll answer that question. And I'll give you -- I'll use 2015 as an example. We grew 11% in 2015. We increased our dividend by 8%. So I would not link the 2 directly together. What I would look at is what are the fundament
componenttext: Yes, that's fair to say. I mean, I'll answer that question. And I'll give you -- I'll use 2015 as an example. We grew 11% in 2015. We increased our dividend by 8%. So I would not link the 2 directly together. What I would look at is what are the fundamentals of the growth drivers. And the fundamentals of the growth drivers are Cameron getting online on time, our utilities performing well and our Mexican pipelines being constructed and in service and all of that is going quite well.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then on the Cameron 4 update and the decision to kind of move to directly to a contracting as opposed to an MoU, can you just maybe give a little bit more color on why you're doing that? And is that something that customers want? Is that
componenttext: Okay, great. And then on the Cameron 4 update and the decision to kind of move to directly to a contracting as opposed to an MoU, can you just maybe give a little bit more color on why you're doing that? And is that something that customers want? Is that something that's better for you so you don't have to commit as much upfront? I wasn't sure I understood the rationale there.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'm going to ask Octávio to cover that. But what I say is that I see it is better for us. Because we do have a timeframe on which we do have to commit to get Cameron in service and maintain continuous construction. So actually getting the sales and
componenttext: Sure, I'm going to ask Octávio to cover that. But what I say is that I see it is better for us. Because we do have a timeframe on which we do have to commit to get Cameron in service and maintain continuous construction. So actually getting the sales and purchase agreements done and have definitive agreements is a real positive for us. So this is something we like to have in place. Octávio, why don't you go ahead and talk about it from the customer perspective as well?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, thank you. So the reason why is as Deb indicated, that we have a timeframe that's tight and we're trying to take advantage of the long-term pricing that we have from our EPC contractor. So going through an MoU will create an additional step that mig
componenttext: Sure, thank you. So the reason why is as Deb indicated, that we have a timeframe that's tight and we're trying to take advantage of the long-term pricing that we have from our EPC contractor. So going through an MoU will create an additional step that might drag that schedule. And as you know, given the way we structure our deals on the LNG, we're not just selling cargoes for a price, which would be much easier sell, we're actually putting together deals that deal with low commodity risks and essentially long-term capacity for the liquefaction. So we have to speak a lot to our customers about the upstream conditions, where the gas from, where it's delivered, how it's delivered. And those tend to be more complicated sessions. And as a result, we've all decided to go forward -- it wasn't just us, the customers also decided to go that way. So the people we are talking to at this point, we have all agreed to pursue the supply purchase agreements and gas supply agreements as part of our discussions in order for later in the year to have the full commitments to take the commitments we need to make on the capital side to launch the project.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And one last question on Aliso. Can you maybe talk a little bit about the -- and I know this is hard way to root cause analysis. But one is kind of the potential scenarios of like a 6s for the future. And I guess the second question is how --
componenttext: Okay, great. And one last question on Aliso. Can you maybe talk a little bit about the -- and I know this is hard way to root cause analysis. But one is kind of the potential scenarios of like a 6s for the future. And I guess the second question is how -- it does seem like Aliso is a critical facility for reliability in California, can you just talk a little bit about that issue and kind of this conflict with some people wanting it not to start up?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm going to have Dennis address that. What I will say is that the DOGGR has come out with a new set of rules that we're already implementing. And that they are very, very parallel to what we filed a few years back in our rate case for our program t
componenttext: Sure. I'm going to have Dennis address that. What I will say is that the DOGGR has come out with a new set of rules that we're already implementing. And that they are very, very parallel to what we filed a few years back in our rate case for our program that was call storage integrity management program or SIM. And so I think there are processes and things we actually envisioned mission and already have filed for in our rate case that will allow us to safely operate this deal going forward. Dennis, do you want to address further?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, good morning, Steve. As that we talked about our SIM program, the utilities, we have an acronym for everything. But we actually started on a pilot program back in 2014, even before we got an approval. And as you know, we have requested within our Ge
componenttext: Sure, good morning, Steve. As that we talked about our SIM program, the utilities, we have an acronym for everything. But we actually started on a pilot program back in 2014, even before we got an approval. And as you know, we have requested within our General Rate Case for additional funding for our Storage Integrity Management program that were waiting for the final decision there. As far as the importance of Aliso, and just gas storage in general, to both gas and electric reliability. I think it's been very clear with a lot of the comments by both policy and regulatory leaders especially, I mean, from the California Energy Commission as well as the PUC that it's vital that we have safe and reliable gas storage to support not just gas demand, but especially in the Los Angeles basin, electric reliability as well. So we're pleased see that in the visit that the Department of Energy, Secretary [indiscernible] when he came out and visited, he reemphasized the importance of making sure that obviously the facilities are safe, but that we had been back online in order to support both gas and electric reliability. So we know that there is -- as Debbie mentioned, there is a full process that's been approved by DOGGR on their comprehensive safety review. We're working very closely with them on that. There's also some legislation that's been percent had that so far is open to amendments to incorporate the process that DOGGR has laid out. So we're optimistic that sound reminds now from a policy and regulatory and political side recognize the importance of getting Aliso back online as safely and as expeditiously as possible.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: It's been a while since we've gotten an update on Mexico. Obviously, you have 3 bids that are coming up that are pretty important. Could you just comment on the competitive environment there? And what you're seeing? And possible opportunities beyond just the CFE pipes at this point?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll have Mark talk about some of the upcoming bids. A couple of things that I've said before and I'll say again in terms of Mexico, and the key thing for us is that we have a really great set of assets in Mexico that are expandable assets that have
componenttext: Sure, I'll have Mark talk about some of the upcoming bids. A couple of things that I've said before and I'll say again in terms of Mexico, and the key thing for us is that we have a really great set of assets in Mexico that are expandable assets that have additional growth potential. And so, these bids are very important to expand the infrastructure that we own there. But they're not the only way that we can grow in Mexico. And Mexico now has some pipeline bids that are going to be coming for us very soon. We talked about the 3 that are out for bid right now, there will be others that will come out later this year. Mexico is also going out for bid for about 2,500 megawatts of renewables. And we have our ESJ plant operational there, that has the ability to stand by about 1,000 megawatts, so we think that's a great opportunity. And then Mexico, it's looking at going into other areas of bidding with electric transmission and electric generation. So there is bidding, but there's also growth potential that occurs from the great asset bids that we have there. Mark, do you want to talk about kind of the bids and ...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Debbie. There's, as you know, there's 3 pipelines right now that are currently under -- that we've submitted bids for and we're awaiting the redetermination. In total, it's roughly a couple of billion dollars worth of work. We think we're well-posit
componenttext: Sure, Debbie. There's, as you know, there's 3 pipelines right now that are currently under -- that we've submitted bids for and we're awaiting the redetermination. In total, it's roughly a couple of billion dollars worth of work. We think we're well-positioned for it. But as you see, they're us -- and there has been some increased competition for some of these pipeline bids. But we are sticking to our kind of strategy of targeting kind of high single digit IRRs. And we're really looking to try to pick up these ones that we think fit our -- that fit our profile and what we're looking for and obviously we're interested in these at the right price. But I think, the most important thing is that Debbie's point on the opportunities around our existing pipeline footprint, which just to remind everyone, we are the largest pipeline operating in Mexico. We are very well-positioned, not only for this new work, but to expand those opportunities and start building laterals into other industrialized areas. And so we see the opportunity for IEnova in Mexico for continued growth. And I think we've all seen some of the comments on PEMEX over the last few days and their desire to raise additional capital and to think about selling some of their additional assets, we're very well poised to take advantage of those opportunities. Our relationships there are very strong. And so, we are very optimistic about IEnova's growth potential.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just following up a little bit more on the Aliso conversation. Can you elaborate a little bit more on thoughts on next steps, just both from a regulatory process, but perhaps more importantly, from an operational perspective? How do you think about get
componenttext: So just following up a little bit more on the Aliso conversation. Can you elaborate a little bit more on thoughts on next steps, just both from a regulatory process, but perhaps more importantly, from an operational perspective? How do you think about getting the asset back in the service? And then also how do you think about your own investment plan in light of what may be required at a regulatory process and/or working around any limitations on the Aliso Canyon asset itself?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just take a comment on that and then I'm going to refer to Dennis on coming back into operation. I think one thing that's quite positive is that when we filed our rate case, we had actually filed for a program that would do internal inspection
componenttext: Yes. Let me just take a comment on that and then I'm going to refer to Dennis on coming back into operation. I think one thing that's quite positive is that when we filed our rate case, we had actually filed for a program that would do internal inspections of wells and some of the things that have now happened on pipelines. And we've filed for a program that would do that for storage facilities. And that -- in the rate case settlement, we ended up with a two-way balancing account that will allow us to make those kinds of investments to do the review of the storage wells and go through them on a program planned kind of a basis, which is what we have proposed. But getting that all in place now and getting the facility operational for injection season, we've been spending a lot of time looking at how we use that program, which is basically aligned with what the Department of Oil, Gas and Geothermal Resource resources, or DOGGR, have kindly outlined as well. So Dennis, why can you kind of talk about what we're doing now with Aliso and all of our storage facilities?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julien, let me start with Aliso. It's really a 2 pronged approach. First is, we're obviously, as Debbie mentioned, we're cooperating with the investigation that's being led by DOGGR and the CPUC. And they have an independent expert on the outside, a compa
componenttext: Julien, let me start with Aliso. It's really a 2 pronged approach. First is, we're obviously, as Debbie mentioned, we're cooperating with the investigation that's being led by DOGGR and the CPUC. And they have an independent expert on the outside, a company called Blade Energy Partners. And so we're supporting them. And they're really driving the time schedule there, whatever time it takes for them to do the work and do issue the report, will kind of take it's own path. But as far as getting the deal back into service, as I mentioned, DOGGR has issued its comprehensive safety review that were working on them with. And it's very detailed process of testing and inspecting, and if necessary, repairs. As Debbie mentioned, it really does -- it's very parallel to what we have put in place as far as our SIM program and what were doing from a pilot standpoint. So we're working to expeditiously to implement that. It's hard to tell at this point in time how long it will take us to get through all of the 115 wells. But the way that the program is put together, it does allow us, once we've accomplished a minimum threshold of tests on all the wells, we can start bringing some of the wells on, we don't have to do a complete work on 100% of those, we can isolate or abandon certain wells and bring on other wells at the same time. So yes, we'll be giving further updates on that down the road. I think the key point there is, again, policy makers, the regulators and we're very closely working with all of these so that they understand what could happen both here in the summer and electric reliability standpoint and from a gas standpoint. We're all really working together to make sure that Aliso and all of our gas storage facilities are safe and reliable and they can service our customers. We're also -- there also is an emergency regulation that was put in place by DOGGR that applies to all gas storage facilities, not just Aliso. So we're complying with that as well. And that includes things such as daily pressure reads, testing the wellhead valves and some other procedures that have to be put in place. So there's a lot going on, we've got a lot of people at all of our facilities and we're focused again, doing this as expeditiously and as safely as possible.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, excellent. And just quickly following up on one of the last questions, with respect to the decision to move from the MoU to just an outright contract. Let me just be very clear about this, your confidence level is higher incrementally? Or you said
componenttext: Great, excellent. And just quickly following up on one of the last questions, with respect to the decision to move from the MoU to just an outright contract. Let me just be very clear about this, your confidence level is higher incrementally? Or you said obviously less ideal market backdrop. But moving in that step, I would presume to be a statement of comfort that indeed this is moving forward, but I don't want to put words in your mouth either.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Julien. Yes, I mean, there's no question that the market is tougher than it was when we signed Cameron 1 through 3. But Octávio has been negotiating with some very strong counterparties and they want to go to the sales and purchase agreement, and
componenttext: Thanks, Julien. Yes, I mean, there's no question that the market is tougher than it was when we signed Cameron 1 through 3. But Octávio has been negotiating with some very strong counterparties and they want to go to the sales and purchase agreement, and we want to go to a sales and purchase agreement, that will allow us more comfort and starting to spend money on the facilities, because it kind of lays out all the terms and as long as you meet all those terms, they are obligated. And an MoU doesn't have that same level of obligation. So I think getting these sales and purchase agreements signed will give us a lot of confidence in being able to move forward with the facility later this year. Octávio, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that we're pretty much, as Debbie indicated, because we're moving up in this direction, obviously the counterparties are using the resources are expensive, it's law firms or their own internal resources so there's interest involved in this. As you
componenttext: I think that we're pretty much, as Debbie indicated, because we're moving up in this direction, obviously the counterparties are using the resources are expensive, it's law firms or their own internal resources so there's interest involved in this. As you know, this is a facility that's not selling into the current market, it's a facility that's going to sell into the market 2020 plus. And it's going to be one of the lowest, if not the lowest facility at that point in time to deliver LNG, to a time where just about everyone agrees there's going to be a shortage of supply.

componenttext: Most of the -- the majority of the $20 million to $25 million is for Port Arthur and its to do the work that is necessary to design enough of the facility where you can price it so that you can market it. And that is engineering, and legal, and cost and all. And then legal costs associated with the sales and purchases agreement for Cameron and then the related facilities, the pipelines and storage and all of that integrate with that. That's where most of the costs are. componenttext: In Mexico, our character in dollars, but we pay taxes in pesos. So that's why we have the FX issue in Mexico, which usually has usually has recently always been in our favor in Mexico.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little more than a coincidence. There's usually some relation to currency valuations around the world, but it has been more of a one for one offset in the past. It has disconnected a little bit as we move forward.
componenttext: It's a little more than a coincidence. There's usually some relation to currency valuations around the world, but it has been more of a one for one offset in the past. It has disconnected a little bit as we move forward.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Faisel, this is Joe. I'll just add to Mark's comment that the FX benefit in Mexico doesn't have to do with the tariffs because of the all the dollar denominated contracts and dolla denominated business is really the functional currency. And that's really
componenttext: Faisel, this is Joe. I'll just add to Mark's comment that the FX benefit in Mexico doesn't have to do with the tariffs because of the all the dollar denominated contracts and dolla denominated business is really the functional currency. And that's really how we operate in Mexico. But we have to pay our taxes in pesos. And the Mexican tax rules require that we have FX adjustments related to our monetary assets and then taking into account inflation. And so As these currencies kind of move in a similar direction against the U.S. dollar, we get this natural hedge, natural offset.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, why don't you walk through that?
componenttext: Joe, why don't you walk through that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Faisel, let me walk through that, because I think this is important for everybody to understand and we talk about it from time to time. We have some really really well run utilities in South America. And over time, those have done extremely well and
componenttext: Yes, Faisel, let me walk through that, because I think this is important for everybody to understand and we talk about it from time to time. We have some really really well run utilities in South America. And over time, those have done extremely well and you can look back to the early 2000s. And they've done very well over time and we like those assets a lot. But they are local currency run companies. And their revenues are in local currencies. And so we've seen a depreciation against the U.S. dollar, because we had to translate those into dollars of about 15% to 20%, since last year's plan. So when we did the 2016 plan last year and showed you a number, those currencies have depreciated 15% to 20%. And there's, to some degrees, some offset in our tariffs because they catch-up over time because we have adjustments in our tariffs. But we've adjusted the revenues or the net earnings from those companies for that change in FX rates from a year ago to the ones we have now. In Mexico, the tax expense I was just referring to a moment ago, that's an annual adjustment, it kind of goes from what was the peso at the beginning of the year to what is it going to be at the end of the year. And I think Debbie mentioned in her remarks that we haven't had this in our planning in the past. And the reason is we're not allowed to under accounting, under GAAP accounting rules, we're not allowed to forecast that. But this year we put it in the plan, because we know that the Mexican peso is forecasted to move about 3.5%. And so we forecasted a change in our tax expense for that 3.5%. And so in 2016, we see a little bit of a loss there. In 2015, we actually had earnings as a result of this. We had $31 million increase at Mexico and a $20 million decrease in South America. So we had $11 million plus. So again, in 2013, 2014, it was neutral, and between 2015 and 2016, it's going to be kind of neutral. These things don't move the needle very much for us, they're pretty small.

So I want to understand why it would be down here year-over-year.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: One question on the LNG and less about share contracting and maybe more about the broader LNG markets. I mean, if you read the stuff that comes out of a lot of the economic consulting firms or the other folks, they tend to talk about the LNG market is ove
componenttext: One question on the LNG and less about share contracting and maybe more about the broader LNG markets. I mean, if you read the stuff that comes out of a lot of the economic consulting firms or the other folks, they tend to talk about the LNG market is oversupplied. And so that would imply that it would be a headwind for any new LNG development? And yet it would seem that some of the things that you talk about in Cameron or in Port Arthur that your views and your actions and potential growth or kind of contrary to that. Just curious if you could talk a little bit about the global LNG market, what you see for the near term, what you see for the long-term?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'm going to ask Octávio to answer that. But what I want to raise to you, is a lot of this is about time frame. And that what you read about is the current LNG market is seen as being oversupplied. What you also read about is that beginning in the
componenttext: Sure, I'm going to ask Octávio to answer that. But what I want to raise to you, is a lot of this is about time frame. And that what you read about is the current LNG market is seen as being oversupplied. What you also read about is that beginning in the 2020 period and beyond, there is a need in the marketplace for more LNG. So a part of it is the timing of these things. If you are having a non-contracted project coming on today, that might be a real challenge. If you have a project coming on where there's a market need and that market need grows over time, then that's a very different market that you're going after. So Octávio, why don't you talk about the broad market and how we feel that our facilities are going to compete in that market?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me give a good introduction to the timeframe issue. One thing that we need start to look at, is the current market is oversupplied as you indicated, no discussion about that. But we also have a little problem with the current market. We have an oversu
componenttext: Let me give a good introduction to the timeframe issue. One thing that we need start to look at, is the current market is oversupplied as you indicated, no discussion about that. But we also have a little problem with the current market. We have an oversupplied market and yet the spot cargoes are more expensive than the long-term pricing, which was agreed in the tight market. So the market is broken in its pricing formula and the market is adjusting to it as we speak and will adjust for the next couple of years. But our focus is not the current market. Our focus is that 2020, as Debbie indicated, where you'll see that the current oversupply will be absorbed then there's a shortage, and then fortunately or unfortunately, depending on your point of view, these facilities take 5, 6 years to come online once you decide to go forward. And then as a result, we need to make decisions today to meet that demand. It is difficult to make. It's largely very capital investments when a lot of the big players are taking write-downs because of oil, that's the condition where the market is tough. Some of the buyers are confused with the oversupply. But our focus is not the current market. So Globally, believe we're going to switch everything from gas to coal and oil which will increase our current footprint significantly which seems like the wins or the other way around. If you believe that we're going forward not only with the continuous economic growth, but with a change to a lower carbon footprint, then gas is going to play a role not just in the current market but in other markets that are yet to open. One interesting statistic I heard this week at [indiscernible] week was the fact that the lower demand from Korea and Japan was made up by increased demand in Middle East countries and therefore the demand didn't go away. And that was not there in the earlier projections. So globally, where our projects fit, we are comfortable, it is a tough market for people to make decisions when they're under significant pressure. But we think we are offering to the market the lowest cost producing facility for 2020, that's why the interest is there.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I remember at one of your investor meetings, you outlined where your facilities, I think it was your last Analyst Day, you outlined where your facilities sit on kind of the cost curve relative to other LNG facilities. Just curious given the fact that
componenttext: And I remember at one of your investor meetings, you outlined where your facilities, I think it was your last Analyst Day, you outlined where your facilities sit on kind of the cost curve relative to other LNG facilities. Just curious given the fact that Port Arthur is green fielding and Cameron was Brownfield. The thing that surprised us back then and surprised us a little bit now is that they're so close on to each other on that dispatch curve, compared to some of the others. How are you thinking about how the economics of Port Arthur as a Greenfield will differ for some of the disclosures that you've given previously on Cameron 1 through 3?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a very good question and I'll be happy to bring up another topic that's forgotten. Regarding in economics of the the Cameron -- Cameron, pardon me. In the Cameron based projects, we included the $1 billion of the cost of the existing facilities, wh
componenttext: That's a very good question and I'll be happy to bring up another topic that's forgotten. Regarding in economics of the the Cameron -- Cameron, pardon me. In the Cameron based projects, we included the $1 billion of the cost of the existing facilities, which is essentially replacement value. So the economics of Cameron in that chart you saw at Analyst Day as well as all the other charts included the value of existing facilities. And so, what we are doing with Woodside and Port Arthur is looking at ways to break some of the paradigms in the industry, keep it as safe and reliable as we wanted to be, as the customers expected to be, but look at ways to reduce cost, just like we found when we did Cameron when we had the lower cost per ton for the Congressional technology liquefaction. We had an even lower price for the expansion of Cameron for trains 4 and 5 and we expect to see similar results for Port Arthur. If we don't find that we can do that, that Port Arthur is not going to go away. We simply believe that the industry has to be going back to a discipline of developing the next lowest marginal cost of supply available in order to be sustainable.

componenttextpreview: I'm not sure what expectations you're referring to. What we're very focused on is that the growth that we have outlined for you in our plan is long-term contracted growth are in our utility. And that what we put in our base plan is things that we already
componenttext: I'm not sure what expectations you're referring to. What we're very focused on is that the growth that we have outlined for you in our plan is long-term contracted growth are in our utility. And that what we put in our base plan is things that we already have under contract and then expected utility performance. What we expect to do is over the next 5 years, we expect to add projects to that. This last year alone, we added 325 megawatts of renewables that will come online late this year. We've added or we'll be adding when the transaction closes the PEMEX acquisition, that was not part of our base plan a year ago. So our expectations are that we are not going to sit still. We're going to continue to develop and grow our business. And that what we show you though in terms of our growth is when we get to our analyst conference, what do what we always do, which us the blue box and the green box that shows you what we have contract and it was basically in our utilities is projects approved in our rate case. And then we show you what we are working on that could add to that growth over the five-year period of time. And we'll be doing the same thing for you this year.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for all the comments on the LNG market today. I did want to ask one more question about Mexico. And I know that some of the pressure on PEMEX does create an opportunity in some of the assets they might be looking to offload. And I'm wondering if yo
componenttext: Thanks for all the comments on the LNG market today. I did want to ask one more question about Mexico. And I know that some of the pressure on PEMEX does create an opportunity in some of the assets they might be looking to offload. And I'm wondering if you see beyond maybe this current slate of projects some headwinds, just from the lower oil revenues on -- from the Mexican government. And maybe if you could talk about how you see that balance of opportunities versus challenge?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, honestly when you talk to our CEO in Mexico, he sees it as an opportunity, because of the whole reason for reform was to bring capital into Mexico to build the kind of infrastructure that they need for the kind of growth. And you have to real
componenttext: Yes, I mean, honestly when you talk to our CEO in Mexico, he sees it as an opportunity, because of the whole reason for reform was to bring capital into Mexico to build the kind of infrastructure that they need for the kind of growth. And you have to realize, Mexico is going to be more competitive, the lower the energy prices are and the long term for them. That has been kind of their stumbling block on being globally competitive. So to the degree that they can use other parties capital. And that would be us, I mean, we'd like to put our capital there. And that they can build the infrastructure that reduces their energy cost that they are moving forward on that basis. And so we think that -- I think it's a struggle for PEMEX with having been reliant on oil revenues. But it's an opportunity for us to come in and build things that wouldn't otherwise be built and that are needed as part of the long-term Mexican infrastructure. So that's kind of the way we look at it. Mark, do you want to?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me just add to that too. I think that the -- when we talk about energy reform in Mexico, I think a lot of folks are focused on the reforms of PEMEX. And they haven't seen increases in production and some of the things that they wanted to see from
componenttext: Yes, let me just add to that too. I think that the -- when we talk about energy reform in Mexico, I think a lot of folks are focused on the reforms of PEMEX. And they haven't seen increases in production and some of the things that they wanted to see from energy reform. And I think that's entirely the fault of $30 oil and very little to do with the reforms. What are coming out of the reforms is the massive amount of it energy infrastructure within the company -- within the country. And that infrastructure is doing exactly what its supposed to do. As Debbie said, it's lowering energy cost, bringing natural gas in the region of the country that didn't have access to it before. It's making it -- it's really making a big difference in lowering electricity costs across the country. And that's working very, very well. And to the extent that low gas -- low oil prices are hindering some of the reforms at PEMEX, I think that again is creating a large opportunity for us, because it increases the need for PEMEX for capital, it gives opportunities for us to look at the assets that they're going to be putting up for sale. And so, from our perspective, I think we think that the reforms are working very much as intended. And we will continue to benefit as being one of the best placed companies in the country to take advantage of those opportunities.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Financial Presentation. A live webcast for this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. Here in San Diego are several m
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Financial Presentation. A live webcast for this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. 
Here in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Chairman and CEO; Mark Snell, President; Joe Householder, Chief Financial Officer; Martha Wyrsch, General Counsel; Trevor Mihalik, Chief Accounting Officer; Dennis Arriola, Chief Executive Officer of SoCalGas; Jeff Martin, Chief Executive Officer of SDG&E; and Octávio Simões, President of Sempra LNG. 
Before starting, I would like to remind everyone that we will be discussing forward-looking statements on this call within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. The factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially are discussed in the company's most recent 10-K filed with the SEC. 
It's important to note that all of the earnings per share amounts in our presentation are shown on a diluted basis and that we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the presentation slides that accompany this call and to Table A in our fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings press release for a reconciliation to GAAP measures. 
I'd also like to note that the forward-looking statements contained in this presentation speak only as of today, February 26, 2016, and the company does not assume any obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements in the future. 
With that, please turn to Slide 4, and let me hand the call over to Debbie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. Before discussing the quarter, I would like to say a few words about the natural gas leak at our Aliso Canyon storage facility. On February 18, the Division of Oil, Gas and Geothermal Resources, or DOGGR, confirmed that the leaking well was
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. Before discussing the quarter, I would like to say a few words about the natural gas leak at our Aliso Canyon storage facility. On February 18, the Division of Oil, Gas and Geothermal Resources, or DOGGR, confirmed that the leaking well was permanently sealed. Our focus since the beginning has been on safely stopping the leak, reducing the odor from the well, reducing the amount of natural gas being emitted into the environment, working cooperatively with agencies and elected officials and supporting local residents, including providing temporary housing and air filtration systems. Now that we have stopped the leak, an independent investigation of the root cause will be conducted. I want to emphasize that providing safe and reliable service to our customers is the highest priority for SoCalGas. We will continue to work with our regulators and customers to ensure our path ahead reflects these values. 
Later, I will provide more information on Aliso Canyon, and Dennis and Martha are also here to address your questions. 
Turning to our financial performance. In 2015, we had very strong results and exceeded our adjusted earnings guidance. This morning, we reported full year earnings of $5.37 per share or $5.21 per share on an adjusted basis. Our 2015 results were driven largely by growth in operating earnings at our California Utilities and Sempra International.
In addition, our board approved an increase in the 2016 dividend to $3.02 per share. This payout represents an 8% annual increase and provides dividend growth that more closely aligns with the 11% annual increase in our 2015 adjusted earnings. Moreover, we are targeting annual dividend increases of 8% to 9% over the next several years to better align our dividend growth with our projected EPS growth. Our dividend strategy is underpinned by confidence in our future cash flows and supports our commitment to return capital to our shareholders.
Regarding 2016 earnings. We have updated our assumptions and are providing an adjusted EPS guidance range of $4.80 per share to $5.20 per share. When compared with the 2015 results, we forecast a higher effective tax rate for 2016. In part, this is due to a large number of benefits recorded last year that related to the resolution of tax matters. 
Also, as we move into the new GRC cycle at our California Utilities, we will now be providing an estimated $60 million of repair allowance tax benefits to ratepayers as part of the standard rate case true-up. In our 2016 adjusted guidance, we assume that we retain all repair allowance benefits for tax years preceding our new GRC. Key updates and comparisons to the 2016 guidance we provided at last year's analyst conference reflects several other factors. Notably, we include our best estimate of the GRC decision for the California Utilities based on our settlement agreement as well as new market assumptions for commodities and foreign exchange rates that have changed considerably since last year. Additionally, our adjusted guidance range now includes approximately $20 million to $25 million of estimated LNG development expense. 
Regarding transactions we announced last year that were additive to our base plan, such as the potential PEMEX acquisition and NEIL renewable contract, we expect the earnings impact to largely occur in 2017 and beyond. 
Please note that our proposed GRC settlement agreement is subject to CPUC approval, and we do not anticipate receiving a final decision until the second quarter. We have moved our analyst conference to May in order to incorporate an expected final GRC decision and will provide you with our business unit guidance and longer-term projections at that time. Overall, we are well positioned to achieve our long-term strategy of providing earnings growth that is twice that of the average utility, but with a moderate risk profile. Combined with strong anticipated growth in the dividend, we are focused on providing top-tier shareholder return. 
Now please turn to Slide 5. This slide summarizes the key assumptions included in our 2016 adjusted EPS guidance, and we'll briefly discuss each item and you can find additional detail in the appendix. 
First, as I mentioned earlier, this year, we include development cost for our LNG liquefaction and related infrastructure opportunities. In 2015, we had about $10 million of similar expense that was excluded from adjusted guidance due to uncertainty about the nature and timing of these costs. Given progress on the projects and our estimates of the spend rate and amounts capitalized and shared with partners, we now include a 2016 after-tax expense of roughly $0.08 to $0.10 per share. Please note, however, that the vast majority of planned expense is targeted for Port Arthur and related infrastructure, as we have already incurred most of the upfront cost for Cameron expansions. Going forward, we will be sharing cost for Port Arthur with our partner, Woodside. We will nevertheless monitor our progress in securing market commitments and other needed approvals to advance the project. To the extent our progress is slower than expected, we will adjust our spending accordingly.
Next, we have seen a significant decline in natural gas price forecast over the past year. Specifically, the Cal border [ph] 2016 forward curve has fallen from $3.60 in our prior guidance to $2.60 in our new adjusted guidance. The impact from this assumption is a reduction in earnings of approximately $0.05 to $0.07 per share that is associated with the LNG marketing contract from our ICA import facility in Mexico. 
Third, we reduced projected earnings from the TDM power plant due to lower power places and lower expected capacity revenues. This month, IEnova decided to hold the asset for sale. The sale would complete our exit from merchant generation and allow IEnova to deploy capital in projects that provide more stable earnings. 
While we project approximately $0.04 to $0.06 per share of reduced earnings associated with TDM, we do not consider any potential gain or loss from the sale in our adjusted guidance. 
Moving to parent. We assume that we will use dividends from Mexico to participate in a potential IEnova equity offering. We forecast a 2016 earnings benefit from lower repatriation tax expense of between $0.08 and $0.10 per share. Offsetting this impact is an estimated $0.04 per share after tax of higher interest expense to fund projects in our base plan. 
Next, like natural gas prices, we have seen exchange rate forecasts move significantly over the past year. Relative to our previous guidance, our current forecast is for the dollar to strengthen in 2016 by an additional 20% against the Chilean currency and by an additional 13% against the Peruvian currency. Projected earnings are reduced by roughly $0.09 to $0.11 per share as a result of translating South American earnings into dollars.
In Mexico, we have not previously forecast the impact of foreign currency effects. We now include in our adjusted guidance a reduction in tax expense associated with peso depreciation during 2016. Based upon the forward curve at year-end, we estimate this benefit to be approximately $0.05 to $0.07 per share. 
With regard to IEnova's acquisition of PEMEX's ownership and their shared joint venture, Mexico's Competition Commission has required PEMEX to competitively auction 2 assets included in the original transaction. IEnova is negotiating changes to the original agreement with PEMEX that will reflect the auction outcome, among other things. Our adjusted guidance assumes that the transaction moves forward with the same assets and closes in the third quarter of 2016. Based on this timing, we assume an estimated $0.02 of accretion this year. Our adjusted guidance excludes, however, any potential gain associated with the remeasurement of our investment in the joint venture.
In our renewables business, we incorporate new forecast for wind resource and availability that reduced earnings by approximately $0.02 per share. However, our base plan now includes 328 megawatts of additional projects announced last year that are under construction. Given that these projects are expected to be in operation by the end of 2016, we expect to see the full earnings impact beginning in 2017.
Finally, for the California Utilities, our prior guidance was based on a very conservative assumption that revenues would be based on our current attrition mechanism with no further adjustments. Our new adjusted guidance range includes projected earnings that more closely align with the GRC settlement agreement and our best estimate of the outcome given the record in the proceeding. 
Now let's go to Slide 6 for a business update, beginning with the California Utilities. In our general rate case, we are currently expecting to see a proposed decision in March and to receive the final decision in the second quarter. As you recall, we reached a multiparty settlement agreement with the major parties in the case. Until we get a final GRC decision, we will record revenues based upon the authorized revenue requirement in 2015. When we receive the final decision, we will make an adjustment to reflect the retroactive earnings back to January 1, 2016. 
Turning to Aliso Canyon. We have received confirmation from DOGGR, the California agency responsible for regulating gas storage, that the leaking well has been permanently sealed. We have approximately 15 Bcf of natural gas in the storage field, and the field is stable. Moving forward, an independent engineering firm has been selected by DOGGR and the CPUC to investigate the root cause of the leak. While we do not know how long this process will take, we will cooperate on the investigation and share publicly available data.
Consistent with new rules under development, we are implementing enhanced leak detection and well inspection activities. We are also working cooperatively with all of the agencies involved to determine a path forward for the facility, which is regarded as integral to the reliability of the electric grid in California. 
Reflecting the most up-to-date information, which primarily includes revised temporary relocation and well drilling expenses, we now estimate the total cost for amounts paid and those forecasted to be paid to be approximately $330 million. Of this amount, approximately 90% is for the temporary relocation program, cost to address the leak and attempts to stop or reduce the emissions. The remaining amount includes, among other items, the value of lost gas and estimated cost to mitigate the GHG emissions. For the estimate, we assume the relocation period for the majority of residents ended on February 25, as agreed upon with the City of Los Angeles. We have concluded it is probable that we will receive insurance recovery for the total amount, less retentions, of $325 million.
Beyond this estimate, we cannot predict all of the potential categories or total amount of future costs that we may incur as a result of the leak. We have at least 4 types of insurance policies that provide an excess of $1 billion in insurance coverage. Based upon what we know today, and subject to various policy limits, exclusions and conditions, we believe that our insurance should also cover the following categories not included in our estimates: costs associated with litigation and claims by nearby residents and businesses; and in some circumstances, depending upon their nature and matter of assessment, fines and penalties. I refer you to our 10-K for further detail. 
Please turn to Slide 7. In Mexico, CFE is tendering several more gas pipelines. IEnova submitted a bid for one pipeline earlier this month, is in process of submitting a bid for a second and is preparing to submit a third bid in March. According to CFE estimates, the 3 pipelines represent an investment opportunity of almost $2 billion, and we expect award dates to occur in March and April. 
This spring, IEnova is also preparing to participate in Mexico's first auction of renewable energy certificate. IEnova is looking at potential solar opportunities and may submit a bid to expand the ESJ wind facility with its joint venture partner, Intergen. The CFE will be the initial off-taker under 15- to 20-year contracts, and total awards could amount to 2,500 megawatts of new power generation.
In our LNG business, there have been 2 noteworthy developments. Our Cameron Expansion project received its FERC environmental assessment on February 12, and we expect to receive the FERC permit in the second quarter. Though current market conditions are not ideal, Cameron Train 4 is a very competitive market offering for long-term buyers. Based on recent meetings with potential customers, we are bypassing the memorandum of understanding stage and are in negotiations for definitive 20-year sales and purchase agreements. While a sales and purchase agreement will take longer to execute than an MOU, we are targeting the second half of 2016 for announcing customer agreements needed to launch the project. This approach provides us greater certainty on project commitments prior to incurring large capital expenditures.
For Port Arthur, yesterday, we signed a joint development agreement with Woodside Petroleum that outlines development roles in the potential project. In addition to how we will share cost and market capacity, the agreement provides a framework for how we will work together technically to design a cost-competitive plant. 
Last month, I was in Australia meeting with the CEO and senior management of Woodside. And we shared a view that Port Arthur has good market prospects post 2020. 
Before moving on, remember that we have not incorporated additional LNG or other growth projects in our guidance. We are actively working on development opportunities across our businesses that could provide upside to both our near-term and long-term projections. 
With that, please turn to Slide 8, and Joe will discuss our financial results. Joe?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Earlier this morning, we reported fourth quarter earnings of $369 million. On an adjusted basis, we reported fourth quarter earnings of $370 million or $1.47 per share. Adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter exclude $3 million of expenses
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. Earlier this morning, we reported fourth quarter earnings of $369 million. On an adjusted basis, we reported fourth quarter earnings of $370 million or $1.47 per share. Adjusted earnings in the fourth quarter exclude $3 million of expenses related to the development of our proposed LNG liquefaction projects. In addition, in October 2015, an agreement was reached with the SONGS insurance provider for a $400 million payment associated with the failure of the replacement steam generators. Of this amount, SDG&E's share was $80 million. After reimbursement of legal fees and an allocation of $75 million of net proceeds to the ratepayers, our fourth quarter adjusted earnings exclude a $2 million after-tax adjustment to the loss on the SONGS plant closure. 
Full year 2015 earnings totaled $1,349,000,000 or $5.37 per share. This compares to 2014 earnings of $1,161,000,000 or $4.63 per share. On an adjusted basis, 2015 earnings were $5.21 per share. Year-over-year, adjusted earnings grew 11%.
Individual financial results for each of our businesses can be found in the section of our presentation entitled Business Unit Earnings. 
I will address the key drivers for our consolidated quarterly results now on Slide 9. Compared to the prior year, fourth quarter earnings include a $48 million seasonality impact that increased earnings at SoCalGas. Recall that applying seasonality to earnings at SoCalGas does not affect full year results. Instead, this fourth quarter variance offsets seasonality impacts during the first 3 quarters of the year.
At parent, we recorded $21 million of lower tax expense, primarily related to favorable resolution of prior year's income tax matters and reduced repatriation of dividends from Mexico. The lower tax expense at parent along with lower effective tax rates at the California Utilities were primary reasons why we exceeded our revised 2015 adjusted guidance that we gave on our third quarter call.
Third, SoCalGas recorded $16 million of higher earnings due to higher CPUC base margin, net of operating expenses. And offsetting these factors was $18 million of lower tax expense in South America in 2014 as a result of Peruvian tax reform. 
Now let's conclude, so please turn to Slide 10. Overall, we delivered strong financial results in 2015 and exceeded our adjusted guidance. Solid growth in operating earnings and confidence in our long-term cash flows supported our decision to raise the 2016 dividend. In order to better align our future dividend growth with projected EPS growth, we are now targeting annual dividend increases of 8% to 9% over the next several years.
Looking ahead over the next 5 years, we continue to anticipate earnings growth around twice the level of our utility sector average. Combined with the strong dividend growth, we aim to provide top-tier total shareholder returns. 
With that, we will conclude our prepared remarks and stop to take any questions you may have.
