componenttext: It's been a while since we've gotten an update on Mexico. Obviously, you have 3 bids coming up that are pretty important. Could you just comment on the competitive environment there and what you're seeing, and possible opportunities beyond just the CFE pipes at this point?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll have Mark talk about some of the upcoming bids, but what -- a couple of things I've said before, and I'll say it again, in terms of Mexico. And the key thing for us is that we have a really great set of assets in Mexico that are expandable asse
componenttext: Sure, I'll have Mark talk about some of the upcoming bids, but what -- a couple of things I've said before, and I'll say it again, in terms of Mexico. And the key thing for us is that we have a really great set of assets in Mexico that are expandable assets that have additional growth potential. And so these bids are very important to expand the infrastructure that we own there, but they're not the only way that we can grow in Mexico. And Mexico now has some pipeline bids that are going to be coming forth very soon. We talked about the 3 that are out for bid right now. There'll be others that will come out later this year. Mexico is also going out for bid for about 2,500 megawatts of renewables. And we have our ESJ plant operational there that has the ability to expand by about 1,000 megawatts. So we think that's a great opportunity. And then, Mexico is looking at going into other areas of bidding with electric transmission and electric generation. So there's bidding, but there's also growth potential that occurs from the great asset bids that we have there. Mark, do you want to talk about kind of the bids and...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Debbie. There's -- as you know, there's 3 pipelines right now that are currently under -- that we've submitted bids for, and we're awaiting the determination. In total, it's roughly a couple billion dollars’ worth of work, and we think we're well
componenttext: Sure, Debbie. There's -- as you know, there's 3 pipelines right now that are currently under -- that we've submitted bids for, and we're awaiting the determination. In total, it's roughly a couple billion dollars’ worth of work, and we think we're well positioned for it. But as you've seen, there are -- there has been some increased competition for some of these pipeline bids. But we're sticking to our kind of strategy of targeting kind of high single-digit IRRs, and we're really looking to try to pick up these ones that we think fit our -- that fit our profile and what we're looking for, and obviously, we're interested in these at the right price. But I think the most important thing, as Debbie's point, is on the opportunities around our existing pipeline footprint, which, just to remind everyone, we are the largest pipeline operator in Mexico. We're very well positioned, not only for this new work, but to expand those opportunities and start building laterals into other industrialized areas. And so we see the opportunity for IEnova in Mexico for continued growth. And I think we've all seen some of the comments on PEMEX over the last few days and their desire to raise additional capital and to think about selling some of their additional assets. We're very well poised to take advantage of those opportunities. Our relationships there are very strong. And so we're very optimistic about IEnova's growth potential.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, we feel comfortable that we're going to get a decision, a proposed decision in the March time frame. I mean, that's what we're looking at. So we think that the settlement -- we think it's likely to get adopted, and that -- we think that we should have a decision, hopefully, sometime in the second quarter.

componenttext: So just following up a little bit more on the Aliso conversation. headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just make a comment on that, and then I'm going to refer to Dennis on coming back into operation. I think one thing that's quite positive is that when we filed our rate case, we had actually filed for a program that would do internal inspectio
componenttext: Yes. Let me just make a comment on that, and then I'm going to refer to Dennis on coming back into operation. I think one thing that's quite positive is that when we filed our rate case, we had actually filed for a program that would do internal inspections of wells and some of the things that have now happened on pipelines. And we filed for a program that would do that for storage facilities. And that -- in the rate case settlement, we ended up with a 2-way balancing account that would allow us to make those kinds of investments to do the review of those storage wells and go through them on a programmed plan kind of a basis, which is what we had proposed. But getting that all in place now and getting the facility operational for injection season, we've been spending a lot of time looking at how we use that program, which is basically aligned with what the Department of Oil, Gas and Geothermal Resource, or DOGGR, has kind of outlined as well. So Dennis, why don't you kind of talk about what we're doing now with Aliso and all of our storage facilities? Yes.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Julien, let me start with Aliso, and it's kind of really a 2-pronged approach. First is we're obviously, as Debbie mentioned, we're cooperating with the investigation that's being led by DOGGR and the CPUC, and they have an independent expert on the
componenttext: Sure. Julien, let me start with Aliso, and it's kind of really a 2-pronged approach. First is we're obviously, as Debbie mentioned, we're cooperating with the investigation that's being led by DOGGR and the CPUC, and they have an independent expert on the outside, a company called Blade Energy Partners. And so we're supporting them. And they're really driving the time schedule there, so whatever time it takes for them to do their work and to issue their report will kind of take its own path. But as far as getting the field back into service, as I mentioned, DOGGR has issued its comprehensive safety review that we're working with them on. And it's a very detailed process of testing, inspecting and, if necessary, repairs. And as Debbie mentioned, it really does -- it's very parallels what we had put in place as far as our SIMP program and what we were doing from a pilot standpoint. So we're working to expeditiously implement that. It's hard to tell at this point in time how long it'll take us to get through all of the 115 wells. But the way that the program is put together, it does allow us, once we've accomplished a minimum threshold of tests on all the wells, we can start bringing some of the wells on. We don't have to do complete work on 100% of those. We can isolate or abandon certain wells and bring on other wells at the same time. So we'll be giving further updates on that down the road. But I think the key point there is, again, policy makers, the regulators -- and we're very closely working with all of these so that they understand what could happen both here in the summer from an electric reliability standpoint and from a gas standpoint. We're all really working together to make sure that Aliso and all of our gas storage facilities are safe and reliable and they can service our customers. We're also -- there also is an emergency regulation that was put in place by DOGGR that applies to all gas storage facilities, not just Aliso, and so we're complying with that as well. And that includes things such as daily pressure reads, testing the wellhead valves and some other procedures that have to be put in place. So there's a lot going on. We've got a lot of people at all of our facilities, and we're focused on, again, doing this as expeditiously and as safely as possible.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, excellent. And just quickly following up on one of the last questions with respect to the decision to move from an MOU to just an outright contract. Let me just be very clear about this. Your confidence level is higher incrementally? Or you said, o
componenttext: Great, excellent. And just quickly following up on one of the last questions with respect to the decision to move from an MOU to just an outright contract. Let me just be very clear about this. Your confidence level is higher incrementally? Or you said, obviously, less ideal market backdrop. But moving in that step, I would presume to be a statement of comfort that, indeed, this is moving forward. But I don't want to put words in your mouth, either.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Julien. Yes, I mean, it -- there's no question that the market is tougher than it was when we signed Cameron 1 through 3. But Octávio has been negotiating with some very strong counterparties, and they want to go to a sales and purchase agreement
componenttext: Thanks, Julien. Yes, I mean, it -- there's no question that the market is tougher than it was when we signed Cameron 1 through 3. But Octávio has been negotiating with some very strong counterparties, and they want to go to a sales and purchase agreement, we want to go to a sales and purchase agreement. That would allow us more comfort in starting to spend money on the facility, because it kind of lays out all the terms. And as long as you meet those terms, then they're obligated. And an MOU doesn't have that same level of obligation. So I think getting these sales and purchase agreements signed would give us a lot of confidence in being able to move forward with the facility later this year. Octávio, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that we're pretty much -- as Debbie indicated, it's good that we're moving in this direction. Obviously, the counterparties are using resources that are expensive, whether it's law firms or their own internal resources, so there's interest inv
componenttext: No. I think that we're pretty much -- as Debbie indicated, it's good that we're moving in this direction. Obviously, the counterparties are using resources that are expensive, whether it's law firms or their own internal resources, so there's interest involved in this. As you know, this is a facility that's not selling into the current market. It's a facility that's going to sell into the market 2020 plus. And it's going to be one of the lowest, if not the lowest, facility at that point in time to deliver LNG to a time where, just about anyone agrees, there's going to be a shortage of supply.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Just the decision to expense some of the LNG development expenses, was that for Port Arthur? Or was that for Cameron's Trains 4 and 5?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of the -- the majority of the $20 million to $25 million is for Port Arthur, and it's to do the work that's necessary to design enough of the facility where you can price it so you can market it, and that is engineering and legal costs and all. And t
componenttext: Most of the -- the majority of the $20 million to $25 million is for Port Arthur, and it's to do the work that's necessary to design enough of the facility where you can price it so you can market it, and that is engineering and legal costs and all. And then, legal costs associated with the sales and purchases agreements for Cameron and then the related facilities, the pipelines and storage and all of that integrate with that. That's what most of the costs are. And they're expense because those are the accounting rules. Once we get contracts signed, then we would expect this expense to not be part of our ongoing guidance, because we'll spend the funds once. And once we get contracts signed, then we would begin capitalization of the substantial part of the project cost.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay, got you. And then, in terms of -- as you enter into these negotiations for trains 4 -- or for Train 4, I mean, what are the hurdle rates you're looking at in terms of return on capital for the project? I mean, is it similar to the IRRs you were talking about with the Mexico pipelines that are 9%? Or is it higher? How do you guys look at the returns?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't share that because we're still negotiating with customers. But we always look at what our cost of capital is on a risk-adjusted basis and that we would have a reasonable return for that. So I mean, that's the way we would be looking at it.
componenttext: Well, we don't share that because we're still negotiating with customers. But we always look at what our cost of capital is on a risk-adjusted basis and that we would have a reasonable return for that. So I mean, that's the way we would be looking at it. And our returns tend to be in the high single digits, low double digits for most of our projects, so.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And can you remind us, on the pipelines in Mexico, the tariffs are in dollar-denominated terms, is that correct? Or am I -- or is some of them in peso terms?
componenttext: Got it. And can you remind us, on the pipelines in Mexico, the tariffs are in dollar-denominated terms, is that correct? Or am I -- or is some of them in peso terms?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Mexico, our tariffs are in dollars, but we pay taxes in pesos. And so that's why we have the FX issue in Mexico, which usually has -- recently has always been in our favor in Mexico.
componenttext: In Mexico, our tariffs are in dollars, but we pay taxes in pesos. And so that's why we have the FX issue in Mexico, which usually has -- recently has always been in our favor in Mexico.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it just happens to be a coincidence that the tax benefit in Mexico offsets the currency depreciation in Chile and Peru?
componenttext: So it just happens to be a coincidence that the tax benefit in Mexico offsets the currency depreciation in Chile and Peru?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little more than a coincidence. There usually is some relation to currency valuations around the world, but it has been more of a one-for-one offset in the past. It has disconnected a little bit as we've moved forward.
componenttext: It's a little more than a coincidence. There usually is some relation to currency valuations around the world, but it has been more of a one-for-one offset in the past. It has disconnected a little bit as we've moved forward.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Faisel, this is Joe. I'll just add on to Mark's comment. The FX benefit in Mexico doesn't have to do with the tariffs because all of the dollar-denominated contracts in our dollar-denominated business is really the functional currency, and that's how we o
componenttext: Faisel, this is Joe. I'll just add on to Mark's comment. The FX benefit in Mexico doesn't have to do with the tariffs because all of the dollar-denominated contracts in our dollar-denominated business is really the functional currency, and that's how we operate in Mexico. But we have to pay our taxes in pesos. And the Mexican tax rules require that we have FX adjustments related to our monetary assets and then taking into account inflation. And so as these currencies kind of move in a similar direction against the U.S. dollar, we get this natural hedge, natural offset.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That makes sense. And then, when you talk about your guidance though for '16, you're talking about a further depreciation in some of these currencies? Or are you just looking at the forward rates? I just want to make sure I understood that line [ind
componenttext: Okay. That makes sense. And then, when you talk about your guidance though for '16, you're talking about a further depreciation in some of these currencies? Or are you just looking at the forward rates? I just want to make sure I understood that line [indiscernible]

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe, why don't you walk through that?
componenttext: Yes, Joe, why don't you walk through that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, let me walk through that, Faisel, because I think this is important for everybody to understand, and we talk about it from time to time. But we have some really, really well-run utilities in South America. And over time, those have done extremel
componenttext: Yes. Yes, let me walk through that, Faisel, because I think this is important for everybody to understand, and we talk about it from time to time. But we have some really, really well-run utilities in South America. And over time, those have done extremely well, and you can look back to the early 2000s. They've done very well over time, and we like those assets a lot. But they are local currency-run companies, and their revenues are in local currency. And so we've seen a depreciation against the U.S. dollar, because we have to translate those into dollars, of about 15% to 20% since last year's plan. So when we did the 2016 plan last year and showed you a number, those currencies have depreciated 15% to 20%. And there's, to some degree, some offset in our tariffs and they catch up over time because we have adjustments in our tariffs. But we've adjusted the revenues or the net earnings from those companies for that change in FX rates from a year ago to the ones we have now. In Mexico, the tax expense I was just referring to a moment ago, that's an annual adjustment. It kind of goes from what was the peso at the beginning of the year to what is it going to be at the end of the year. And I think Debbie mentioned in her remarks that we haven't had this in our planning in the past. And the reason is we're not allowed to, under accounting -- GAAP accounting rules, we're not allowed to kind of forecast that. So -- but this year, we put it in the plan because we know that the Mexican peso is forecasted to move about 3.5%. And so we forecasted a change in our tax expense for that 3.5%. And so in 2016, we see a little bit of a loss there. In 2015, we actually had earnings as a result of this. We had $31 million increase at Mexico and a $20 million decrease in South America. So we had $11 million plus. So again, in 2013, 2014, it was neutral, in between 2015 and 2016, net, it's going to be kind of neutral. These things don't move the needle very much for us. They're pretty small.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's very clear, and I appreciate that. Last question for me. On the renewable segment, just -- and this is a small number, but if I look at the top line revenues, and your table left [ph] sort of year-over-year, they are down. I'm just trying to understand why. I know that there's a lot of stuff below the line, including tax and gains on asset sales and stuff like that, that tend to move the needle -- tend to move the earnings. But on the top line, I would suspect that, that number would be relatively stable. So I'm just trying to understand why it would be down year-over-year.

And so there are certain assets that we owned 100% in 2014 that are now owned 50% and then are picked up through the equity method of accounting.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: One question on LNG, and less about share contracting and maybe more about just the broader LNG markets. I mean, if you read the stuff that comes out of a lot of the economic consulting firms or other folks, they tend to talk about how the LNG market is o
componenttext: One question on LNG, and less about share contracting and maybe more about just the broader LNG markets. I mean, if you read the stuff that comes out of a lot of the economic consulting firms or other folks, they tend to talk about how the LNG market is oversupplied, and so it would -- that would imply that it would be a headwind for any new LNG development. And yet it seems, with some of the things you talk about at Cameron 4 and Port Arthur, that your views and your actions and potential growth are kind of contrary to that. Just curious if you could talk a little bit about the global LNG market, what you see for the near term and what you see for the long term.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm going to ask Octávio to answer that. But what I want to raise to you is a lot of this is about time frame and that what you read about is the current LNG market is seen as being oversupplied. What you also read about is that beginning in the 20
componenttext: Sure. I'm going to ask Octávio to answer that. But what I want to raise to you is a lot of this is about time frame and that what you read about is the current LNG market is seen as being oversupplied. What you also read about is that beginning in the 2020 period and beyond, there is a need in the marketplace for more LNG. So part of it is the timing of these things. If you are having a non-contracted project coming on today, that might be a real challenge. If you have a project coming on when there's a market need and that market need grows over time, then that's a very different market that you're going after. So Octávio, why don't you talk about the broad market and how -- and then, how we feel that our facilities are going to compete in that market.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you gave a good introduction to the time frame issue. The one thing that we need start to looking at is the current market is oversupplied, as you indicated. No discussion about that. But we also have a little problem with the current market. We hav
componenttext: Well, you gave a good introduction to the time frame issue. The one thing that we need start to looking at is the current market is oversupplied, as you indicated. No discussion about that. But we also have a little problem with the current market. We have an oversupplied market, and yet the spot cargoes are more expensive than the long-term pricing, which was agreed on in a tight market. So the market is broken in its pricing formulas, and it -- the market is adjusting to it as we speak and will adjust for the next couple of years. But our focus is not the current market. Our focus is the 2020, as Debbie indicated, where you'll see that the current oversupply will be absorbed, and then, there's a shortage. And unfortunately, or fortunately depending on your point of view, these facilities take 5, 6 years to come online once you decide to go forward. And as a result, we need to make decisions today to meet that demand. It is difficult to make. It's large capital investments when a lot of the big players are taking write-downs because of oil. That's the condition why the market is tough. Some of the buyers are confused by the oversupply. But our focus is not the current market. So globally, unless you believe we're going to switch everything from gas to coal and oil, which would increase our current footprint significantly and it seems like the winds are the other way around, if you do believe that we are going forward not only with the continuous economic growth but with a change to a lower carbon footprint, then gas is going to play a role not just in the current markets but in other markets that are yet to open. One interesting statistic I heard this week at CERAWeek was the fact that the lower demand from Korea and Japan was made up by increased demand in Middle East countries, and therefore, the demand didn't go away. And that was not there in the earlier projections. So globally, where our projects fit, we're comfortable. It is a tough market for people to make decisions when they're under significant pressure. But we think we are offering to the market the lowest-cost producing facility for 2020, and that's why the interest is there.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I remember, at one of your investor meetings, you outlined where your facilities -- I think it was your last Analyst Day, you outlined where your facilities sit on kind of a cost curve relative to other global LNG facilities. Just curious, given the f
componenttext: And I remember, at one of your investor meetings, you outlined where your facilities -- I think it was your last Analyst Day, you outlined where your facilities sit on kind of a cost curve relative to other global LNG facilities. Just curious, given the fact that Port Arthur is greenfield and Cameron was brownfield, the thing that surprised us back then, and still does a little bit now, is that they are so close to each other on that dispatch curve and compared to some of the others. How are you thinking about how the economics of Port Arthur as a greenfield would differ from some of the disclosures you've given previously on Cameron 1 through 3?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a very good question, and I'll be happy to bring up another topic that sometimes gets forgotten. In the economics of the Carmen -- pardon me, in the Cameron-based project, we included $1 billion of the cost of the existing facilities, which is esse
componenttext: That's a very good question, and I'll be happy to bring up another topic that sometimes gets forgotten. In the economics of the Carmen -- pardon me, in the Cameron-based project, we included $1 billion of the cost of the existing facilities, which is essentially replacement value. So the economics of Cameron in that chart you saw at Analyst Day, as well as all the other charts, included the value of existing facilities. And so what we're doing with Woodside and Port Arthur is looking at ways to break some of the paradigms in the industry, keep it as safe and reliable as we want it to be, as the customers expect it to be, but look at ways to reduce cost. Just like we found when we did Cameron that we had the lower cost per ton for conventional technology of liquefaction. We have an even lower price for the expansion of Cameron for Trains 4 and 5, and we expect to achieve similar results with Port Arthur. If we don't find that we can do that, then Port Arthur is not going to go away. We simply believe that the industry has to be going back to a discipline of developing the next lowest marginal cost available of supply in order to be sustainable.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: This is Ashar. Debbie, I just wanted to -- a little bit confusion, a lot of calls going on today. But if I am correct, I heard you say in your prepared remarks, and please correct me if I'm wrong, that the goal is still to meet or exceed previous expectations set. Is that correct?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure what expectations you're referring to. What we're very focused on is that the growth that we have outlined for you in our plan is long-term contracted growth are in our utilities. And that what we put in our base plan is things that we alread
componenttext: I'm not sure what expectations you're referring to. What we're very focused on is that the growth that we have outlined for you in our plan is long-term contracted growth are in our utilities. And that what we put in our base plan is things that we already have under contract and then expected utility performance. What we expect to do is, over the next 5 years, we expect to add projects to that. This last year alone, we added 325 megawatts of renewables that will come online late this year. We've added, or will be adding when the transaction closes, the PEMEX acquisition. That was not part of our base plan a year ago. So our expectations are that we're not going to sit still. We're going to continue to develop and grow our business. And that what we show you, though, in terms of our growth is when -- and when we get to our analyst conference, we'll do what we always do, which is the blue box and the green box that shows you what we have contracted and what's basically in our utilities as projects approved are in our rate case. And then, we show you what we're working on that could add to that growth over the 5-year period of time. And we'll be doing the same thing for you this year.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go to MorningStar's Mark Barnett next.
componenttext: We'll go to MorningStar's Mark Barnett next.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for all the comments on the LNG market today. I did want to ask one more question about Mexico. And I know that some of the pressure on PEMEX does create an opportunity in the -- some of the assets they might be looking to offload. But I'm wonderin
componenttext: Thanks for all the comments on the LNG market today. I did want to ask one more question about Mexico. And I know that some of the pressure on PEMEX does create an opportunity in the -- some of the assets they might be looking to offload. But I'm wondering if you see beyond maybe this current slate of projects some headwinds, just from the lower oil revenues, on -- from the Mexican government. And maybe if you could talk about how you see that balance of opportunity versus challenge.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, honestly, when you talk to our CEO in Mexico, he sees that as an opportunity. Because the whole reason for reform was to bring capital into Mexico to build the kind of infrastructure that they need for the kind of growth. And you have to real
componenttext: Yes, I mean, honestly, when you talk to our CEO in Mexico, he sees that as an opportunity. Because the whole reason for reform was to bring capital into Mexico to build the kind of infrastructure that they need for the kind of growth. And you have to realize, Mexico is going to be more competitive the lower the energy prices are in the long term for them. That has been kind of their stumbling block on being globally competitive. So to the degree that they can use other party's capital, and that would be us -- I mean, we'd like to put our capital there, and that they can build the infrastructure that reduces their energy cost, that they're moving forward on that basis. And so we think that -- I think it's a struggle for PEMEX with having been reliant on oil revenues, but it's an opportunity for us to come in and build things that wouldn't otherwise be built and that are needed as part of the long-term Mexican infrastructure. So that's kind of the way we look at it. Mark, do you want to...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I will just -- let me just add to that, too, as I think that the -- when we talk about energy reform in Mexico, I think a lot of folks are focused on the reforms at PEMEX. And they haven't seen increases in production and some of the things that they
componenttext: Yes, I will just -- let me just add to that, too, as I think that the -- when we talk about energy reform in Mexico, I think a lot of folks are focused on the reforms at PEMEX. And they haven't seen increases in production and some of the things that they expected to see from energy reform, and I think that's entirely the fault of $30 oil and very little to do with the reforms. What are coming out of the reforms is a massive amount of energy infrastructure within the company -- within the country, and that infrastructure is doing exactly what it's supposed to do. As Debbie said, it's lowering energy cost, bringing natural gas in the regions of the country that didn't have access to it before. It's making it -- it's really making a big difference in lowering electricity costs across the country. And that's working very, very well. And to the extent that low gas -- low oil prices are hindering some of the reforms at PEMEX, I think that, again, is creating a large opportunity for us, because it increases the need for PEMEX for capital, it gives opportunities for us to look at the assets that they're going to be putting up for sale. And so from our perspective, I think we think that the reforms are working very much as intended and that we will continue to benefit as being one of the best placed companies in the country to take advantage of those opportunities.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Right.

And if you have any follow-up questions, our Investor Relations team is available to answer anything that was left off from the call today. Thank you very much.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Sempra Energy First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Rick Vaccari. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Sempra Energy First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Rick Vaccari. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2016 Financial Presentation. A live webcast for this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. With me in San Diego are several members of ou
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2016 Financial Presentation. A live webcast for this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. 
With me in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Chairman and CEO; Mark Snell, President; Joe Householder, Chief Financial Officer; Martha Wyrsch, General Counsel; Trevor Mihalik, Chief Accounting Officer; Dennis Arriola, Chief Executive Officer of SoCalGas; and Jeff Martin, Chief Executive Officer of San Diegeo Gas & Electric.
Before starting, I would like to remind everyone that we will be discussing forward-looking statements on this call within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. The factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially are discussed in the company's most recent 10-K and 10-Q. It's important to note that all of the earnings per share amounts in our presentation are shown on a diluted basis and that we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the presentation slides that accompany this call and to Table A in our first quarter 2016 earnings press release for a reconciliation to GAAP measures. 
I'd also like to note that the forward-looking statements contained in this presentation speak only as of today, May 4, 2016, and the company does not assume any obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements in the future. 
With that, please turn to Slide 4, and let me hand the call over to Debbie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. On today's call, we are following a slightly different format. As you know, the final GRC decision for our California Utilities has not been issued. However, we expect to receive the proposed decision relatively soon. Because we have reached
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. On today's call, we are following a slightly different format. As you know, the final GRC decision for our California Utilities has not been issued. However, we expect to receive the proposed decision relatively soon. Because we have reached a multiparty settlement agreement, we continue to believe the most likely GRC outcome is one consistent with that settlement. We also believe we have made a strong showing to support our historical treatment of tax repair allowance benefits. Therefore, today, we are updating our 2016 adjusted EPS guidance and providing you with our long-term growth rate assuming a GRC outcome consistent with the settlement. We think the best approach is to postpone our analyst conference until we have a final GRC decision. We are tentatively looking at the month of July in New York City as a possible date for the conference. Once we receive a PD, we will confirm the date and location. 
In our other businesses, we recently announced the sale of our Southeast utilities and our interest in REX. We expect to receive about $760 million of cash proceeds to invest in projects that align better with our growth strategy. As you know, our strategy is to provide growth that is roughly twice that of the utility average but with a commensurate risk profile. I will discuss these transactions later on the call. 
Our updated 2016 adjusted guidance range is now $4.60 per share to $5 per share. This range reflects approximately $60 million of reduced earnings from REX. The sale of our Southeast utilities does not affect current or future earnings, since earnings reduced from the sale can largely be offset by lower interest cost. 
Looking forward, we are well positioned for strong growth over the next 5 years. We expect our base plan to provide earnings in 2020 at $7.20 per share to $7.80 per share. The resulting adjusted compound annual growth rate for 2016 to 2020 is about 12%. 
Prior to the sale of REX, the comparable growth rate would have been about 11%. 
Joe will address the growth rate further in his remarks, but I want to emphasize that we expect to have significant credit capacity in the latter years of our plan, which will provide us with flexibility and capital allocation. We will discuss our plan assumptions, business unit projections and growth strategy in more depth once we reschedule the analyst conference. 
Turning to our financial results. We reported first quarter adjusted earnings of $370 million. As a reminder, until we receive a final GRC, we are recording revenues based upon 2015 authorized amounts. Once we receive a final decision, we will record the impact of the 2016 authorized margins back to January 1. 
If the GRC have been finalized by January and was consistent with the settlement agreements, utility first quarter earnings would have been in line with last year, despite the fact that approximately $60 million of annual tax repair benefits will now flow to customers under the new GRC. 
Now please turn to Slide 5. There are several updates related to Aliso Canyon. First, SoCalGas is cooperating with the other and the CPUC on the root cause investigation through their contractor Blade Energy Partners. We expect the investigation to take about 6 to 9 months with the results being issued by the agents late this year or early next year. Second, we are working to get the field back in service for injection. Consistent with [indiscernible] proposed safety review, we have implemented a plan to prioritize and test wells with the goal to have the facility in service by the end of this summer. Third, we are working with state and local agencies to address electric reliability concerns. Aliso Canyon currently has about 15 Bcf of gas available for withdrawal. When deciding how best to use that gas, reliability for both the summer and winter seasons must be considered. Fourth, we are completing our estimate of the total amount of gas lost from the leak and formulating a plan to mitigate that amount. Fifth, the temporary relocation program has been extended to allow the county to complete in-home testing, which results expected this month. SoCalGas and public agencies have conducted numerous tests of outdoor air quality. Results continue to confirm that air quality in Quarter Ranch is at normal levels. Finally, we are addressing the litigation that has been filed related to the leak. 
With regards to cost, we have incurred additional amounts, primarily from continuation of the temporary relocation program as ordered by the court. The court has scheduled a follow appearing on June 7. Based on an expectation that the relocation program continues through June 7, we estimate the cost for amounts paid and forecast to be paid at approximately $665 million. We have recorded an insurance receivable of $660 million. Our cost estimate does not include certain potential items as described on the slide. Please refer to our 2015 10-K and first quarter 2016 10-Q for more detail on cost and our insurance. 
Now let's turn to Slide 6 for an update on our other businesses. Since our current assets to determine whether they fit with our long-term contracted infrastructure model and whether they integrate with other assets to offer strong long-term growth prospects. We identified 3 assets that are no longer a strategic fit for us: REX, our Southeast utilities and the TDM power plant in Mexico. For the first 2, we have announced sales agreement; and for TDM, we are conducting a sales process. 
For REX, we expect the sale of our equity interest to close in the second quarter and to provide $440 million in proceeds. The sale also allows us to forego expected future contributions for capital investment and debt repayments. We believe our capital can be better utilized to further enhance our strong growth outlook. As a result of the sale, we forecast the reduction for partial year 2016 earnings of approximately $60 million, which is included in our adjusted EPS range of $4.60 per share to $5 per share. It is important to note that had we held our interest in REX, we expected 2020 earnings to be immaterial and dilute our growth, largely due to loss of earnings from west to east contracts that expire in 2019. In addition, we plan to permanently release uncontracted capacity held by Sempra. The negative earnings impacted this capacity release is projected to be between $100 million and $120 million, and will be recorded in the second quarter. This amount reflects the acceleration estimated losses that would have otherwise been realized over the remaining contract term. It is excluded from our 2016 adjusted earnings guidance. 
Moving to our Southeast utilities. We finalized the sales agreement last week and expect to receive $323 million in cash proceeds with the buyer to assume $67 million of debt. We did not see significant additional growth potential in our Southeast utility footprint, and the earnings impact is projected to be offset with reduced interest cost. Similar to REX, we expect to use the proceeds to invest in projects with strong growth prospects. 
Finally, TDM is the third asset that no longer fits with our long-term contracted infrastructure strategy. It is currently held for sale, and we are in the midst of a sales process. 
Now pleased to turn to Slide 7. IEnova is building its position as the largest private energy company in Mexico to identify and originate new investment opportunities. IEnova is working on multiple development initiatives, including M&A, asset optimization, strategic partnerships with established companies and new companies seeking to enter the Mexican market, and emerging the opportunities in clean energy, storage and liquids infrastructure. One example of asset optimization is the building laterals of our gas pipeline network to interconnect with end users. Just this week, CFE awarded IEnova a contracted build to small lateral that connects our Sonora pipeline to a combined cycle power plant. In addition to project opportunities identified by IEnova, the CFE bidding process for natural gas pipelines continues. We are currently evaluating 2 tenders with likely bid dates during the second quarter. In generation, we expect to see the second round of renewable energy auctions in August. And in Electric Transmission, we expect to see the first 2 bids under new rules on energy reform in 2016 and 2017. Each Electric Transmission project represents an estimated $1.2 billion of investments. 
With that, please turn to Slide 8, and I'll turn the call over to Joe. Joe?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Turning to our long-term financial projections, we expect that our base plan can provide 2020 earnings of $7.20 per share to $7.80 per share. The resulting adjusted earnings cater from 2016 to 2020 is about 12%. Some of our key plan assump
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. Turning to our long-term financial projections, we expect that our base plan can provide 2020 earnings of $7.20 per share to $7.80 per share. The resulting adjusted earnings cater from 2016 to 2020 is about 12%. Some of our key plan assumptions include an $18.5 billion capital program, including joint venture CapEx for Cameron Trains 1 to 3; full year earnings of $300 million to $350 million from Cameron Trains 1 to 3 in both 2019 and 2020; a GRC outcome in line with our proposed settlement agreement; and tax repair allowance benefits prior to 2016 being retained by shareholders; and an optional $2 billion share repurchase. Under our base plan, annual adjusted EBITDA is expected to increase by $1.7 billion over the planned period, raising our FFO to debt to roughly 22%. Including our targeted annual increase in the dividend of 8% to 9%, we project excess credit capacity in the later years of our plan to be between $2 billion and $4 billion. Leaving excess capacity on our balance sheet would not maximize shareholder value. We have used a conservative assumption of an optional $2 billion share repurchase, split between 2019 and 2020. While we do include this assumption, it is our intention to allocate capital toward high-value development projects. 
I will discuss all of our base plan assumptions and provide business unit guidance at our analyst conference. I want to remind you today that our plan is not aspirational in nature. It is anchored on expected utility performance and projects that are already contracted and operating or under construction. This approach gives us high visibility and conviction in our growth rate. 
On a final note, before turning to the quarterly results, I want to address the long-term earnings impact from the REX capacity release that Debbie discussed earlier. In the base plan we presented last year, we had only assumed about $5 million to $10 million of annual losses associated with this capacity for 2016 and 2017 because we have not factored in the financial distress that several counterparties have recently experienced. We have no capacity obligations in 2020. By permanently releasing the capacity now, our new 5-year plan does not have to reflect any future losses from this capacity nor any negative impact from the recently announced counterparty bankruptcies beyond the loss we expect to record in the second quarter. 
Now please turn to Slide 9. This morning, we reported first quarter earnings of $319 million. On an adjusted basis, we reported first quarter earnings of $370 million or $1.47 per share. Adjusted earnings this quarter exclude the $27 million after-tax loss on the pending sale of our equity interest in REX and $24 million of deferred Mexican income tax expense as a result of holding the TDM power plant for sale. In addition, just as a reminder, in 2016, we are now including LNG development expenses in our reported adjusted earnings and adjusted earnings guidance. Whereas in 2015, these were excluded. There are several factors affecting the first quarter results that are either timing items or items expected to reverse in later quarters. 
Please turn to Slide 10 and I will discuss the key factors impacting our quarterly earnings. Quarter-over-quarter, adjusted earnings were impacted by the following items: At our California Utilities, we had $17 million of lower earnings, mostly due to higher operating cost from higher depreciation and litigation, with no increase in authorized margin due to the delay in our GRC. As Debbie noted, until we receive a final decision, we are recording revenues based on amounts authorized for 2015. Once we receive the final decision, we will record the cumulative impact of 2016 authorized revenues back to January 1. Including this retroactive benefit, we expect the utilities' quarterly earnings would be roughly in line with last year, which is important given the fact that approximately $60 million of annual tax repair benefits will now flow to customers under the new GRC. 
Moving to the parent category, we recorded $10 million of higher losses due to $7 million of lower repatriation tax expense that was more than offset by $10 million of higher net interest expense combined with the $5 million income tax benefit that was recorded in the first quarter of 2015. At U.S. Gas & Power, we had $9 million of lower earnings due primarily to the impact of natural gas price movements on inventories that we sold forward. We expect this $9 million lost to reverse by year-end. At Sempra International, we had $8 million of lower earnings from foreign currency effects. This was due to a $4 million negative impact from South America and a $4 million higher positive impact in Mexico in Q1 2015. At SoCalGas, our Q1 '15 results included an $8 million GCIM award. No GCIM award is recorded in Q1 2016 as this award was received in the fourth quarter of last year. 
Now let's conclude on Slide 11. In summary, we have updated our 2016 adjusted earnings guidance to $4.60 per share to $5 per share to reflect the REX sale. The annualized impact of the REX sale will also reduce earnings by approximately $70 million per year for the next few years. Our adjusted guidance is defined in further detail in the appendix. 
In terms of our financial results. While our first quarter earnings were impacted by the delay in our GRC, we will record the retroactive authorized margin back to January 1 once the final decision is received. 
Finally, assuming the GRC outcome is consistent with the settlement agreement, we project the base plan adjusted earnings CAGR of about 12% from 2016 to 2020. 
With that, we will conclude our prepared comments and stop to take any questions you may have.

componenttext: So first quick question to get out of the way, what's the implied growth rate year-over-year in 2019 to 2020? You talked about share repurchases in the beginning, I just wanted to settle that.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've disclosed now is the growth rate through 2020, and we're not going to give any adjusted earnings guidance for 2019. We always give you that that fifth year and our 5-year plan. But I think you can kind of infer from what we've given you b
componenttext: Well, what we've disclosed now is the growth rate through 2020, and we're not going to give any adjusted earnings guidance for 2019. We always give you that that fifth year and our 5-year plan. But I think you can kind of infer from what we've given you before and kind of the range of growth over that period of time. What I will say is, as you know, in our business that some of our growth tends to be lumpy, and it's because we have a large projects coming onto service. And in 2019 will be the first full year of Cameron Trains 1 through 3 going into service. Those trains remain on schedule to be completed throughout 2018, as we've told you before. So 2019 you'll see that come into 2019. And so 2019 will be lumpy, in comparison to 2018. And 2018 will be lumpy when compared to 2017 as the trains kind of service.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Julian, this is Joe. I'll just add on to that, exactly what Debbie said, but remember, the way we build our base plan, it will have utility growth ongoing from attrition and utility growth in South America, but there are no new projects that we have outli
componenttext: Julian, this is Joe. I'll just add on to that, exactly what Debbie said, but remember, the way we build our base plan, it will have utility growth ongoing from attrition and utility growth in South America, but there are no new projects that we have outlined that would come on service in '19 and '20. So the growth rate that you would see there, you would predict to see there, won't be what we expect to have, because we expect to have new projects, but we're talking about 4, 5 years from now.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with that technicality out of the way, thinking holistically, what is the next focus, at least, of the company when it comes to that cap allocation. I appreciate you delineating the share repurchases as a placeholder, you're selling down some of the g
componenttext: And with that technicality out of the way, thinking holistically, what is the next focus, at least, of the company when it comes to that cap allocation. I appreciate you delineating the share repurchases as a placeholder, you're selling down some of the gas assets deeming the noncore. Where is the company going, if you can kind of at least describe your preliminary thinking? I know it's a bit of an Analyst Day kind of question, but just thought I'd get it out there, especially in light of what should be near-term cash proceeds from the asset sales you articulated already?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me talk to you about some of the things that we're looking at and obviously, there's a lot of M&A activity right now in the space, there's a lot opportunities, but we have a lot of organic growth as well, so let me talk about some of those thing
componenttext: Well, let me talk to you about some of the things that we're looking at and obviously, there's a lot of M&A activity right now in the space, there's a lot opportunities, but we have a lot of organic growth as well, so let me talk about some of those things. First of all, we are still looking at the train 4 being developed, and so that we would anticipate having agreements in place by the end of the year, based upon conversations we've been having with the parties now, and that is not the call up our growth plan. The numbers we gave you for 2020 has nothing for any additional LNG beyond Trains 1 through 3. So we're still focused on that. We think it's a good growth opportunity for us. And then what we also think is the integrated assets, when you have such a huge demand for gas, the opportunity to develop high points to serve the loads is a really good opportunity for REX. So we continue to look at putting capital into those areas. I would also say that as you look at the opening of the energy markets in Mexico, they're at their infancy right now. They've only done sort of the gas infrastructure. We have Electric Transmission, we have pipeline for liquids, have a pipeline -- terminals to liquid, we have a lot of more energy infrastructure to come out for opportunities in Mexico. And we think we just have wonderful foundation of assets there that allows us some opportunities. And then I would say, our renewable business, we don't talk a lot about our renewables business. But we have a growing robust successful renewable business that we continue to have new projects that we find that we have the ability to expand some of our existing projects. What I would say is that we have a strategy that really focused on growing more than twice the rate or twice the rate of typical utility, but with a similar risk profile. So when we start looking at the assets, we look at, or the long-term contracted? Can they have low volatility because we know you all value low volatility with growth, and can they support our growing dividends, and can they give us the strength of the balance sheet that we're seeing over the 5 years of the plan. And so projects that kind of a pick that criteria, we're open to let things. We constantly look on the M&A, and we see some assets that may be on the market that might be of interest to us. So our strategy hasn’t changed, and we just thought that the capital that we have in some of these things was kind of trapped and was not really integrated with anything else we had, and was not going to provide the kind of growth that other investments might.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on Mexico first. The 3 pipeline bids, which I know that got disqualified from. Could you explain the reasoning behind that? And if there's any way to reverse result or appeal it and how that may affect that bidding going forward for
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on Mexico first. The 3 pipeline bids, which I know that got disqualified from. Could you explain the reasoning behind that? And if there's any way to reverse result or appeal it and how that may affect that bidding going forward for you guys?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'm going to have Mark address of that because I think it's important to note that it was and kind of -- it didn't happen with us being disqualified one bid after the other. Unfortunately, we have to submit all bids kind of at the same time, and we
componenttext: Sure, I'm going to have Mark address of that because I think it's important to note that it was and kind of -- it didn't happen with us being disqualified one bid after the other. Unfortunately, we have to submit all bids kind of at the same time, and we didn't find out about being disqualified for the first one until the other 2 had already been submitted. But Mark, could you talk a bit about really going forward, and how we're dealing with.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, sure. I mean, on those particular bids, what the methodology that we used was to adjust our tariff  to CFE by additional capacity that we anticipated to sell to other customers down the road. But without specifying exactly where of a pipeline we wo
componenttext: Right, sure. I mean, on those particular bids, what the methodology that we used was to adjust our tariff  to CFE by additional capacity that we anticipated to sell to other customers down the road. But without specifying exactly where of a pipeline we would do that, and that's basis of which they would disqualify us. And as Debbie said, we submitted 3 bids at once, used that same methodology, we're disqualified. We don't agree with it, and we challenged it. But I think we've adjusted our bidding procedure going forward. And we -- frankly, it's kind of behind us now, and we're looking at the other bids, and we have adjusted how we're doing it, and we would expect to be quite competitive in the future. So it's not something -- it was unfortunate and just the way those bids came together. But it's behind us now, and we're moving on. So I will say that I think -- talking about Mexico, in particular, we're still in a very, very good competitive position there. And I'm really pleased with the growth that we've had. It's unfortunate you don't see it quite in the financials, but our EBITDA, it was up 19% from $93 million last year to $110 million, if you include our ownership in the JV, our proportionate share of the EBITDA. And it gets mass a little bit in the GAAP reporting and because of FX. Last quarter, in 2015, in the first quarter, we had a 3% inflation with the strengthening of the peso, which actually reduced our tax expense. And in '16, it was pretty much flat, and so we didn't get that same benefit. So that kind of masked the underlying growth. But we have very strong growth there, and are in a very good competitive position in Mexico.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And Debbie, you mentioned a lot of opportunity to Mexico, beyond just the CFE pipeline. Could you maybe comment on your near term, what may be the best opportunities that we should be looking at?
componenttext: Got it. And Debbie, you mentioned a lot of opportunity to Mexico, beyond just the CFE pipeline. Could you maybe comment on your near term, what may be the best opportunities that we should be looking at?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll talk about some. And I think one that we have before us that we expect to close during the third quarter is the PEMEX acquisition of the JV assess that we currently hold jointly with PEMEX, and we're still moving forward on that. But as you pro
componenttext: Sure, I'll talk about some. And I think one that we have before us that we expect to close during the third quarter is the PEMEX acquisition of the JV assess that we currently hold jointly with PEMEX, and we're still moving forward on that. But as you probably read, PEMEX is looking at other potential asset sales, and they have a number of assets that we would be interested in, that will give us some opportunities. We're also looking at some of the other energy assets that are in Mexico now, some of which are in operations, some of which are in the development stage, that we could potentially acquire, and we have some that we're looking at there. And then just in terms of the broader markets opening, you have the bids coming out that are about $1.2 billion a piece for Electric Transmission that we're seeing. We have renewables being bid, and several billions worth of potential there. And then for us, since we kind of own and operate pipeline, there's a lot of liquid pipeline assets in Mexico. They're currently held by PEMEX now or needs for new liquids pipeline that deal with their opening of the oil market. And so we think that, that's a great the area for us as well to have similar type of long-term contract and infrastructure in liquids.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And my last question, with you guys divesting REX, there's no real domestic midstream presence. Are you looking to grow that through acquisition organically? Or is that something that's not necessarily important as long as you have contracted grow
componenttext: Got it. And my last question, with you guys divesting REX, there's no real domestic midstream presence. Are you looking to grow that through acquisition organically? Or is that something that's not necessarily important as long as you have contracted growth in other areas?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we've looked at is a strategy to grow that, but more on an integrated basis with our other assets. And when you have a huge load, like building an LNG facility, that gives you the opportunity to build pipelines and storage to serve that load, th
componenttext: Yes, what we've looked at is a strategy to grow that, but more on an integrated basis with our other assets. And when you have a huge load, like building an LNG facility, that gives you the opportunity to build pipelines and storage to serve that load, that integrate with others. And then to expand those in a way that you can pick up additional customers, whether they're like generations facilities or manufacturing facilities, and really have a full pipeline. So what we tend to look at is where we have a load and where the ones that has that cloud, whether it's a utility or say a contract with PEMEX, or let's say, a contract for LNG export that we like to have access that integrate with that load. So that would be priority for looking at access as to how they could be more integrated with our business. I mean REX is fine, but it doesn't integrate with anything we had. We don’t have a 25% interest in, we did not control that. It has contracts expiring, it just really didn't fit our model. And I don't want to that to tell you what all that we're reluctant to get into other midstream assets. We are very interested in getting into those types of assets. But they need to provide us more growth. And when we look at REX, we just did not see the profile as providing the kind of growth. But there's are some interesting asset that we're starting to look at now that maybe come on market that we are already in existence. And then there's some that we foresee the need to develop that we think will be very interesting as well.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Gregory Gordon with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll go next to Gregory Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to be clear on if I were trying to replicate your business plans in your financial model that we take the balance sheet capacity you have, and we just assume that you buy the shares back at some higher stock price as we compound out 4 years
componenttext: So I just want to be clear on if I were trying to replicate your business plans in your financial model that we take the balance sheet capacity you have, and we just assume that you buy the shares back at some higher stock price as we compound out 4 years of growth. Because -- and that will be a pretty low implied return on equity on that capital, relative to what you would consider a competitive hurdle rate for an actual infrastructure project. Is that a fair articulation of the math?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg. I think you figured that out actually quite well. One of the things we've struggled with is that when we do our base plan, the only things we put in our base plan are things we already have contracted and our expected utility earnings. And most
componenttext: Yes, Greg. I think you figured that out actually quite well. One of the things we've struggled with is that when we do our base plan, the only things we put in our base plan are things we already have contracted and our expected utility earnings. And most others, when they build those plants, they put aspirational projects in, we don't do that. So then when we looked at this and we saw with all the other projects we have in our contract and what that will deal and looking at the cash flow as we have coming from the projects that are in service at the time and what was our FFO to debt, we just said, "There's no way we will sit with that FFO to debt on our balance sheet at that time." So what's of the most conservative assumption we could put in and decided that to do a stock buyback with the most conservative way to handle it. So I'm going to turn it over to Joe to talk a bit more about how you might think about that in your question.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Greg, I want to emphasize the 2 key factors that you mentioned. The element of the base plan that is built on the strength of our regulated utilities and there already contracted infrastructure business that contributes to the strong balan
componenttext: Thanks, Debbie. Greg, I want to emphasize the 2 key factors that you mentioned. The element of the base plan that is built on the strength of our regulated utilities and there already contracted infrastructure business that contributes to the strong balance sheet and the cash flow. So we did, kind of what you said, we looked forward, we had a pickup price, we estimated the price base on a reasonable utility multiple out, several years out and used that as a way to develop the optional share buyback. And I think that our goal is really to develop infrastructure and beat that. So the earnings from those projects will replace this, and that's the goal that we expect to achieve.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: I would assume once we get to Analyst Day that you would give us sort of the similar framework of this is what we have sort of in the list of things that are moving ahead, and then the checklist of aspirational items that we can hold you either achieving or not achieving as you move through time, much like you did last year.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, we'll do the blue box, which is the base plan, and the green box, which is the aspirational items. And the key thing is that some of those aspirational items will replace the stock buybacks obviously. But to the extent that we can do more of t
componenttext: Absolutely, we'll do the blue box, which is the base plan, and the green box, which is the aspirational items. And the key thing is that some of those aspirational items will replace the stock buybacks obviously. But to the extent that we can do more of those projects, they would also be additive to the stock buyback. And so we'll go through all of that with you at the analyst meeting as we usually do.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

Has it been mostly the extension by the judges of the location program or have there been other items that have been significant?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes, let me -- I'm going to refer this to Dennis so he can kind of walk you through some of that and what's happening relative to the relocation. But the majority of these costs are associated with the relocation. The vast majority I think is about 70% of the cost are relocation. So Dennis, do want to kind of walking through that a bit?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. You're right, if the back when we reported in the 10-K the cost of about $332 million. Since that time, we have had the relocation program extended at least a couple of times by the courts. So if you look at the change of about $330 million, the maj
componenttext: Sure. You're right, if the back when we reported in the 10-K the cost of about $332 million. Since that time, we have had the relocation program extended at least a couple of times by the courts. So if you look at the change of about $330 million, the majority of that has been relocation, 70%. Then you basically have 2 other buckets. About 15% of the overall total relates to the work of stopping the leak, building the relief wells, the root cause investigation that's underway and everything. And then you get the buckets of the other cost related to legal and other out of about that. So those are the 3 main: 70% relo, or 15% for the stopping the leak and the investigation, and then the other 15% related to legal expense and other costs.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: On the TDM asset sale, I suppose that with the sales sort of announced, does that mean it was difficult to sort of get a long-term contract on that plant for sales in New Mexico? Is that sort of the genesis behind why this asset is being sold? I thought that this was far underneath that bucket of assets that could be under long-term contract, but maybe that was a possibility.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to have Mark talk about that, but it have been sold under the U.S. previously. And then we were working on the possibility of trying to sell it into the Mexican markets. But as we look at the asset and the difficulty in that, we decided tha
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to have Mark talk about that, but it have been sold under the U.S. previously. And then we were working on the possibility of trying to sell it into the Mexican markets. But as we look at the asset and the difficulty in that, we decided that it was not likely to be not long-term contracted in the near term. Mark, you want to...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's right. The plant right now is configured only for sale into the U.S. We've looked at, and we have a plan to connect it into the grid in Mexico. It could be that in the not-too-distant future, that there could be a long-term contract opportu
componenttext: I think that's right. The plant right now is configured only for sale into the U.S. We've looked at, and we have a plan to connect it into the grid in Mexico. It could be that in the not-too-distant future, that there could be a long-term contract opportunity with the CFE. They did -- the CFE just did sponsor and build a new plant very close to our LNG facility in [indiscernible] in Sonata, and so it's going to delay for some years the need for additional capacity in that region. And also to just wit h those kinds of plans, fossil fuel fired plants in Mexico, the contracting periods are not as long as they once were. And so we started to see that this asset is not likely to meet our kind of long-term contracted objectives. And therefore, we thought that we ought to put it out in the market and see if we -- and move to sell it. All that said, I think we have certainly a reserve price in our heads, and if we don't get it, then we'll rethink, but I think we're in very good -- we're looking at kind of moving forward on it.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. In the event is going back Aliso, I just wanted to understand. You're saying that if I went sort of any major sight on final report in the agencies until late '16 or '17, are there going to be sort of any additional findings that come ou
componenttext: That makes sense. In the event is going back Aliso, I just wanted to understand. You're saying that if I went sort of any major sight on final report in the agencies until late '16 or '17, are there going to be sort of any additional findings that come out through the regulatory process over the next few months?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well,  I would say, there were some additional findings from DOGGR that indicated that SoCalGas was in full compliance with all the rules that were in place at that time. And DOGGR came out with those findings early on from the preliminary review. But rig
componenttext: Well,  I would say, there were some additional findings from DOGGR that indicated that SoCalGas was in full compliance with all the rules that were in place at that time. And DOGGR came out with those findings early on from the preliminary review. But right now, the work delayed is doing on-site in conjunction with the CPUC, I don't think we're going to get any preliminary information. What they'll do is they're gathering the data and then they'll write a report, and likely to report will be out at the end of this year or early next year. Dennis, do you want to add to that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing that I'd add to that, Debbie, there's a lot of work going on, not just under cost investigation with DOGGR, the CPUC and Blade, but work to get Aliso back up and running. And I can tell you right now that it's really clear that the regulato
componenttext: The only thing that I'd add to that, Debbie, there's a lot of work going on, not just under cost investigation with DOGGR, the CPUC and Blade, but work to get Aliso back up and running. And I can tell you right now that it's really clear that the regulators and policymakers truly understand the importance of Aliso Canyon and gas storage to both gas and electric reliabilities. So the tone is basically, let's make it's safe, but let's it get back up and running as quickly as we can. And so far, we've got -- of the 114 wells at Aliso, about 100 of them have completed the Phase 1 inspections, and we're transitioning those now to Phase 2, so that our target right now if I goes to have the field ready for full operation, obviously, subject to DOGGR operation, but the late summer, probably late August, so a lot of work going on there.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then the storage field that would not be able to go back to operation until this report comes out, or could you put it back into service before that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Today, we've got about 15 billion cubic feet of gas. So if needed, we can withdraw. We're just not allowed to inject until the field has been confirmed ready by DOGGR. As I said, our current target right now is to have wells ready for reinjection by late summer.

componenttext: And that's separate from the root cause analysis. So those things -- they aren't linked. The root cause is going down one workstream, and then there's a separate workstream to get the field back up and running.

componenttext: Okay, makes sense. And then just on REX. I just want to make sure I understand the sort of what you have additionally have in guidance in the past. So I guess did you always have sort of the legacy sort of REX interest that you have going to 0 earnings in 2020? Just trying to make sure I understood it correctly.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: You understood it correctly. We basically had -- it was de minimus in 2020 because we have looked at the contracts all expiring in 2019, and then there was debt refinancing that needed to be done, and so we looked at the economics of that. And so when we'
componenttext: You understood it correctly. We basically had -- it was de minimus in 2020 because we have looked at the contracts all expiring in 2019, and then there was debt refinancing that needed to be done, and so we looked at the economics of that. And so when we're putting our plans together, we were not expecting REX to continue at the kind of run rate that -- we told you, it was $60 million for the 10 months we have this year. We were not expecting it to continue at that kind of run rate after those contracts expired in 2019.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
