componenttext: Yes, I'll let Joe in.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think, Julien, nothing in particular. We're building out about $1 billion of renewables this year, and money is fungible. We're looking at all kinds of opportunities. Mark's groups are looking at lot of opportunities. So I can't name one thing becau
componenttext: No. I think, Julien, nothing in particular. We're building out about $1 billion of renewables this year, and money is fungible. We're looking at all kinds of opportunities. Mark's groups are looking at lot of opportunities. So I can't name one thing because there's a whole bunch of things on the plate.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Neel Mitra with Tudor, Pickering.
componenttext: We'll go next to Neel Mitra with Tudor, Pickering.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on Mexico first. The 3 pipeline bids, which I know you got disqualified from. Could you explain the reasoning behind that? And if there's any way to reverse the result or appeal it? And how that may affect the bidding going forward
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on Mexico first. The 3 pipeline bids, which I know you got disqualified from. Could you explain the reasoning behind that? And if there's any way to reverse the result or appeal it? And how that may affect the bidding going forward for you guys?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm going to have Mark address that because I think it's important to note that it wasn't kind of -- it didn't happen with us being disqualified, one bid after the other. Unfortunately, we had to submit all bids kind of at the same time, and we didn
componenttext: Sure. I'm going to have Mark address that because I think it's important to note that it wasn't kind of -- it didn't happen with us being disqualified, one bid after the other. Unfortunately, we had to submit all bids kind of at the same time, and we didn't find out about being disqualified for the first one until the other 2 had already been submitted. But Mark, would you talk a little bit about how that happened? We're really going forward on how we're dealing with it.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, sure. I mean, on those particular bids, what the methodology that we used was to adjust our tariff to CFE by additional capacity that we anticipated to sell to other customers down the road. And -- but without specifying exactly where on the pipeli
componenttext: Right, sure. I mean, on those particular bids, what the methodology that we used was to adjust our tariff to CFE by additional capacity that we anticipated to sell to other customers down the road. And -- but without specifying exactly where on the pipeline we would do that, and that's basis of which they would -- disqualified us. And as Debbie said, we submitted 3 bids at once, used that same methodology where we're disqualified. We don't agree with it, and we've challenged it. But I think we've adjusted our bidding procedure going forward. And we -- frankly, it's kind of behind us now. And we're looking at the other bids, and we have adjusted how we're doing it. We would expect to be quite competitive in the future. So it's not something -- it was unfortunate in just the way those bids came together. But it's behind us now, and we're moving on. But I will say that I think -- talking about Mexico, in particular, it's -- we're still in a very, very good competitive position there. And I'm really pleased with the growth that we've had. It's unfortunate that you don't see it quite in the financials. But our EBITDA there was up 19% from $93 million last year to $110 million, if you include our ownership in the JV -- I mean, our proportionate share of their EBITDA. And it gets masked a little bit in the GAAP reporting and because of FX. Last quarter, in 2015, in the first quarter, we had a 3% inflation with -- or strengthening of the peso, which actually reduced our tax expense. And in '16, it was pretty much flat, and so we didn't get that same benefit. So that kind of masked the underlying growth. But we had very strong growth there, and are in a very good and competitive position in Mexico.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And Debbie, you mentioned a lot of opportunities in Mexico, beyond just the CFE pipelines. Could you maybe comment on, near term, what the -- maybe the best opportunities are that we should be looking at?
componenttext: Got it. And Debbie, you mentioned a lot of opportunities in Mexico, beyond just the CFE pipelines. Could you maybe comment on, near term, what the -- maybe the best opportunities are that we should be looking at?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll talk about some. And I think one that we have before us that we expect to close during the third quarter is the PEMEX acquisition of the JV assets that we currently hold jointly with PEMEX, and we're still moving forward on that. But as you pro
componenttext: Sure, I'll talk about some. And I think one that we have before us that we expect to close during the third quarter is the PEMEX acquisition of the JV assets that we currently hold jointly with PEMEX, and we're still moving forward on that. But as you probably read, now PEMEX is looking at other potential asset sales, and they have a number of assets that we would be interested in that would give us some opportunities. We're also looking at some of the other energy assets that are in Mexico now, some of which are in operations, some of which are in the development stage, that we could potentially acquire. And we have some that we're looking at there. And then just in terms of the broader markets opening, you have the bids coming out that are about $1.2 billion a piece for Electric Transmission that we're seeing. We have renewables being bid, and several billions worth of potential there. And then for us, since we kind of own and operate pipelines, there's a lot of liquid pipeline assets in Mexico. They're currently held by PEMEX now or needs for new liquids pipeline that deal with their opening of the oil markets. And so we think that, that's a great the area for us as well to have similar type of long-term contract and infrastructure in liquids.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And my last question, with you guys divesting REX, there's no real domestic midstream presence. Are you looking to grow that through acquisition or organically? Or is that something that's not necessarily important as long as you have contracted g
componenttext: Got it. And my last question, with you guys divesting REX, there's no real domestic midstream presence. Are you looking to grow that through acquisition or organically? Or is that something that's not necessarily important as long as you have contracted growth in other areas?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we've looked at is a strategy to grow that, but more on an integrated basis with our other assets. And that -- when you have a huge load, like building an LNG facility, that gives you the opportunity to build pipelines and storage to serve that
componenttext: Yes, what we've looked at is a strategy to grow that, but more on an integrated basis with our other assets. And that -- when you have a huge load, like building an LNG facility, that gives you the opportunity to build pipelines and storage to serve that load, that integrate with others. And then to expand those in a way that you can pick up additional customers, whether they're electric generation facilities or manufacturing facilities, and really have a full pipeline. So what we tend to look at is where we have a load and where the ones that has that load, whether it's a utility or it's a contract with PEMEX or it's a contract for LNG export, that we like to have assets that integrate with that load. And so that would be kind of our priority for looking at access, it's to how they could be more integrated with our business. I mean REX is fine. But it doesn't integrate with anything we had. We only had the 25% interest in it. We didn't control it. It had contracts expiring. It just really didn't fit our model. And I don't want that to tell you at all that we're reluctant to get into other midstream assets. We are very interested in getting into those types of assets. But they need to provide us more growth. And when we look at REX, we just did not see the profile as providing the kind of growth. But there's some interesting assets that we're starting to look at now, that maybe come on market that we -- are already in existence. And then there's some that we foresee the need to develop that we think would be very interesting as well.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Gregory Gordon with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Gregory Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to be clear on if -- I were trying to replicate your business plan with my own financial model, that we take the balance sheet capacity you have and we just assume that you buy the shares back at some higher stock price as we've compound ab
componenttext: So I just want to be clear on if -- I were trying to replicate your business plan with my own financial model, that we take the balance sheet capacity you have and we just assume that you buy the shares back at some higher stock price as we've compound about 4 years of growth. Because -- and that would be a pretty low implied return on equity on that capital, relative to what you would consider a competitive hurdle rate for an actual infrastructure project. Is that -- would that -- is that a fair articulation of the math?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg. I think you figured that out actually quite well. Well, one of the things we've struggled with is that when we do our base plan, the only things we put in our base plan are things we already have contracted and our expected utility earnings. An
componenttext: Yes, Greg. I think you figured that out actually quite well. Well, one of the things we've struggled with is that when we do our base plan, the only things we put in our base plan are things we already have contracted and our expected utility earnings. And that most others, when they build those plants, they put aspirational projects in. We don't do that. So then when we looked at this and we thought with all the projects we have under contract and what that would yield, and then looking at the cash flows we have coming from the projects that are in service at the time and what that did to our FFO to debt, we just said there's no way we would sit with that FFO to debt on our balance sheet at that time. So what's of the most conservative assumption we could put in and decided that to do a stock buyback were the most conservative way to handle it. So I'm going to turn it to Joe to talk a bit more about how you might think about that in your question.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Yes, Greg, I want to emphasize the 2 key factors that she mentioned. That are the element of the base plan that's built on the strength of our regulated utilities and the already contracted infrastructure business that contributes to the s
componenttext: Thanks, Debbie. Yes, Greg, I want to emphasize the 2 key factors that she mentioned. That are the element of the base plan that's built on the strength of our regulated utilities and the already contracted infrastructure business that contributes to the strong balance sheet and the cash flow. So we did kind of what you said. We looked forward. We had to pick a price. We estimated a price base on a reasonable utility multiple out -- several years out and used that as a way to develop the optional share buyback. And I think that our goal is really to develop infrastructure and beat that. And so the earnings from those projects will replace this, and that's the goal that we expect to achieve.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I would assume, once we get to Analyst Day that you would give us the -- sort of the -- a similar framework of this is what we have sort of in the list of things that are moving ahead. And then the checklist of aspirational items that we can ho
componenttext: Great. And I would assume, once we get to Analyst Day that you would give us the -- sort of the -- a similar framework of this is what we have sort of in the list of things that are moving ahead. And then the checklist of aspirational items that we can hold you either achieving or not achieving as you move through time, much like you did last year.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We'll do the blue box, which is the base plan, and the green box, which is the aspirational items. And -- I mean, the key thing is that some of those aspirational items will replace the stock buybacks, obviously. But to the extent that we can
componenttext: Absolutely. We'll do the blue box, which is the base plan, and the green box, which is the aspirational items. And -- I mean, the key thing is that some of those aspirational items will replace the stock buybacks, obviously. But to the extent that we can do more of those projects, they would also be additive to the stock buyback. And so we'll go through all of that with you at the Analyst Meeting, as we usually do.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Switching to Aliso Canyon. The costs, obviously, are up pretty significantly since the 10-K disclosure of around $330 million, if my memory serves me correctly. Can you give us what the incremental cost have been in basic buckets? Has it been mostl
componenttext: Great. Switching to Aliso Canyon. The costs, obviously, are up pretty significantly since the 10-K disclosure of around $330 million, if my memory serves me correctly. Can you give us what the incremental cost have been in basic buckets? Has it been mostly the extension by the judges of the location program? Or has it been other items that have also been significant?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me -- I'm going to refer this to Dennis so he can kind of walk you some of that and what's happening relative to the relocation. But the majority of these costs are associated with relocation. The vast majority -- I think it's about 70% of the co
componenttext: Yes, let me -- I'm going to refer this to Dennis so he can kind of walk you some of that and what's happening relative to the relocation. But the majority of these costs are associated with relocation. The vast majority -- I think it's about 70% of the costs are relocation. So Dennis, do you want to kind of walk him through that a bit?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Greg, you're right. If you think back when we reported in the 10-K, the cost were about $332 million. Since that time, we have had the relocation program extended at least a couple of times by the courts. So the -- if you look at the change of about
componenttext: Sure. Greg, you're right. If you think back when we reported in the 10-K, the cost were about $332 million. Since that time, we have had the relocation program extended at least a couple of times by the courts. So the -- if you look at the change of about $330 million, the majority of that has been relocation, 70%. Then you basically have 2 other buckets. About 15% of the overall total relates to the work of stopping the leak, building the relief wells, the root cause investigation that's underway and everything. And then you've got the buckets of the other cost related to legal and other out-of-pockets. So those are the 3 main: 70% relo, 70 -- or 15% for the stopping the leak and the investigation, and then the other 15% related to legal expense and other costs.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Faisel Khan with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Faisel Khan with Citigroup.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the TdM asset sale, I suppose that with the sales sort of announced, did that mean it was difficult to sort of get a long-term contract on that plant for sales in New Mexico? Is that sort of the genesis behind why this asset's being sold? Is it the --
componenttext: On the TdM asset sale, I suppose that with the sales sort of announced, did that mean it was difficult to sort of get a long-term contract on that plant for sales in New Mexico? Is that sort of the genesis behind why this asset's being sold? Is it the -- I thought that this would sort of fall underneath that bucket of assets that could be under a long-term contract, but maybe that wasn't a possibility.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to have Mark talk about that. But it have been sold under the U.S. previously, and -- that we were working on the possibility of trying to sell it into the Mexican markets. But as we looked at the asset and the difficulty in that, we decide
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to have Mark talk about that. But it have been sold under the U.S. previously, and -- that we were working on the possibility of trying to sell it into the Mexican markets. But as we looked at the asset and the difficulty in that, we decided that it was not likely to be not long-term contracted in the near term. Mark, you want to...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's right. I mean, I -- the plant right now is configured only for sale into the U.S. We've looked at -- and we have a plan to connect it into the grid in Mexico. It could be that in the not-too-distant future, that there could be a long-t
componenttext: Yes, I think that's right. I mean, I -- the plant right now is configured only for sale into the U.S. We've looked at -- and we have a plan to connect it into the grid in Mexico. It could be that in the not-too-distant future, that there could be a long-term contract opportunity with the CFE. They did -- the CFE just did sponsor and build a new plant very close to our LNG facility in -- down by Ensenada. And so it's going to delay for some years the need for additional capacity in that region. And also to -- just with those kinds of plants, fossil fuel-fired plants in Mexico, the contracting periods are not as long as they once were. And so it -- we started to see that this asset is not likely to meet our kind of long-term contracted objectives. And therefore, we thought that we ought to put it on the market and see if we -- and move to sell it. All that said, I think we have certainly a reserve price in our heads, that if we don't get it or don't get it, then we'll rethink that. But I think we're in very good -- we're looking at trying to move forward on it.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Makes sense. And then just going back Aliso, I just want to understand. So you're saying we probably won't get any major final report in the agencies until late '16 or '17. Are there going to be sort of any initial findings that come out through the
componenttext: Okay. Makes sense. And then just going back Aliso, I just want to understand. So you're saying we probably won't get any major final report in the agencies until late '16 or '17. Are there going to be sort of any initial findings that come out through the regulatory process over the next few months?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, there were some initial findings from DOGGR that indicated that SoCalGas was in full compliance with all the rules that were in place at that time, and DOGGR came out with those findings early on from the preliminary review. But right n
componenttext: Well, I would say, there were some initial findings from DOGGR that indicated that SoCalGas was in full compliance with all the rules that were in place at that time, and DOGGR came out with those findings early on from the preliminary review. But right now, the work that Blade is doing on-site in conjunction with CPUC, I don't think we're going to get any preliminary information. What they'll do is they're gathering the data and then they'll write the report, and it's likely that report will be out at the end of this year or early next year. Dennis, do you want to add to that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the only thing that I'd add to that, Debbie, is that there's a lot of work going on, not just under the root cause investigation with DOGGR, the CPUC and Blade, but work to get Aliso back up and running. And I can tell you right now that it's really c
componenttext: No, the only thing that I'd add to that, Debbie, is that there's a lot of work going on, not just under the root cause investigation with DOGGR, the CPUC and Blade, but work to get Aliso back up and running. And I can tell you right now that it's really clear that the regulators and policymakers truly understand the importance of Aliso Canyon and gas storage to both gas and electric reliability. So the tone is basically, let's make it's safe, but let's it get back up and running as quickly as we can. And so far, we've got -- of the 114 wells at Aliso, about 100 of them have completed the Phase 1 inspections, and we're transitioning those now to Phase 2. So that our target right now, Faisel, is to have the field ready for full operation, obviously, subject to DOGGR confirmation, but by the late summer, probably late August. So a lot of work going on there.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the storage field would not be able to go back into operation until this report comes out? Or could you put it back into service before then?
componenttext: Okay. And then the storage field would not be able to go back into operation until this report comes out? Or could you put it back into service before then?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, today, we've got about 15 billion cubic feet of gas. So if needed, we can withdraw. We're just not allowed to inject until the field has been confirmed ready by DOGGR. And as I said, our current target right now is to have wells ready for reinjectio
componenttext: Well, today, we've got about 15 billion cubic feet of gas. So if needed, we can withdraw. We're just not allowed to inject until the field has been confirmed ready by DOGGR. And as I said, our current target right now is to have wells ready for reinjection by late summer.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that is before the full report will be out.
componenttext: And that is before the full report will be out.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And that's separate from the root cause analysis. So those things don't -- they aren't linked. The root cause is going down one work stream, and then there's a separate work stream to get the field back up and running.
componenttext: Yes. And that's separate from the root cause analysis. So those things don't -- they aren't linked. The root cause is going down one work stream, and then there's a separate work stream to get the field back up and running.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, makes sense. And then just on REX. I just want to make sure I understand the sort of -- I guess what you had additionally had in guidance in the past. So I guess, did you always have sort of the legacy sort of REX interest that you have going to 0 e
componenttext: Okay, makes sense. And then just on REX. I just want to make sure I understand the sort of -- I guess what you had additionally had in guidance in the past. So I guess, did you always have sort of the legacy sort of REX interest that you have going to 0 earnings in 2020? I just want to make sure I understood that correctly.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, you understood it correctly. I mean, we basically had -- it was de minimus in 2020 because we had looked at the contracts all expiring in 2019, and then there was debt refinancing that needed to be done. And so we looked at the economics of that.
componenttext: Yes. No, you understood it correctly. I mean, we basically had -- it was de minimus in 2020 because we had looked at the contracts all expiring in 2019, and then there was debt refinancing that needed to be done. And so we looked at the economics of that. And so when we're putting our plans together, we were not expecting REX to continue at the kind of run rate that -- we told you, it was $60 million for the 10 months we had this year. We were not expecting it to continue at that kind of run rate after those contracts expired in 2019.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to have a sense, do you expect the contracts to expire and nothing would happen after that? Or did you also -- did you expect some recontracting but at a lower rate? And did it also include the east-to-west sort of contracts that were signed?
componenttext: Just to have a sense, do you expect the contracts to expire and nothing would happen after that? Or did you also -- did you expect some recontracting but at a lower rate? And did it also include the east-to-west sort of contracts that were signed?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We looked at all of that, and we expected that there would be some contracting at a lower rate. Mark, you want to...
componenttext: Yes. We looked at all of that, and we expected that there would be some contracting at a lower rate. Mark, you want to...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Faisel. Yes, obviously, we did. We had a projection of what we thought the recontracting rate would be. And then we also assumed that we would continue with the east-to-west contracting that we've done. And that -- we had a market check on that, and
componenttext: Yes, Faisel. Yes, obviously, we did. We had a projection of what we thought the recontracting rate would be. And then we also assumed that we would continue with the east-to-west contracting that we've done. And that -- we had a market check on that, and that's what was in our plan. But that, combined with the interest cost and some refinancing that we thought was going to happen, it just didn't have a material impact on our financials beyond 2018.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And last question for me. Just with the midstream MLP market sort of coming back to some degree off the bottom, I'm just wondering -- and also to sell REX, does this mean the MLP is sort of completely off the table even in the future?
componenttext: Okay, got it. And last question for me. Just with the midstream MLP market sort of coming back to some degree off the bottom, I'm just wondering -- and also to sell REX, does this mean the MLP is sort of completely off the table even in the future?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say nothing is off the table in the future. I mean I would never do that. We will always look at what's the lowest cost of capital for us to grow, and that's just the way we look at it. That REX was not a core asset for the MLP anyway since we onl
componenttext: I would say nothing is off the table in the future. I mean I would never do that. We will always look at what's the lowest cost of capital for us to grow, and that's just the way we look at it. That REX was not a core asset for the MLP anyway since we only owned a fraction of it, and we really didn't have the ability to use that as openly as you would an asset that you had 100%. And I would say, Cameron trains 1 through 3 are excellent assets for an MLP. So those would not be off the table. But right now, if you kind of look at where the market is, it's certainly not our top priority.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michael Lapides at Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Lapides at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, I have a couple of them. First of all, Debbie, can you talk about the portfolio, and whether you think there's anything else within it that you wouldn't view as core or strategic to Sempra over the long term. And if so, why?
componenttext: Actually, I have a couple of them. First of all, Debbie, can you talk about the portfolio, and whether you think there's anything else within it that you wouldn't view as core or strategic to Sempra over the long term. And if so, why?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. There's nothing that we identify right now that fits that category, Michael. We look at our assets all the time. And all of our assets, other assets, really are pretty well long-term contracted. The only one that comes up that we look at constantly
componenttext: Sure. There's nothing that we identify right now that fits that category, Michael. We look at our assets all the time. And all of our assets, other assets, really are pretty well long-term contracted. The only one that comes up that we look at constantly is gas storage. And that we do have still contracts on gas storage that have some duration left on those contracts. And we look at that and say how does that fit with our other asset. And what we see happening kind of in the Gulf region with the export of LNG, the conversion of coal to gas and need for different types of assets to support that, and then looking at the storage market right now. We kind of think that the timing on that asset, if things are going to happen, they're going to get better, not likely worse. And so that's one we constantly look at. But we have concluded on that, at least for the time being, it doesn't seem like something that we would want to try to get out of our portfolio at this time.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. When you talk about the $18.5 billion capital plan over the next 5 years, how much of that is at the 2 core California Utilities?
componenttext: Got it. When you talk about the $18.5 billion capital plan over the next 5 years, how much of that is at the 2 core California Utilities?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's about $12 billion of that at the 2 California Utilities, so the vast majority of that. And there may be some opportunities -- I was just going to say, there may be some opportunities for the Utilities to actually consume more of that. There's some pr
componenttext: It's about $12 billion of that at the 2 California Utilities, so the vast majority of that. And there may be some opportunities -- I was just going to say, there may be some opportunities for the Utilities to actually consume more of that. There's some projects that we have -- that are on the green sheets that we show you, that we're hoping to get some approval on, that would add to the capital expenditures at the Utilities during that time. But we really put in that -- only the ones that we have some great visibility and high certainty that we either have rate case approval or project approval from the CPUC or FERC.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last question, how are you thinking about the growth rate in the South American Utilities relative to the rest of the Sempra portfolio? I ask only because if I back out just the FX impact, it still doesn't seem like it was a huge growth rate and
componenttext: Okay. And last question, how are you thinking about the growth rate in the South American Utilities relative to the rest of the Sempra portfolio? I ask only because if I back out just the FX impact, it still doesn't seem like it was a huge growth rate and going back over the last couple of quarters as well. Just curious how you're thinking about that business and kind of its organic growth potential?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we still see a lot of organic growth potential there. Because similar to Mexico, there's huge needs for infrastructure in those countries. And we're looking at some -- quite a few things right now, in Peru, in particular. Mark, why don't you
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we still see a lot of organic growth potential there. Because similar to Mexico, there's huge needs for infrastructure in those countries. And we're looking at some -- quite a few things right now, in Peru, in particular. Mark, why don't you maybe hit a little bit about some of the things that we've looked at and opportunities for growth there.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I mean, there is huge infrastructure needs there. I do think both economies, probably Chile more than Peru, but both economies have been affected by the downturn in the mining sector, and effectively China's downturn. And so I think that's hurt the
componenttext: Right. I mean, there is huge infrastructure needs there. I do think both economies, probably Chile more than Peru, but both economies have been affected by the downturn in the mining sector, and effectively China's downturn. And so I think that's hurt their overall growth. But I think when you look at them, where they've been historically and what the expectation is for this year and next year, we still see strong underlying growth that you just don't see in any domestic utilities. You still see the 3%, 4% customer growth and 3%, 4% energy growth coming back. And we -- I think with the recession, we've had a little bit of a downturn there. But it's -- we see that coming back. And then on top of that, we see some large infrastructure needs, which really wouldn't be available to us if we weren't active in that market, in the utility market there. We just wouldn't have a presence to be able to capitalize on those. And so we're -- I think, we're -- again, we don't put those in our plan because we don't have them signed up yet. But we're close on several things, and I think it looks promising. It looks like there's definitely some activity level that's going to be happening down there that'll increase the growth for those facilities.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next is Steve Fleishman with Wolfe.
componenttext: The next is Steve Fleishman with Wolfe.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. First on the assumptions on the rate case. So you highlight that the guidance includes the settlement, including the repair tax treatment. Could you just remind me the -- I recall that not being a big number. But I just want t
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. First on the assumptions on the rate case. So you highlight that the guidance includes the settlement, including the repair tax treatment. Could you just remind me the -- I recall that not being a big number. But I just want to make sure I know what the number is for the prior repair tax treatment.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me have Joe walk through the repair tax treatment numbers for you. The -- let me talk about the rate case though, while he's getting the precise numbers on that. What I would say is on the GRC, that we've been given every indication that we shoul
componenttext: Yes, let me have Joe walk through the repair tax treatment numbers for you. The -- let me talk about the rate case though, while he's getting the precise numbers on that. What I would say is on the GRC, that we've been given every indication that we should be getting a decision soon. And that we're expecting, since we had 8 out of 11 parties sign on to the settlement, that we would likely get the settlement as the outcome. We would also expect to get the repair allowance because we feel like we have very strong argument and have differentiated ourselves in terms of how we handled it in our rate cases going forward and returning the benefits to customers. And so we would anticipate getting a decision hopefully very soon and that very consistent with the settlement. And what we've been told is that the paying up and the delay is not any different than what you're hearing from other utilities commenting on their proceedings is that there's just a lack of resources at the commission right now, especially in the ALJ division to get some out these things out as quickly as they would like. And so we anticipated that it would come earlier. But -- that we continue to be told it will be soon, and that it is really more hung up because of their resource issue. Okay, Joe?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, let me just remind you all, Jeff and Dennis and their teams have been working closely with the commission on this issue. And we've tried to emphasize with them that we have very unique facts that we are differentiated from some of the other utiliti
componenttext: Steve, let me just remind you all, Jeff and Dennis and their teams have been working closely with the commission on this issue. And we've tried to emphasize with them that we have very unique facts that we are differentiated from some of the other utilities. And some of those things relate to -- our rate case was actually worked on and closed -- and officially closed by the ALJ before we made our changes in the tax treatment. And in our 2012 GRC, we offered up a sharing mechanism, much like we have in the past, and that was rejected. It was denied. So we've kind of offered up avenues for them to look at these kind of things. And as we've talked about before, there's very good precedent that the savings you generate before the next rate case were all kinds of things, tax, general operating flow to shareholders. So we think this will be resolved favorably. But let me get to the numbers that you asked about. There's 2 timing periods that are important: one is up through 2014 and then one is 2015. And I'll talk about the first period first. So from the beginning of the rate case through '14, the intervenors that applied for this suggested that we had about $90 million at each utility that they want to be adjusted through rate base. So that would be a rate base adjustment. And the impact, if we loss that -- we don't think we will. But if we lost that, the impact would be $6 million to $7 million in each of the utilities kind of going forward because of that change in rate base. But then, the commission asked us to put a memorandum account together for 2015 savings from this tax repair allowance. And if we were to lose that issue, we will of course appeal it and fight it. But if we were to lose it, we would have to take a charge of about $70 million. That's broken between the 2 utilities. But in total, $65 million to $70 million in total for the '15 memorandum account. Again, I think these are things that we expect to go in our favor. We're giving you all the data done before.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But in -- I guess, the big reason I ask this question is the scheme of a range at $7.20 to $7.80. These are pretty small when you look at the ongoing impact. They're really not meaningful. So I didn't know why you kind of highlighted it out because
componenttext: Okay. But in -- I guess, the big reason I ask this question is the scheme of a range at $7.20 to $7.80. These are pretty small when you look at the ongoing impact. They're really not meaningful. So I didn't know why you kind of highlighted it out because it really doesn't move the needle very much at all.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it doesn't move the needle at all in the outer years. It was really a 2016 issue because if that decision were to come out in the next couple of weeks and we had a negative result, then we didn't want to surprise anybody.
componenttext: Yes, it doesn't move the needle at all in the outer years. It was really a 2016 issue because if that decision were to come out in the next couple of weeks and we had a negative result, then we didn't want to surprise anybody.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the Aliso, with the changes to the relocation that you set up, can you give a sense of what the ongoing -- like, weekly cost is? Is there some way to get a sense of that?
componenttext: Okay. And just on the Aliso, with the changes to the relocation that you set up, can you give a sense of what the ongoing -- like, weekly cost is? Is there some way to get a sense of that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me hand it to Dennis. I think that one of the things that we need to kind of put in perspective is that we've made a lot of changes to the program that reduced the cost from where it was. And so Dennis can kind of walk you through, including the
componenttext: Yes. Let me hand it to Dennis. I think that one of the things that we need to kind of put in perspective is that we've made a lot of changes to the program that reduced the cost from where it was. And so Dennis can kind of walk you through, including the number of people that are going home now, which is quite significant. Dennis?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, let me give you a little color around that. Because I think as we get some questions, people want to understand and put it in perspective. I mean, when you look -- first of all, the leak, as you know, was permanently sealed back on February 18. And
componenttext: Steve, let me give you a little color around that. Because I think as we get some questions, people want to understand and put it in perspective. I mean, when you look -- first of all, the leak, as you know, was permanently sealed back on February 18. And at the time, when you look at the number of people that were impacted, it was really a -- the vast majority of the households around Aliso Canyon, they never left. They stayed at their homes. Everything was safe and everything. So it was a smaller number to begin with. But since then, we've had over 54% of any impacted residents that have actually gone back to their homes. And every week, we're seeing more and more. So to give you an actual run rate is difficult because, as Debbie said, we're doing things within our program that allow us to -- and help the residents move, say, from hotels to corporate-style apartments, more family-situated apartments with kitchens where they can cook and everything, and that helps bring down the cost. The other things that we're doing is we've been offering in-home cleaning services to give further assurance to residents that everything's safe. So while we haven't given an official run rate, what we can tell you is that the number that we gave out for -- the $655 million assumed relocation expenses through June 7. And as we said, we expect to get additional information from the Department of Public Health this month regarding their testing. And I think that type of information will even further get people more comfortable that they can go home, and we'll see the numbers continue to drop week after week.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And they just very quickly, last question. Debbie, any incremental color to your year-end call on views on Cameron 4?
componenttext: All right. And they just very quickly, last question. Debbie, any incremental color to your year-end call on views on Cameron 4?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And let me just ask Mark to address that as we've been having some conversations with Octávio recently about how those discussions are going. And actually, I feel pretty positive about what we're hearing from the customers and the high level of inte
componenttext: Yes. And let me just ask Mark to address that as we've been having some conversations with Octávio recently about how those discussions are going. And actually, I feel pretty positive about what we're hearing from the customers and the high level of interest. So Mark?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, thanks. I think the big thing though, the point to keep in mind is as far as U.S. LNG exports go, we believe train 4 will be the least expensive options available. So that's why we have -- we continue to have pretty good interest from people l
componenttext: Yes, Steve, thanks. I think the big thing though, the point to keep in mind is as far as U.S. LNG exports go, we believe train 4 will be the least expensive options available. So that's why we have -- we continue to have pretty good interest from people looking at securing that option early and maybe even in advance of when world demand may require it. So we are feeling pretty confident that it's going to move forward. We -- our original statements that we made on the last call at the end of the year or 2 were that we expected to have something wrapped up by the end of the year and that our FID amount would be in the first part of next year. And that hasn't changed. So we're still working towards that. And if we get any indication that things are different, we'll tell you right away. But I think right now, we're still feeling like this will happen sometime this year.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then I would add to that. Just that you all read about what's happening in the markets. And we have great expressed interest from customers. I mean, they're spending time, they're putting teams on this to negotiate with us. So it's not like they'
componenttext: Yes. And then I would add to that. Just that you all read about what's happening in the markets. And we have great expressed interest from customers. I mean, they're spending time, they're putting teams on this to negotiate with us. So it's not like they're just saying, "We kind of like to do something." They're actually dedicating resources to this. But this is a very challenging market to get agreement signed in. And so I just want to counterbalance that. And honestly, if we get agreements signed in January or February next year versus December of this year, I'll be a happy camper. So -- and we're really focused on it. And as I said, it's not like the counterparties are not engaged fully. They are engaged fully.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Rose-Lynn Armstrong at Barclays.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Rose-Lynn Armstrong at Barclays.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk with a little bit greater specificity about the construction progress at Cameron trains 1 through 3? And then separately, regarding the Aliso estimate, the $665 million, can -- with regards to the relocation assumption in there, are you
componenttext: Can you just talk with a little bit greater specificity about the construction progress at Cameron trains 1 through 3? And then separately, regarding the Aliso estimate, the $665 million, can -- with regards to the relocation assumption in there, are you assuming that the same number of households are relocated in the entire period? Or is there sort of a declining trend through June 7?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me take the LNG question first and talk a little bit about that, and then have Dennis address the assumptions on the relocation. So for Camerons 1 through 3, we're 43% complete. The construction is going really well. We're slightly ahead of our
componenttext: Sure. Let me take the LNG question first and talk a little bit about that, and then have Dennis address the assumptions on the relocation. So for Camerons 1 through 3, we're 43% complete. The construction is going really well. We're slightly ahead of our construction schedule. I would say on schedule, but if you look at some of the data, we're slightly ahead. And that we're still expecting train 1 to come on in March of '18, train 2 to come on in July of '18 and 3 in November of '18, which was the schedule that we would outline for you previously. So everything's going very, very well there. I would say, the safety performance has been exceptional on the job. And that the major material's a long lead time. Materials have all been ordered. And everything is moving quite well on construction. I don't know, Mark, is there anything else you want to add?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I think, right now, the project is moving as smoothly as we could have expected it. It's just -- it's in very good shape.
componenttext: No. I mean, I think, right now, the project is moving as smoothly as we could have expected it. It's just -- it's in very good shape.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So then your second question related to the assumptions that are in the $665 million on the relocation, and let me have Dennis address that.
componenttext: So then your second question related to the assumptions that are in the $665 million on the relocation, and let me have Dennis address that.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rose-Lynn. Yes, as I mentioned, what we did is we assumed that the relocation cost would continue through June 7. And we basically -- to be conservative, we've assumed that they stay flat throughout that period. Now what we are seeing, and this was
componenttext: Sure, Rose-Lynn. Yes, as I mentioned, what we did is we assumed that the relocation cost would continue through June 7. And we basically -- to be conservative, we've assumed that they stay flat throughout that period. Now what we are seeing, and this was incorporated into our assumptions, is that as we're cleaning more homes, people are going home. They're being -- they were even more comfortable that their homes are safe and everything. So we are seeing more and more people go home that way. The other thing that we've been doing, that we incorporated into our assumptions is as we're able to locate more of the family-style corporate housing options within the area, we're transitioning more people from hotels where they're also receiving Per Diem to these corporate apartments, where they have their kitchens and we don't have to pay the Per Dies. So those are the types of -- and that's part of the program that we have. That's part of the approved program. So that helps reduce the overall cost as well. So all those things are built into it, but we aren't assuming a huge drop-off. But we are seeing that on a week-to-week basis, so I think that's favorable.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, to Paul Patterson, Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: Next, to Paul Patterson, Glenrock Associates.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: So I just wanted to touch base as to revisit Steve's question on the growth rate and the repairs deduction. Just to understand this, the impact is roughly approximately $70 million in 2016. And then after that, it really doesn't have much of a significant impact afterwards. Is that the way to look at this?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Joe. Yes, that's the way to think of it. But the $65 million to $70 million is not in any of our numbers. We're assuming that we would not and we don't have that impact. So it's really -- if we get a negative impact going forward, there's jus
componenttext: Yes. This is Joe. Yes, that's the way to think of it. But the $65 million to $70 million is not in any of our numbers. We're assuming that we would not and we don't have that impact. So it's really -- if we get a negative impact going forward, there's just really very -- it's not significant, not material.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I just wanted to double check on that. And then with respect to the $100 million to $120 million of capacity release and the loss that you guys expected to get in the second quarter on that, what would it have been if you -- I mean, I'm just not com
componenttext: Okay, I just wanted to double check on that. And then with respect to the $100 million to $120 million of capacity release and the loss that you guys expected to get in the second quarter on that, what would it have been if you -- I mean, I'm just not completely clear. Was it that -- I mean, you did describe it, and I apologize. But what would it have been if you hadn't done that? What if it just been sort of pro rated through -- over to 2019 or something? Or...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. I said that and so I'll say it again so it's clear. It'll be in the transcript. I said that in our plan, the one that we gave you last year, we had for 2016 and '17 between $5 million and $10 million of losses related to this capacity, because
componenttext: Yes, Paul. I said that and so I'll say it again so it's clear. It'll be in the transcript. I said that in our plan, the one that we gave you last year, we had for 2016 and '17 between $5 million and $10 million of losses related to this capacity, because we had a lot of capacity sold forward. It wasn't exactly at the same price we were buying the capacity up. It is pretty close. So we had a $5 million to $10 million loss for '16 and '17. That did not take into account some of the recent financial troubles that some of the capacity holders had. So if we had kept it, we would have had bigger losses going forward, which is why, as we tried to sell this forward and on a permanent basis, we're taking a bigger loss than you would assume from the $5 million to $10 million had been in our plan. But for you to adjust your plan, you were probably basing them off of our numbers. And I wanted you to know what was in our numbers before, which was $5 million to $10 million for the next couple of years.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the potential buyback, that's kind of a placeholder. And if I understand it correctly, you guys are aiming for better returns with investments and what have you. But the 12% sort of has this as a placeholder in the event that you, for some
componenttext: Okay. And then the potential buyback, that's kind of a placeholder. And if I understand it correctly, you guys are aiming for better returns with investments and what have you. But the 12% sort of has this as a placeholder in the event that you, for some reason, not able to find investments. Is that right way to think of it?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. That is the way to think about it. And what I'd like to emphasize is, look, we're pretty unique here. Most of our peers, whether they're utilities or midstream companies or renewable companies, are issuing equity to grow. We're actually growing
componenttext: Yes, Paul. That is the way to think about it. And what I'd like to emphasize is, look, we're pretty unique here. Most of our peers, whether they're utilities or midstream companies or renewable companies, are issuing equity to grow. We're actually growing our earnings and our cash flow so fast and increasing the strength of our balance sheet and increasing our dividend 8% to 9% a year over this period, that we're able to actually look at a potential buyback if we don't capture some of these projects we're working on. But we fully expect to capture those projects and do better. We just showed this is an optional thing. It's within our control, and we can do. That's unique.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if you were to be able to find the investment, the 12% would be on the lower end of the range. Is that the way to think of it?
componenttext: Okay. So if you were to be able to find the investment, the 12% would be on the lower end of the range. Is that the way to think of it?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just add to that. The 12% is based upon what we already have under contract and in construction. So -- and what our expected utility earnings would be, assuming we get the settlement in the rate case, and then we just assume in out years that
componenttext: Yes. Let me just add to that. The 12% is based upon what we already have under contract and in construction. So -- and what our expected utility earnings would be, assuming we get the settlement in the rate case, and then we just assume in out years that we use attrition in addition to that. So we try to use conservative assumptions for that. But then we show you all the development projects. And in this time, we thought that using the assumption of the buyback is conservative because we wouldn't be sitting there with 22% FFO to debt on our balance sheet and not do something with it. What we fully expect in the next 5 years that we will have projects that will have a much better return than what we're showing you with the stock buyback. But we have is just -- we have wonderful flexibility. And to be able to show you 5 years what we have long-term contracted that yields that kind of a growth rate and gives us the strength of the balance sheet, that gives us the flexibility if we were not to find projects to buyback stock, which we don't think is going to be the outcome because we have a robust backlog of projects that we're working on. But it's just a wonderful position to be in. And honestly, this is what I was going to talk about at the analyst meeting. Because it's -- not too many others can talk about having a strengthening balance sheet, having this type of a 12% growth rate with conservative assumptions and then having the ability to grow the dividend by 8% to 9% over that 5-year period of time, with nothing else. So that was going to be a lot of my presentation. I'm -- kind of close to even kind of what we're going to be talking about. But it's a really great position to be in. And since we didn't do the analyst conference, we wanted you to all understand where we stood relative to that. And we'll go into a lot more detail, as we always do, when we get to the conference.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Well, thanks for all of you joining us today. And as always, if you have any follow-up questions, feel free to contact our IR team. We look forward to seeing you at the analyst conference. We will let you know as soon as we get a date scheduled so that you can plan around that. And thank you very much for being understanding with our decision to postpone that. We would not like to have done that, but we also want to do the best job possible in outlining our business. And I think having the certainty of a rate case decision will be a much better position to be in when we really talk to you about the business. So have a great day, and we'll see you some time, hopefully, in July.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Sempra Energy First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Rick Vaccari. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Sempra Energy First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Rick Vaccari. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2016 Financial Presentation. A live webcast for this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. With me in San Diego are several members of ou
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2016 Financial Presentation. A live webcast for this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. 
With me in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Chairman and CEO; Mark Snell, President; Joe Householder, Chief Financial Officer; Martha Wyrsch, General Counsel; Trevor Mihalik, Chief Accounting Officer; Dennis Arriola, Chief Executive Officer of SoCalGas; and Jeff Martin, Chief Executive Officer of San Diego Gas & Electric.
Before starting, I would like to remind everyone that we will be discussing forward-looking statements on this call within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. The factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially are discussed in the company's most recent 10-K and 10-Q. It's important to note that all of the earnings per share amounts in our presentation are shown on a diluted basis and that we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the presentation slides that accompany this call and to Table A in our first quarter 2016 earnings press release for a reconciliation to GAAP measures. 
I'd also like to note that the forward-looking statements contained in this presentation speak only as of today, May 4, 2016, and the company does not assume any obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements in the future. 
With that, please turn to Slide 4, and let me hand the call over to Debbie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick. On today's call, we are following a slightly different format. As you know, the final GRC decision for our California Utilities has not been issued. However, we expect to receive a proposed decision relatively soon. Because we have reached a
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick. On today's call, we are following a slightly different format. As you know, the final GRC decision for our California Utilities has not been issued. However, we expect to receive a proposed decision relatively soon. Because we have reached a multiparty settlement agreement, we continue to believe the most likely GRC outcome is one consistent without settlement. We also believe we have made a strong showing to support our historical treatment of tax repair allowance benefits. Therefore, today, we are updating our 2016 adjusted EPS guidance and providing you with our long-term growth rate, assuming a GRC outcome consistent with the settlement. 
We think the best approach is to postpone our analyst conference until we have a final GRC decision. We are tentatively looking at the month of July in New York City as a possible date for the conference. Once we receive a PD, we will confirm the date and location. 
In our other businesses, we recently announced the sale of our Southeast utilities and our interest in REX. We expect to receive about $760 million of cash proceeds to invest in projects that align better with our growth strategy. As you know, our strategy is to provide growth that is roughly twice that of the utility average but with a commensurate risk profile. I will discuss these transactions later on the call. 
Our updated 2016 adjusted guidance range is now $4.60 per share to $5 per share. This range reflects approximately $60 million of reduced earnings from REX. The sale of our Southeast utilities does not affect current or future earnings, since earnings reduced from the sale can largely be offset by lower interest costs.
Looking forward, we are well positioned for strong growth over the next 5 years. We expect our base plan to provide earnings in 2020 of $7.20 per share to $7.80 per share. The resulting adjusted compound annual growth rate for 2016 to 2020 is about 12%. Prior to the sale of REX, the comparable growth rate would have been about 11%. Joe will address the growth rate further in his remarks, but I want to emphasize that we expect to have significant credit capacity in the latter years of our plan, which will provide us with flexibility in capital allocation. We will discuss our plan assumptions, business unit projections and growth strategy in more depth once we reschedule the analyst conference. 
Turning to our financial results. We reported first quarter adjusted earnings of $370 million. As a reminder, until we receive a final GRC, we are recording revenues based upon 2015 authorized amounts. Once we receive a final decision, we will record the impact of the 2016 authorized margin back to January 1. If the GRC had been finalized by January 1 and was consistent with the settlement agreement, Utilities' first quarter earnings would have been in line with last year, despite the fact that approximately $60 million of annual tax repair benefits will now flow to customers under the new GRC. 
Now please turn to Slide 5. There are several updates related to Aliso Canyon. First, SoCalGas is cooperating with DOGGR and the CPUC on the root cause investigation through their contractor, Blade Energy Partners. We expect the investigation to take about 6 to 9 months with the results being issued by the agencies late this year or early next year. 
Second, we are working to get the field back in service for injection. Consistent with DOGGR's proposed safety review, we have implemented a plan to prioritize and test wells, with a goal to have the facility in service by the end of this summer.
Third, we are working with state and local agencies to address electric reliability concerns. Aliso Canyon currently has about 15 Bcf of gas available for withdrawal. When deciding how best to use that gas, reliability for both the summer and winter seasons must be considered. 
Fourth, we are completing our estimate of the total amount of gas lost from the leak and formulating a plan to mitigate that amount. 
Fifth, the temporary relocation program has been extended to allow the county to complete in-home testing, which results expected this month. SoCalGas and public agencies have conducted numerous tests of outdoor air quality. Results continue to confirm that air quality in Porter Ranch is at normal levels. 
Finally, we are addressing the litigations that has been filed related to the leak. 
With regards to cost, we have incurred additional amounts, primarily from continuation of the temporary relocation program as ordered by the court. The court has scheduled a follow appearing on June 7. Based on an expectation that the relocation program continues through June 7, we estimate the cost for amounts paid and forecast to be paid at approximately $665 million. We have recorded an insurance receivable of $660 million. Our cost estimate does not include certain potential items as described on the slide. Please refer to our 2015 10-K and first quarter 2016 10-Q for more detail on cost and our insurance. 
Now let's turn to Slide 6 for an update on our other businesses. Sempra constantly looks at our assets to determine whether they fit with our long-term contracted infrastructure model and whether they integrate with other assets to offer strong long-term growth prospects. We identified 3 assets that are no longer a strategic fit for us: REX, our Southeast utilities and the TdM power plant in Mexico. For the first 2, we have announced sales agreement; and for TdM, we are conducting a sales process. 
For REX, we expect the sale of our equity interest to close in the second quarter and to provide $440 million in proceeds. The sale also allows us to forego expected future contributions for capital investment and debt repayments. We believe our capital can be better utilized to further enhance our strong growth outlook. 
As a result of the sale, we forecast the reduction for partial year 2016 earnings of approximately $60 million, which is included in our adjusted EPS range of $4.60 per share to $5 per share. It is important to note that had we held our interest in REX, we expected 2020 earnings to be immaterial and dilute our growth, largely due to loss of earnings from west-to-east contracts that expire in 2019. 
In addition, we plan to permanently release uncontracted capacity held by Sempra. The negative earnings impact of this capacity release is projected to be between $100 million and $120 million, and will be recorded in the second quarter. This amount reflects the acceleration of estimated losses that would have otherwise been realized over the remaining contract term. It is excluded from our 2016 adjusted earnings guidance. 
Moving to our Southeast utilities. We finalized the sales agreement last week and expect to receive $323 million in cash proceeds with the buyer to assume $67 million of debt. We did not see significant additional growth potential in our Southeast utility footprint, and the earnings impact is projected to be offset with reduced interest costs. Similar to REX, we expect to use the proceeds to invest in projects with stronger growth prospects. 
Finally, TdM is the third asset that no longer fits with our long-term contracted infrastructure strategy. It is currently held for sale, and we are in the midst of a sales process. 
Now please turn to Slide 7. IEnova's building upon its position as the largest private energy company in Mexico to identify and originate new investment opportunities. IEnova is working on multiple development initiatives: including M&A; asset optimization; strategic partnerships with established companies and new companies seeking to enter the Mexican market; and emerging the opportunities in clean energy, storage and liquids infrastructure. 
One example of asset optimization is the building of laterals of our gas pipeline network to interconnect with end users. Just this week, CFE awarded IEnova a contract to build to small lateral that connects our Sonora pipeline to a combined-cycle power plant. In addition to project opportunities identified by IEnova, the CFE bidding process for natural gas pipelines continues. We are currently evaluating 2 tenders with likely bid dates during the second quarter. 
In generation, we expect to see the second round of renewable energy auctions in August. And in Electric Transmission, we expect to see the first 2 bids under new rules on energy reform in 2016 and 2017. Each Electric Transmission project represents an estimated $1.2 billion of investment.
With that, please turn to Slide 8, and I'll turn the call over to Joe. Joe?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Turning to our long-term financial projections, we expect that our base plan can provide 2020 earnings of $7.20 per share to $7.80 per share. The resulting adjusted earnings CAGR from 2016 to 2020 is about 12%. Some of our key plan assumpt
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. Turning to our long-term financial projections, we expect that our base plan can provide 2020 earnings of $7.20 per share to $7.80 per share. The resulting adjusted earnings CAGR from 2016 to 2020 is about 12%. Some of our key plan assumptions include an $18.5 billion capital program, including joint venture CapEx for Cameron trains 1 through 3; full year earnings of $300 million to $350 million from Cameron trains 1 through 3 in both 2019 and 2020; a GRC outcome in line with our proposed settlement agreement; and tax repair allowance benefits prior to 2016 being retained by shareholders; and an optional $2 billion share repurchase.
Under our base plan, annual adjusted EBITDA is expected to increase by $1.7 billion over the plan period, raising our FFO to debt to roughly 22%. Including our targeted annual increase in the dividend of 8% to 9%, we project excess credit capacity in the later years of our plan to be between $2 billion and $4 billion. 
Leaving excess capacity on our balance sheet would not maximize shareholder value. We have used a conservative assumption of an optional $2 billion share repurchase, split between 2019 and 2020. While we do include this assumption, it is our intention to allocate capital toward high-value development projects. 
I will discuss all of our base plan assumptions and provide business unit guidance at our analyst conference. I want to remind you today that our plan is not aspirational in nature. It is anchored on expected utility performance and projects that are already contracted and operating or under construction. This approach gives us high visibility and conviction in our growth rate. 
On a final note, before turning to the quarterly results, I want to address the long-term earnings impact from the REX capacity release that Debbie discussed earlier. In the base plan we presented last year, we had only assumed about $5 million to $10 million of annual losses associated with this capacity for 2016 and 2017 because we had not factored in the financial distress that several counterparties have recently experienced. We had no capacity obligations in 2020. By permanently releasing the capacity now, our new 5-year plan does not have to reflect any future losses from this capacity nor any negative impact from the recently announced counterparty bankruptcies beyond the loss we expect to record in the second quarter. 
Now please turn to Slide 9. This morning, we reported first quarter earnings of $319 million. On an adjusted basis, we reported first quarter earnings of $370 million or $1.47 per share. Adjusted earnings this quarter exclude the $27 million after-tax loss on the pending sale of our equity interest in REX and $24 million of deferred Mexican income tax expense as a result of holding the TdM power plant for sale. 
In addition, just as a reminder, in 2016, we are now including LNG development expenses in our reported adjusted earnings and adjusted earnings guidance, whereas in 2015, these were excluded. There are several factors affecting the first quarter results that are either timing items or items expected to reverse in later quarters. 
Please turn to Slide 10 and I will discuss the key factors impacting our quarterly earnings. Quarter-over-quarter, adjusted earnings were impacted by the following items. At our California Utilities, we had $17 million of lower earnings, mostly due to higher operating cost from higher depreciation and litigation, with no increase in authorized margin due to the delay in our GRC. As Debbie noted, until we receive a final decision, we are recording revenues based on amounts authorized for 2015. Once we receive the final decision, we will record the cumulative impact of 2016 authorized revenues back to January 1. Including this retroactive benefit, we expect the Utilities' quarterly earnings would be roughly in line with last year, which is important, given the fact that approximately $60 million of annual tax repair benefits will now flow to customers under the new GRC. 
Moving to the parent category, we recorded $10 million of higher losses due to $7 million of lower repatriation tax expense that was more than offset by $10 million of higher net interest expense combined with the $5 million income tax benefit that was recorded in the first quarter of 2015. 
At U.S. Gas & Power, we had $9 million of lower earnings due primarily to the impact of natural gas price movements on inventories that we sold forward. We expect this $9 million lost to reverse by year-end. 
At Sempra International, we had $8 million of lower earnings from foreign currency effects. This was due to a $4 million negative impact in South America and a $4 million higher positive impact in Mexico in Q1 2015. 
At SoCalGas, our Q1 '15 results included an $8 million GCIM award. No GCIM award was recorded in Q1 2016 as this award was received in the fourth quarter of last year. 
Now let's conclude on Slide 11. In summary, we have updated our 2016 adjusted earnings guidance to $4.60 per share to $5 per share to reflect the REX sale. The annualized impact of the REX sale will also reduce earnings by approximately $70 million per year for the next few years. Our adjusted guidance is defined in further detail in the appendix. 
In terms of our financial results. While our first quarter earnings were impacted by the delay in our GRC, we will record the retroactive authorized margin back to January 1 once the final decision is received. 
Finally, assuming the GRC outcome is consistent with the settlement agreement, we project the base plan adjusted earnings CAGR of about 12% from 2016 to 2020. 
With that, we will conclude our prepared comments and stop to take any questions you may have.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
