headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let's -- well -- so first quick question to get out of the way, what's the implied growth rate year-over-year in 2019 into 2020? You talked about share repurchases. I've been getting questions on it, I just wanted to settle that.
componenttext: So let's -- well -- so first quick question to get out of the way, what's the implied growth rate year-over-year in 2019 into 2020? You talked about share repurchases. I've been getting questions on it, I just wanted to settle that.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we've disclosed now is the growth rate through 2020, and we're not going to give any adjusted earnings guidance for 2019. We always give you that fifth year and our 5-year plan. But I think you can kind of infer from what we've given you before
componenttext: Well, what we've disclosed now is the growth rate through 2020, and we're not going to give any adjusted earnings guidance for 2019. We always give you that fifth year and our 5-year plan. But I think you can kind of infer from what we've given you before and kind of the range of growth over that period of time. What I will say is as you know in our business, that some of our growth tends to be lumpy because we have large projects coming into service. And in 2019, will be the first full year of Cameron trains 1 through 3 going into service. Those trains remain on schedule to be completed throughout 2018, as we've told you before. So 2019, you'll see that come into 2019. And so 2019 will be lumpy in comparison to 2018. And 2018 will be lumpy when compared to 2017 as the trains kind of service.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I -- Julian, this is Joe. I'll just add on to that, exactly what Debbie said. But remember, the way we build our base plan, it will have utility growth ongoing from attrition and utility growth in South America, but there are no new projects that we h
componenttext: And I -- Julian, this is Joe. I'll just add on to that, exactly what Debbie said. But remember, the way we build our base plan, it will have utility growth ongoing from attrition and utility growth in South America, but there are no new projects that we have outlined that would come on service in '19 and '20. So the growth rate that you would see there or you would predict to see there won't be what we expect to have, because we expect to have new projects. But we're talking about 4 or 5 years from now.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And with that technicality out of the way, thinking holistically, what is the next focus, at least, of the company when it comes to that capital allocation? I appreciate you delineating the share repurchases as a placeholder. You're selling down so
componenttext: Great. And with that technicality out of the way, thinking holistically, what is the next focus, at least, of the company when it comes to that capital allocation? I appreciate you delineating the share repurchases as a placeholder. You're selling down some of the gas assets, deeming them noncore. Where is the company going? If you can kind of at least describe your preliminary thinking? I know it's a little bit of an Analyst Day kind of question, but I just thought I'd get it out there, especially in light of what should be nearer-term cash proceeds from the asset sales that you articulated already.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me talk to you about some of the things that we're looking at. And obviously, there's a lot of M&A activity right now in the space, there's a lot opportunities. But we have a lot of organic growth as well, so let me talk about some of those thin
componenttext: Well, let me talk to you about some of the things that we're looking at. And obviously, there's a lot of M&A activity right now in the space, there's a lot opportunities. But we have a lot of organic growth as well, so let me talk about some of those things. First of all, we are still looking at the train 4 being developed. And so that we would anticipate having agreements in place by the end of the year, based upon conversations we've been having with the parties now. And that is not at all in our growth plans. So the numbers we gave you for 2020 has nothing for any additional LNG beyond trains 1 through 3. So we still focus on that. We think it's a good growth opportunity for us. And then what we also think is the integrated assets. When you have such a huge demand for gas, the opportunity to develop pipelines and storage to serve those loads is a really great opportunity for us so we continue to look at putting capital into those areas. I would also say that as you look at the opening of the energy markets in Mexico, they're at the infancy right now. They've only done some of the gas infrastructure. We have Electric Transmission. We have pipelines for liquids. We have a pipelines -- or terminals for liquids. We have a lot of more energy infrastructure to come out for opportunities in Mexico. And we think we just have wonderful foundation of assets there that allows us some opportunity. And then I would say, our renewable business -- we don't talk a lot about our renewable business. But we had a growing, robust, successful renewable business that we continue to have new projects that we find, and we have the ability to expand on some of our existing projects. What I would say is that we have a strategy that's really focused on growing at more than twice the rate or twice the rate of the typical utility, but with a similar risk profile. So when we start looking at the assets, we look at are they long-term contracted? Can they have low volatility? Because we know you all value low volatility with growth. And can they support our growing dividends? And can they give us the strength of the balance sheet that we're seeing over the 5 years of the plan? And so projects that kind of fit that criteria, we're open to a lot of things. We constantly look on the M&A, and we see some assets that may be on the market that might be of interest to us. So our strategy hasn't changed, and we just thought that the capital that we had in some of these things was kind of trapped and was not really integrated with anything else we had, and was not going to provide us the kind of growth that other investments might.

Mark's groups are looking at lot of opportunities. So I can't name one thing because there's a whole bunch of things on the plate.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to touch on Mexico first. The 3 pipeline bids, which I know you got disqualified from. Could you explain the reasoning behind that? And if there's any way to reverse the result or appeal it? And how that may affect the bidding going forward
componenttext: I just wanted to touch on Mexico first. The 3 pipeline bids, which I know you got disqualified from. Could you explain the reasoning behind that? And if there's any way to reverse the result or appeal it? And how that may affect the bidding going forward for you guys?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm going to have Mark address that because I think it's important to note that it wasn't kind of -- it didn't happen with us being disqualified, one bid after the other. Unfortunately, we had to submit all bids kind of at the same time, and we didn
componenttext: Sure. I'm going to have Mark address that because I think it's important to note that it wasn't kind of -- it didn't happen with us being disqualified, one bid after the other. Unfortunately, we had to submit all bids kind of at the same time, and we didn't find out about being disqualified for the first one until the other 2 had already been submitted. But Mark, would you talk a little bit about how that happened? We're really going forward on how we're dealing with it.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, sure. I mean, on those particular bids, what the methodology that we used was to adjust our tariff to CFE by additional capacity that we anticipated to sell to other customers down the road. And -- but without specifying exactly where on the pipeli
componenttext: Right, sure. I mean, on those particular bids, what the methodology that we used was to adjust our tariff to CFE by additional capacity that we anticipated to sell to other customers down the road. And -- but without specifying exactly where on the pipeline we would do that, and that's basis of which they would -- disqualified us. And as Debbie said, we submitted 3 bids at once, used that same methodology where we're disqualified. We don't agree with it, and we've challenged it. But I think we've adjusted our bidding procedure going forward. And we -- frankly, it's kind of behind us now. And we're looking at the other bids, and we have adjusted how we're doing it. We would expect to be quite competitive in the future. So it's not something -- it was unfortunate in just the way those bids came together. But it's behind us now, and we're moving on. But I will say that I think -- talking about Mexico, in particular, it's -- we're still in a very, very good competitive position there. And I'm really pleased with the growth that we've had. It's unfortunate that you don't see it quite in the financials. But our EBITDA there was up 19% from $93 million last year to $110 million, if you include our ownership in the JV -- I mean, our proportionate share of their EBITDA. And it gets masked a little bit in the GAAP reporting and because of FX. Last quarter, in 2015, in the first quarter, we had a 3% inflation with -- or strengthening of the peso, which actually reduced our tax expense. And in '16, it was pretty much flat, and so we didn't get that same benefit. So that kind of masked the underlying growth. But we had very strong growth there, and are in a very good and competitive position in Mexico.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And Debbie, you mentioned a lot of opportunities in Mexico, beyond just the CFE pipelines. Could you maybe comment on, near term, what the -- maybe the best opportunities are that we should be looking at?
componenttext: Got it. And Debbie, you mentioned a lot of opportunities in Mexico, beyond just the CFE pipelines. Could you maybe comment on, near term, what the -- maybe the best opportunities are that we should be looking at?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll talk about some. And I think one that we have before us that we expect to close during the third quarter is the PEMEX acquisition of the JV assets that we currently hold jointly with PEMEX, and we're still moving forward on that. But as you pro
componenttext: Sure, I'll talk about some. And I think one that we have before us that we expect to close during the third quarter is the PEMEX acquisition of the JV assets that we currently hold jointly with PEMEX, and we're still moving forward on that. But as you probably read, now PEMEX is looking at other potential asset sales, and they have a number of assets that we would be interested in that would give us some opportunities. We're also looking at some of the other energy assets that are in Mexico now, some of which are in operations, some of which are in the development stage, that we could potentially acquire. And we have some that we're looking at there. And then just in terms of the broader markets opening, you have the bids coming out that are about $1.2 billion a piece for Electric Transmission that we're seeing. We have renewables being bid, and several billions worth of potential there. And then for us, since we kind of own and operate pipelines, there's a lot of liquid pipeline assets in Mexico. They're currently held by PEMEX now or needs for new liquids pipeline that deal with their opening of the oil markets. And so we think that, that's a great area for us as well to have similar type of long-term contract and infrastructure in liquids.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And my last question, with you guys divesting REX, there's no real domestic midstream presence. Are you looking to grow that through acquisition or organically? Or is that something that's not necessarily important as long as you have contracted g
componenttext: Got it. And my last question, with you guys divesting REX, there's no real domestic midstream presence. Are you looking to grow that through acquisition or organically? Or is that something that's not necessarily important as long as you have contracted growth in other areas?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we've looked at is a strategy to grow that, but more on an integrated basis with our other assets. And that -- when you have a huge load, like building an LNG facility, that gives you the opportunity to build pipelines and storage to serve that
componenttext: Yes, what we've looked at is a strategy to grow that, but more on an integrated basis with our other assets. And that -- when you have a huge load, like building an LNG facility, that gives you the opportunity to build pipelines and storage to serve that load, that integrate with others. And then to expand those in a way that you can pick up additional customers, whether they're electric generation facilities or manufacturing facilities, and really have a full pipeline. So what we tend to look at is where we have a load and where the ones that has that load, whether it's a utility or it's a contract with PEMEX or it's a contract for LNG export, that we like to have assets that integrate with that load. And so that would be kind of our priority for looking at access, it's to how they could be more integrated with our business. I mean REX is fine. But it doesn't integrate with anything we had. We only had the 25% interest in it. We didn't control it. It had contracts expiring. It just really didn't fit our model. And I don't want that to tell you at all that we're reluctant to get into other midstream assets. We are very interested in getting into those types of assets. But they need to provide us more growth. And when we look at REX, we just did not see the profile as providing the kind of growth. But there's some interesting assets that we're starting to look at now, that maybe come on market that we -- are already in existence. And then there's some that we foresee the need to develop that we think would be very interesting as well.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Gregory Gordon with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Gregory Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to be clear on if  I were trying to replicate your business plan with my own financial model, that we take the balance sheet capacity you have and we just assume that you buy the shares back at some higher stock price as we've compound abou
componenttext: So I just want to be clear on if  I were trying to replicate your business plan with my own financial model, that we take the balance sheet capacity you have and we just assume that you buy the shares back at some higher stock price as we've compound about 4 years of growth. Because -- and that would be a pretty low implied return on equity on that capital, relative to what you would consider a competitive hurdle rate for an actual infrastructure project. Is that -- would that -- is that a fair articulation of the math?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg. I think you figured that out actually quite well. Well, one of the things we've struggled with is that when we do our base plan, the only things we put in our base plan are things we already have contracted and our expected utility earnings. An
componenttext: Yes, Greg. I think you figured that out actually quite well. Well, one of the things we've struggled with is that when we do our base plan, the only things we put in our base plan are things we already have contracted and our expected utility earnings. And that most others, when they build those plants, they put aspirational projects in. We don't do that. So then when we looked at this and we thought with all the projects we have under contract and what that would yield, and then looking at the cash flows we have coming from the projects that are in service at the time and what that did to our FFO to debt, we just said there's no way we would sit with that FFO to debt on our balance sheet at that time. So what's the most conservative assumption we could put in and decided that to do a stock buyback were the most conservative way to handle it. So I'm going to turn it to Joe to talk a little bit more about how you might think about that in your question.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Yes, Greg, I want to emphasize the 2 key factors that she mentioned. That are the element of the base plan that's built on the strength of our regulated utilities and the already contracted infrastructure business that contributes to the s
componenttext: Thanks, Debbie. Yes, Greg, I want to emphasize the 2 key factors that she mentioned. That are the element of the base plan that's built on the strength of our regulated utilities and the already contracted infrastructure business that contributes to the strong balance sheet and the cash flow. So we did kind of what you said. We looked forward. We had to pick a price. We estimated a price base on a reasonable utility multiple out -- several years out and used that as a way to develop the optional share buyback. And I think that our goal is really to develop infrastructure and beat that. And so the earnings from those projects will replace this, and that's the goal that we expect to achieve.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I would presume, once we get to Analyst Day that you would give us the -- sort of the -- a similar framework of this is what we have sort of in the list of things that are moving ahead. And then the checklist of aspirational items that we can h
componenttext: Great. And I would presume, once we get to Analyst Day that you would give us the -- sort of the -- a similar framework of this is what we have sort of in the list of things that are moving ahead. And then the checklist of aspirational items that we can hold you either achieving or not achieving as you move through time, much like you did last year.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We'll do the blue box, which is the base plan, and the green box, which is the aspirational items. And -- I mean, the key thing is that some of those aspirational items will replace the stock buybacks, obviously. But to the extent that we can
componenttext: Absolutely. We'll do the blue box, which is the base plan, and the green box, which is the aspirational items. And -- I mean, the key thing is that some of those aspirational items will replace the stock buybacks, obviously. But to the extent that we can do more of those projects, they would also be additive to the stock buyback. And so we'll go through all of that with you at the Analyst Meeting, as we usually do.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Switching to Aliso Canyon. The costs, obviously, are up pretty significantly since the 10-K disclosure of around $330 million, if my memory serves me correctly. Can you give us what the incremental cost have been in basic buckets? Has it been mostl
componenttext: Great. Switching to Aliso Canyon. The costs, obviously, are up pretty significantly since the 10-K disclosure of around $330 million, if my memory serves me correctly. Can you give us what the incremental cost have been in basic buckets? Has it been mostly the extension by the judges of the relocation program? Or has it been other items that have also been significant?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me -- I'm going to refer this to Dennis so he can kind of walk you some of that and what's happening relative to the relocation. But the majority of these costs are associated with relocation. The vast majority -- I think it's about 70% of the co
componenttext: Yes, let me -- I'm going to refer this to Dennis so he can kind of walk you some of that and what's happening relative to the relocation. But the majority of these costs are associated with relocation. The vast majority -- I think it's about 70% of the costs are relocation. So Dennis, do you want to kind of walk him through that a bit?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Greg, you're right. If you think back when we reported in the 10-K, the cost were about $332 million. Since that time, we have had the relocation program extended at least a couple of times by the courts. So the -- if you look at the change of about
componenttext: Sure. Greg, you're right. If you think back when we reported in the 10-K, the cost were about $332 million. Since that time, we have had the relocation program extended at least a couple of times by the courts. So the -- if you look at the change of about $330 million, the majority of that has been relocation, 70%. Then you basically have 2 other buckets. About 15% of the overall total relates to the work of stopping the leak, building the relief wells, the root cause investigation that's underway and everything. And then you've got the buckets of the other cost related to legal and other out-of-pockets. So those are the 3 main: 70% relo, 70 -- or 15% for the stopping the leak and the investigation, and then the other 15% related to legal expense and other costs.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Faisel Khan with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll go next to Faisel Khan with Citigroup.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the TdM asset sale, I suppose that with the sales sort of announced, did that mean it was difficult to sort of get a long-term contract on that plant for sales in New Mexico? Is that sort of the genesis behind why this asset's being sold? Is it the --
componenttext: On the TdM asset sale, I suppose that with the sales sort of announced, did that mean it was difficult to sort of get a long-term contract on that plant for sales in New Mexico? Is that sort of the genesis behind why this asset's being sold? Is it the -- I thought that this would sort of fall underneath that bucket of assets that could be under a long-term contract, but maybe that wasn't a possibility.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to have Mark talk about that. But it have been sold under the U.S. previously, and -- that we were working on the possibility of trying to sell it into the Mexican markets. But as we looked at the asset and the difficulty in that, we decide
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to have Mark talk about that. But it have been sold under the U.S. previously, and -- that we were working on the possibility of trying to sell it into the Mexican markets. But as we looked at the asset and the difficulty in that, we decided that it was not likely to be not long-term contracted in the near term. Mark, you want to...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's right. I mean, I -- the plant right now is configured only for sale into the U.S. We've looked at -- and we have a plan to connect it into the grid in Mexico. It could be that in the not-too-distant future, that there could be a long-t
componenttext: Yes, I think that's right. I mean, I -- the plant right now is configured only for sale into the U.S. We've looked at -- and we have a plan to connect it into the grid in Mexico. It could be that in the not-too-distant future, that there could be a long-term contract opportunity with the CFE. They did -- the CFE just did sponsor and build a new plant very close to our LNG facility in -- down by Ensenada. And so it's going to delay for some years the need for additional capacity in that region. And also to -- just with those kinds of plants, fossil fuel-fired plants in Mexico, the contracting periods are not as long as they once were. And so it -- we started to see that this asset is not likely to meet our kind of long-term contracted objectives. And therefore, we thought that we ought to put it on the market and see if we -- and move to sell it. All that said, I think we have certainly a reserve price in our heads, that if we don't get it or don't get it, then we'll rethink that. But I think we're in very good -- we're looking at trying to move forward on it.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Makes sense. And then just going back to Aliso, I just want to understand. So you're saying we probably won't get any major final report in the agencies until late '16 or '17. Are there going to be sort of any initial findings that come out through
componenttext: Okay. Makes sense. And then just going back to Aliso, I just want to understand. So you're saying we probably won't get any major final report in the agencies until late '16 or '17. Are there going to be sort of any initial findings that come out through the regulatory process over the next few months?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, there were some initial findings from DOGGR that indicated that SoCalGas was in full compliance with all the rules that were in place at that time, and DOGGR came out with those findings early on from the preliminary review. But right n
componenttext: Well, I would say, there were some initial findings from DOGGR that indicated that SoCalGas was in full compliance with all the rules that were in place at that time, and DOGGR came out with those findings early on from the preliminary review. But right now, the work that Blade is doing on-site in conjunction with CPUC, I don't think we're going to get any preliminary information. What they'll do is they're gathering the data and then they'll write the report, and it's likely that report will be out at the end of this year or early next year. Dennis, do you want to add to that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the only thing that I'd add to that, Debbie, is that there's a lot of work going on, not just under the root cause investigation with DOGGR, the CPUC and Blade, but work to get Aliso back up and running. And I can tell you right now that it's really c
componenttext: No, the only thing that I'd add to that, Debbie, is that there's a lot of work going on, not just under the root cause investigation with DOGGR, the CPUC and Blade, but work to get Aliso back up and running. And I can tell you right now that it's really clear that the regulators and policymakers truly understand the importance of Aliso Canyon and gas storage to both gas and electric reliability. So the tone is basically, let's make  sure it's safe, but let's it get back up and running as quickly as we can. And so far, we've got -- of the 114 wells at Aliso, about 100 of them have completed the Phase 1 inspections, and we're transitioning those now to Phase 2. So that our target right now, Faisel, is to have the field ready for full operation, obviously, subject to DOGGR confirmation, but by the late summer, probably late August. So a lot of work going on there.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the storage field would not be able to go back into operation until this report comes out? Or could you put it back into service before then?
componenttext: Okay. And then the storage field would not be able to go back into operation until this report comes out? Or could you put it back into service before then?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, today, we've got about 15 billion cubic feet of gas. So if needed, we can withdraw. We're just not allowed to inject until the field has been confirmed ready by DOGGR. And as I said, our current target right now is to have wells ready for reinjectio
componenttext: Well, today, we've got about 15 billion cubic feet of gas. So if needed, we can withdraw. We're just not allowed to inject until the field has been confirmed ready by DOGGR. And as I said, our current target right now is to have wells ready for reinjection by late summer.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that is before the full report will be out.
componenttext: And that is before the full report will be out.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And that's separate from the root cause analysis. So those things don't -- they aren't linked. The root cause is going down one work stream, and then there's a separate work stream to get the field back up and running.
componenttext: Yes. And that's separate from the root cause analysis. So those things don't -- they aren't linked. The root cause is going down one work stream, and then there's a separate work stream to get the field back up and running.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, makes sense. And then just on REX. I just want to make sure I understand the sort of -- I guess what you had additionally had in guidance in the past. So I guess, did you always have sort of the legacy sort of REX interest that you have going to 0 e
componenttext: Okay, makes sense. And then just on REX. I just want to make sure I understand the sort of -- I guess what you had additionally had in guidance in the past. So I guess, did you always have sort of the legacy sort of REX interest that you have going to 0 earnings in 2020? I just want to make sure I understood that correctly.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, you understood it correctly. I mean, we basically had -- it was de minimus in 2020 because we had looked at the contracts all expiring in 2019, and then there was debt refinancing that needed to be done. And so we looked at the economics of that.
componenttext: Yes. No, you understood it correctly. I mean, we basically had -- it was de minimus in 2020 because we had looked at the contracts all expiring in 2019, and then there was debt refinancing that needed to be done. And so we looked at the economics of that. And so when we're putting our plans together, we were not expecting REX to continue at the kind of run rate that -- we told you, it was $60 million for the 10 months we had this year. We were not expecting it to continue at that kind of run rate after those contracts expired in 2019.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to have a sense, do you expect the contracts to expire and nothing would happen after that? Or did you also -- did you expect some recontracting but at a lower rate? And did it also include the east-to-west sort of contracts that were signed?
componenttext: Just to have a sense, do you expect the contracts to expire and nothing would happen after that? Or did you also -- did you expect some recontracting but at a lower rate? And did it also include the east-to-west sort of contracts that were signed?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We looked at all of that, and we expected that there would be some contracting at a lower rate. Mark, you want to...
componenttext: Yes. We looked at all of that, and we expected that there would be some contracting at a lower rate. Mark, you want to...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Faisel. Yes, obviously, we did. We had a projection of what we thought the recontracting rate would be. And then we also assumed that we would continue with the east-to-west contracting that we've done. And that -- we had a market check on that, and
componenttext: Yes, Faisel. Yes, obviously, we did. We had a projection of what we thought the recontracting rate would be. And then we also assumed that we would continue with the east-to-west contracting that we've done. And that -- we had a market check on that, and that's what was in our plan. But that, combined with the interest cost and some refinancing that we thought was going to happen, it just didn't have a material impact on our financials beyond 2018.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And last question for me. Just with the midstream MLP market sort of coming back to some degree off the bottom, I'm just wondering -- and also to sell REX, does this mean the MLP is sort of completely off the table even in the future?
componenttext: Okay, got it. And last question for me. Just with the midstream MLP market sort of coming back to some degree off the bottom, I'm just wondering -- and also to sell REX, does this mean the MLP is sort of completely off the table even in the future?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say nothing is off the table in the future. I mean I would never do that. We will always look at what's the lowest cost of capital for us to grow, and that's just the way we look at it. That REX was not a core asset for the MLP anyway since we onl
componenttext: I would say nothing is off the table in the future. I mean I would never do that. We will always look at what's the lowest cost of capital for us to grow, and that's just the way we look at it. That REX was not a core asset for the MLP anyway since we only owned a fraction of it, and we really didn't have the ability to use that as openly as you would an asset that you had 100%. And I would say, Cameron trains 1 through 3 are excellent assets for an MLP. So those would not be off the table. But right now, if you kind of look at where the market is, it's certainly not our top priority.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michael Lapides at Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Lapides at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, I have a couple of them. First of all, Debbie, can you talk about the portfolio, and whether you think there's anything else within it that you wouldn't view as core or strategic to Sempra over the long term. And if so, why?
componenttext: Actually, I have a couple of them. First of all, Debbie, can you talk about the portfolio, and whether you think there's anything else within it that you wouldn't view as core or strategic to Sempra over the long term. And if so, why?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. There's nothing that we identify right now that fits that category, Michael. We look at our assets all the time. And all of our assets, other assets, really are pretty well long-term contracted. The only one that comes up that we look at constantly
componenttext: Sure. There's nothing that we identify right now that fits that category, Michael. We look at our assets all the time. And all of our assets, other assets, really are pretty well long-term contracted. The only one that comes up that we look at constantly is gas storage. And that we do have still contracts on gas storage that have some duration left on those contracts. And we look at that and say how does that fit with our other asset. And what we see happening kind of in the Gulf region with the export of LNG, the conversion of coal to gas and need for different types of assets to support that, and then looking at the storage market right now. We kind of think that the timing on that asset, if things are going to happen, they're going to get better, not likely worse. And so that's one we constantly look at. But we have concluded on that, at least for the time being, it doesn't seem like something that we would want to try to get out of our portfolio at this time.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. When you talk about the $18.5 billion capital plan over the next 5 years, how much of that is at the 2 core California Utilities?
componenttext: Got it. When you talk about the $18.5 billion capital plan over the next 5 years, how much of that is at the 2 core California Utilities?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's about $12 billion of that at the 2 California Utilities, so the vast majority of that. And there may be some opportunities -- I was just going to say, there may be some opportunities for the Utilities to actually consume more of that. There's some pr
componenttext: It's about $12 billion of that at the 2 California Utilities, so the vast majority of that. And there may be some opportunities -- I was just going to say, there may be some opportunities for the Utilities to actually consume more of that. There's some projects that we have -- that are on those green sheets that we show you, that we're hoping to get some approval on, that would add to the capital expenditures at the Utilities during that time. But we really put in that -- only the ones that we have some great visibility and high certainty that we either have rate case approval or project approval from the CPUC or FERC.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last question, how are you thinking about the growth rate in the South American Utilities relative to the rest of the Sempra portfolio? I ask only because if I back out just the FX impact, it still doesn't seem like it was a huge growth rate and
componenttext: Okay. And last question, how are you thinking about the growth rate in the South American Utilities relative to the rest of the Sempra portfolio? I ask only because if I back out just the FX impact, it still doesn't seem like it was a huge growth rate and going back over the last couple of quarters as well. Just curious how you're thinking about that business and kind of its organic growth potential?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we still see a lot of organic growth potential there. Because similar to Mexico, there's huge needs for infrastructure in those countries. And we're looking at some -- quite a few things right now, in Peru, in particular. Mark, why don't you
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we still see a lot of organic growth potential there. Because similar to Mexico, there's huge needs for infrastructure in those countries. And we're looking at some -- quite a few things right now, in Peru, in particular. Mark, why don't you maybe hit a little bit about some of the things that we've looked at and opportunities for growth there.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I mean, there is huge infrastructure needs there. I do think both economies, probably Chile more than Peru, but both economies have been affected by the downturn in the mining sector, and effectively China's downturn. And so I think that's hurt the
componenttext: Right. I mean, there is huge infrastructure needs there. I do think both economies, probably Chile more than Peru, but both economies have been affected by the downturn in the mining sector, and effectively China's downturn. And so I think that's hurt their overall growth. But I think when you look at them, where they've been historically and what the expectation is for this year and next year, we still see strong underlying growth that you just don't see in any domestic utilities. You still see the 3%, 4% customer growth and 3%, 4% energy growth coming back. And we -- I think with the recession, we've had a little bit of a downturn there. But it's -- we see that coming back. And then on top of that, we see some large infrastructure needs, which really wouldn't be available to us if we weren't active in that market, in the utility market there. We just wouldn't have a presence to be able to capitalize on those. And so we're -- I think, we're -- again, we don't put those in our plan because we don't have them signed up yet. But we're close on several things, and I think it looks promising. It looks like there's definitely some activity level that's going to be happening down there that'll increase the growth for those facilities.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next is Steve Fleishman with Wolfe.
componenttext: The next is Steve Fleishman with Wolfe.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick questions. First on the assumptions on the rate case. So you highlight that the guidance includes the settlement, including the repair tax treatment. Could you just remind me the -- I recall that not being a big number. But I just want t
componenttext: A couple of quick questions. First on the assumptions on the rate case. So you highlight that the guidance includes the settlement, including the repair tax treatment. Could you just remind me the -- I recall that not being a big number. But I just want to make sure I know what the number is for the prior repair tax treatment.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me have Joe walk through the repair tax treatment numbers for you. The -- let me talk about the rate case though, while he's getting the precise numbers on that. What I would say is on the GRC, that we've been given every indication that we shoul
componenttext: Yes, let me have Joe walk through the repair tax treatment numbers for you. The -- let me talk about the rate case though, while he's getting the precise numbers on that. What I would say is on the GRC, that we've been given every indication that we should be getting a decision soon. And that we're expecting, since we had 8 out of 11 parties sign on to the settlement, that we would likely get the settlement as the outcome. We would also expect to get the repair allowance because we feel like we have very strong argument and have differentiated ourselves in terms of how we handled it in our rate cases going forward and returning the benefits to customers. And so we would anticipate getting a decision hopefully very soon and that very consistent with the settlement. And what we've been told is that the paying up and the delay is not any different than what you're hearing from other utilities commenting on their proceedings is that there's just a lack of resources at the commission right now, especially in the ALJ division to get some out these things out as quickly as they would like. And so we anticipated that it would come earlier. But -- that we continue to be told it will be soon, and that it is really more hung up because of their resource issue. Okay, Joe?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, let me just remind you all, Jeff and Dennis and their teams have been working closely with the commission on this issue. And we've tried to emphasize with them that we have very unique facts that are differentiated from some of the other utilities.
componenttext: Steve, let me just remind you all, Jeff and Dennis and their teams have been working closely with the commission on this issue. And we've tried to emphasize with them that we have very unique facts that are differentiated from some of the other utilities. And some of those things relate to -- our rate case was actually worked on and closed and officially closed by the ALJ before we made our changes in the tax treatment. And in our 2012 GRC, we offered up a sharing mechanism, much like we have in the past, and that was rejected. It was denied. So we've kind of offered up avenues for them to look at these kind of things. And as we've talked about before, there's very good precedent that the savings you generate before the next rate case were all kinds of things, tax, general operating flow to shareholders. So we think this will be resolved favorably. But let me get to the numbers that you asked about. There's 2 timing periods that are important: one is up through 2014 and then one is 2015. And I'll talk about the first period first. So from the beginning of the rate case through '14, the intervenors that applied for this suggested that we had about $90 million at each utility that they want to be adjusted through rate base. So that would be a rate base adjustment. And the impact, if we loss that -- we don't think we will. But if we lost that, the impact would be $6 million to $7 million in each of the utilities kind of going forward because of that change in rate base. But then, the commission asked us to put a memorandum account together for 2015 savings from this tax repair allowance. And if we were to lose that issue, we will of course appeal it and fight it. But if we were to lose it, we would have to take a charge of about $70 million. That's broken between the 2 utilities. But in total, $65 million to $70 million in total for the '15 memorandum account. Again, I think these are things that we expect to go in our favor. We're giving you all the data done before.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Let me hand it to Dennis. I think that one of the things that we need to kind of put in perspective is that we've made a lot of changes to the program that reduced the cost from where it was. And so Dennis can kind of walk you through, including the number of people that are going home now, which is quite significant. Dennis?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, let me give you a little color around that. Because I think as we get some questions, people want to understand and put it in perspective. I mean, when you look -- first of all, the leak, as you know, was permanently sealed back on February 18. And
componenttext: Steve, let me give you a little color around that. Because I think as we get some questions, people want to understand and put it in perspective. I mean, when you look -- first of all, the leak, as you know, was permanently sealed back on February 18. And at the time, when you look at the number of people that were impacted, it was really a -- the vast majority of the households around Aliso Canyon, they never left. They stayed at their homes. Everything was safe and everything. So it was a smaller number to begin with. But since then, we've had over 54% of any impacted residents that have actually gone back to their homes. And every week, we're seeing more and more. So to give you an actual run rate is difficult because, as Debbie said, we're doing things within our program that allow us to -- and help the residents move, say, from hotels to corporate-style apartments, more family-situated apartments with kitchens where they can cook and everything, and that helps bring down the cost. The other things that we're doing is we've been offering in-home cleaning services to give further assurance to residents that everything's safe. So while we haven't given an official run rate, what we can tell you is that the number that we gave out for -- the $665 million assumed relocation expenses through June 7. And as we said, we expect to get additional information from the Department of Public Health this month regarding their testing. And I think that type of information will even further get people more comfortable that they can go home, and we'll see the numbers continue to drop week after week.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, thanks. I think the big thing though, the point to keep in mind is as far as U.S. LNG exports go, we believe train 4 will be one of the least expensive options available. So that's why we have -- we continue to have pretty good interest from p
componenttext: Yes, Steve, thanks. I think the big thing though, the point to keep in mind is as far as U.S. LNG exports go, we believe train 4 will be one of the least expensive options available. So that's why we have -- we continue to have pretty good interest from people looking at securing that option early and maybe even in advance of when world demand may require it. So we are feeling pretty confident that it's going to move forward. We -- our original statements that we made on the last call at the end of the year or 2 were that we expected to have something wrapped up by the end of the year and that our FID amount would be in the first part of next year. And that hasn't changed. So we're still working towards that. And if we get any indication that things are different, we'll tell you right away. But I think right now, we're still feeling like this will happen sometime this year.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then I would add to that. Just that you all read about what's happening in the markets. And we have great expressed interest from customers. I mean, they're spending time, they're putting teams on this to negotiate with us. So it's not like they'
componenttext: Yes. And then I would add to that. Just that you all read about what's happening in the markets. And we have great expressed interest from customers. I mean, they're spending time, they're putting teams on this to negotiate with us. So it's not like they're just saying, "We kind of like to do something." They're actually dedicating resources to this. But this is a very challenging market to get agreement signed in. And so I just want to counterbalance that. And honestly, if we get [indiscernible] versus December of this year, I'll be a happy camper. So -- and we're really focused on it. And as I said, it's not like the counterparties are not engaged fully. They are engaged fully.

componenttext: Sure. Let me take the LNG question first and talk a little bit about that, and then have Dennis address the assumptions on the relocation. So for Camerons 1 through 3, we're 43% complete. The construction is going really well. We're slightly ahead of our construction schedule. I would say on schedule, but if you look at some of the data, we're slightly ahead. And that we're still expecting train 1 to come on in March of '18, train 2 to come on in July of '18 and 3 in November of '18, which was the schedule that we would outline for you previously. So everything's going very, very well there. I would say, the safety performance has been exceptional on the job. And that the major material's a long lead time. Materials have all been ordered. And everything is moving quite well on construction. I don't know, Mark, is there anything else you want to add?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Rose-Lynn. Yes, as I mentioned, what we did is we assumed that the relocation cost would continue through June 7. And we basically -- to be conservative, we've assumed that they stay flat throughout that period. Now what we are seeing, and this was
componenttext: Sure, Rose-Lynn. Yes, as I mentioned, what we did is we assumed that the relocation cost would continue through June 7. And we basically -- to be conservative, we've assumed that they stay flat throughout that period. Now what we are seeing, and this was incorporated into our assumptions, is that as we're cleaning more homes, people are going home. They're being -- they were even more comfortable that their homes are safe and everything. So we are seeing more and more people go home that way. The other thing that we've been doing, that we incorporated into our assumptions is as we're able to locate more of the family-style corporate housing options within the area, we're transitioning more people from hotels where they're also receiving Per Diem to these corporate apartments, where they have their kitchens and we don't have to pay the Per Diems. So those are the types of -- and that's part of the program that we have. That's part of the approved program. So that helps reduce the overall cost as well. So all those things are built into it, but we aren't assuming a huge drop-off. But we are seeing that on a week-to-week basis, so I think that's favorable.

componenttext: Yes, Paul. I said that and so I'll say it again so it's clear. It'll be in the transcript. I said that in our plan, the one that we gave you last year, we had for 2016 and '17 between $5 million and $10 million of losses related to this capacity, because we had a lot of capacity sold forward. It wasn't exactly at the same price we were buying the capacity up. It is pretty close. So we had a $5 million to $10 million loss for '16 and '17. That did not take into account some of the recent financial troubles that some of the capacity holders had. So if we had kept it, we would have had bigger losses going forward, which is why, as we tried to sell this forward and on a permanent basis, we're taking a bigger loss than you would assume from the $5 million to $10 million had been in our plan. But for you to adjust your plan, you were probably basing them off of our numbers. And I wanted you to know what was in our numbers before, which was $5 million to $10 million for the next couple of years.

componenttext: Okay. And then the potential buyback, that's kind of a placeholder. And if I understand it correctly, you guys are aiming for better returns with investments and what have you. But the 12% sort of has this as a placeholder in the event that you, for some reason, not able to find investments. Is that right way to think of it?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul. That is the way to think about it. And what I'd like to emphasize is, look, we're pretty unique here. Most of our peers, whether they're utilities or midstream companies or renewable companies, are issuing equity to grow. We're actually growing
componenttext: Yes, Paul. That is the way to think about it. And what I'd like to emphasize is, look, we're pretty unique here. Most of our peers, whether they're utilities or midstream companies or renewable companies, are issuing equity to grow. We're actually growing our earnings and our cash flow so fast and increasing the strength of our balance sheet and increasing our dividend 8% to 9% a year over this period, that we're able to actually look at a potential buyback if we don't capture some of these projects we're working on. But we fully expect to capture those projects and do better. We just showed this is an optional thing. It's within our control, and we can do. That's unique.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just add to that. The 12% is based upon what we already have under contract and in construction. So -- and what our expected utility earnings would be, assuming we get the settlement in the rate case, and then we just assume in out years that
componenttext: Yes. Let me just add to that. The 12% is based upon what we already have under contract and in construction. So -- and what our expected utility earnings would be, assuming we get the settlement in the rate case, and then we just assume in out years that we use attrition in addition to that. So we try to use conservative assumptions for that. But then we show you all the development projects. And in this time, we thought that using the assumption of the buyback is conservative because we wouldn't be sitting there with 22% FFO to debt on our balance sheet and not do something with it. What we fully expect in the next 5 years that we will have projects that will have a much better return than what we're showing you with the stock buyback. But we have is just -- we have wonderful flexibility. And to be able to show you 5 years what we have long-term contracted that yields that kind of a growth rate and gives us the strength of the balance sheet, that gives us the flexibility if we were not to find projects to buyback stock, which we don't think is going to be the outcome because we have a robust backlog of projects that we're working on. But it's just a wonderful position to be in. And honestly, this is what I was going to talk about at the analyst meeting. Because it's -- not too many others can talk about having a strengthening balance sheet, having this type of a 12% growth rate with conservative assumptions and then having the ability to grow the dividend by 8% to 9% over that 5-year period of time, with nothing else. So that was going to be a lot of my presentation. I'm -- kind of close to even kind of what we're going to be talking about. But it's a really great position to be in. And since we didn't do the analyst conference, we wanted you to all understand where we stood relative to that. And we'll go into a lot more detail, as we always do, when we get to the conference.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Sempra Energy Second Quarter Earning Results Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Rick Vaccari. Please go ahead.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. Here in San Diego are several members of our management t
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website under the Investors section. Here in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Snell, President; Joe Householder, Chief Financial Officer; Martha Wyrsch, General Counsel; Trevor Mihalik, Chief Accounting Officer; Dennis Arriola, Chief Executive Officer of SoCalGas; and Jeff Martin, Chief Executive Officer of San Diego Gas & Electric.
Before starting, I would like to remind everyone that we will be discussing forward-looking statements on this call within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. The factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially are discussed in the company's most recent 10-K and 10-Q. 
It's important to note that all of the earnings per share amounts in our presentation are shown on a diluted basis, and they will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the presentation slides that accompany this call and to Table A in our second quarter 2016 earnings press release for a reconciliation to GAAP measures.
I'd also like to note that the forward-looking statements contained in this presentation speak only as of today, August 4, 2016, and the company does not assume any obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements in the future. We'll keep our prepared remarks shorter than usual today, with a focus on the quarterly earnings as we just held our analyst conference. 
With that, please turn to Slide 4, let me hand the call over to Debbie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rick, and thanks to all of you who were able to make it to our analyst conference a few weeks ago. We couldn't have asked for better attendance and enjoyed being able to talk to you in person and listen to your feedback.Based on our year-to-date
componenttext:
Thanks, Rick, and thanks to all of you who were able to make it to our analyst conference a few weeks ago. We couldn't have asked for better attendance and enjoyed being able to talk to you in person and listen to your feedback.
Based on our year-to-date results, I will start by reaffirming our 2016 adjusted EPS guidance range of $4.60 per share to $5 per share. Joe will review the details of this quarter's results, but first, let me take some time to address the strategic goals we have for the natural gas business. We previously disclosed the sale of our interest in REX, which negatively impacted our quarterly results. We also expect losses in this segment in 2016 and 2017, which are incorporated into our adjusted guidance. 
Our decision to sell REX reflects an implementation of our strategy for the natural gas business to focus our investments around our anchor LNG assets where we have competitive advantages. Octávio discussed this at our analyst conference. We also decided to sell our Southeast utilities and TdM and redeployed the capital on assets that better align with our strategy and provide stronger long-term growth.
I'd like to spend a minute reiterating the value proposition that we believe is top-tier among our utility industry peers. And that is a result of Sempra's long-term strategy. First, our strategy continues to provide the building blocks for high total shareholder return. Our base plan projections result in an approximate 12% adjusted earnings per share compound growth rate through 2020.  
Second, we plan to grow the dividend 8% to 9% annually. Third, we have a healthy balance sheet, with significant projected credit capacity in the latter years of the plan, which gives us several options to return value to our shareholders. Fourth, our businesses have great development platforms with a long runway of opportunity. Finally, with those development opportunities, we are committed to our strategy of long-term contracted infrastructure and utility earnings, which moderates risk and provides less volatility in varying market environments.
Now I will turn it over to Joe to review the quarterly financial results. Please turn to Slide 5.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Earlier this morning, we reported second quarter earnings of $16 million or $0.06 per share. We also reported second quarter adjusted earnings of $200 million or $0.79 per share compared to second quarter adjusted earnings in 2015 of $259
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. Earlier this morning, we reported second quarter earnings of $16 million or $0.06 per share. We also reported second quarter adjusted earnings of $200 million or $0.79 per share compared to second quarter adjusted earnings in 2015 of $259 million or $1.03 per share. 
Quarter-over-quarter, adjusted earnings were impacted by the following items: at U.S. Gas & Power, we have losses of $19 million in the second quarter of 2016 compared with gains of $5 million in the second quarter of 2015, both related to the movements of natural gas prices on inventory that we sold forward. We expect the majority of this quarter's losses to reverse by year-end as we sell the natural gas held in inventory. Our goal is to operate this part of the business to lower our economic exposure to commodity price swings. Also at U.S. Gas & Power, we had $8 million of lower equity earnings due to the sale of our interest in REX.
At SoCalGas, we had a $13 million impairment as a result of the CPUC decision related to the North-South Pipeline. We are now working on ways to recover all or a portion of these expenses and more importantly, develop alternative solutions for the reliability needs in Southern California that this pipeline was designed to address. Last year, SoCalGas had a $13 million retroactive earnings benefit from higher CPUC rate base approved in the second quarter of 2015. You can find the individual financial results for our businesses in the Business Unit Earnings section.
Please turn to the next slide. As Debbie mentioned, we took actions in the first half of this year to continue to align our assets with our long-term strategy, and that our California Utilities, we received the final general rate case decision. As a result, we made several after-tax adjustments to arrive at adjusted earnings this quarter. 
The significant adjustments are: first, a loss of $123 million for the permanent releases of pipeline capacity that natural gas held with REX and others; second, $80 million in charges as a result of the final GRC decision for the reallocation to ratepayers of certain benefits from tax repairs deductions; and third also related to the GRC decision, earnings benefits of $21 million for the retroactive GRC effect related to the first quarter of 2016.
Additionally, I want to remind you that we expect to report significant gains that will be excluded from adjusted earnings for 2 transactions when they close, both of which may happen in the third quarter. First, we expect the after-tax gain for the sale of our Southeast utilities to be approximately $70 million. We also expect to record a significant after-tax gain from the remeasurement of IEnova's investment in the shared joint venture with PEMEX upon its acquisition of PEMEX's interest. 
Regarding this acquisition, we have made progress recently, and we expect to close this year, subject to regulatory approvals. The transaction was restructured earlier in July and a new price for the 7 assets was finalized at approximately $1.1 billion. The sale by PEMEX will be submitted to the regulators for final approval. 
I'd also like to address Aliso Canyon. We have increased the cost estimate to $717 million, and we have begun collecting under the insurance policies and to date have received approximately $34 million. On July 25, the individual and business filed an updated and consolidated complaint as required under the case management order. In addition, the county of Los Angeles filed a separate complaint against SoCalGas, a primary component of which takes new safety measures.
Please see our Aliso Canyon Status Update slide in the appendix, which describes the costs included and excluded from our estimate. And please refer to our 2015 10-K and second quarter 10-Q for more detail on these costs and our insurance coverage.
Finally, as Debbie mentioned, we are reaffirming our 2016 adjusted EPS guidance of $4.60 per share to $5 per share. With that, we will conclude our prepared remarks and stop to take your questions.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me talk a little bit about first, the investment opportunities that are there, and we have a lot of things that are -- that are coming together now, first of which we won the Marine Pipeline bid in conjunction with TransCanada, and our investmen
componenttext: Sure. Let me talk a little bit about first, the investment opportunities that are there, and we have a lot of things that are -- that are coming together now, first of which we won the Marine Pipeline bid in conjunction with TransCanada, and our investment there is about $840 million for that project. And then it appears that the transaction with PEMEX is going to move forward as we had indicated and hopefully close by the end of the third quarter, and that's about $1.1 billion. In addition to that, we're looking at some M&A activity. There are some renewables, that second auction is coming up for bid and we have some projects that we're looking at bidding into that second auction. And so if you kind of look at all of those, we have several billion dollars' worth of new projects that we're going to be working on over the next few years and we've already secured and several other billion dollars' worth of project between the renewables and then the transmission bids that are going to be coming up that are additional opportunities for us. And further than that, we're starting to do some things with the assets we have, like we just built a lateral or got an agreement to build a lateral. We have some others under negotiation of the existing pipelines. So we're looking at how we keep taking assets that we have and growing those assets. So it has a great opportunity. I was just with Joe and Mark in Mexico City last week. We spent time down there with the Secretary of Energy, the Secretary of Treasury, the head of PEMEX, the head the CFE, . And everyone is very enthusiastic about the Mexico infrastructure opportunities. And I will tell you, their view is they're not slowing down because it's critical to what their goal is to have manufacturing in Mexico. So we're really, really excited about the IEnova opportunities. Going specific to your question then, what we're going to do, and I can't tell you what position we're going to take on the equity, but we're going to look at all of that, and we are going to look at all of the capital needs. I think we have a couple hundred million of available in Mexico right now. And so we're going to have to look at the total capital needs that we would expect over the next year or so and then look at what's the right position for us to be in relative to that. We told you that we're not repatriating because we wanted to take a position in the equity offering assuming that the equity offering occurs, and we would expect this to occur. So there's really not a definitive percentage ownership that we've ascribed to. What we'd love to do is have the pie keep getting better, and we don't have to keep our same position in the pie. We don't have to own 80% of the pie. We'd like the pie to be bigger and own a significant position in that pie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. But is there kind of a point in which, let's say, Cameron 4 does or does not move forward, that, that would potentially evolve as you think about capital allocation? Or do you kind of think about separately and distinctly as what is the return pro
componenttext: Got it. But is there kind of a point in which, let's say, Cameron 4 does or does not move forward, that, that would potentially evolve as you think about capital allocation? Or do you kind of think about separately and distinctly as what is the return proposition in Mexico, not necessarily what happens with the Cameron?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're not looking at -- because we think any of these -- all these projects are really good and they're financeable. So that -- I wouldn't say that's a consideration but we have some things going on in Peru right now that are very exciting. Potential
componenttext: Yes, we're not looking at -- because we think any of these -- all these projects are really good and they're financeable. So that -- I wouldn't say that's a consideration but we have some things going on in Peru right now that are very exciting. Potentially, we have the projects in Mexico and then we have the Cameron 4. And so from a capital allocation standpoint, as we've kind of looked at it, that we've set up IEnova so that we could issue equity through IEnova. We have the opportunity through our Peruvian company to issue equity. It already has -- it's in the market and we own like 83% of that. So if we need the capital for that, we could issue equity and Luz Del Sur. And then for Cameron 4, we could issue equity at Sempra for that. So we have different ways that we can finance these things. And honestly, if we have great projects that earn significantly above the cost of capital, we have not had an issue in being able to finance them. Further, we showed you at the analyst meeting, our balance sheet strengthened over the 5-year period of time. And so we put a plug in at $1.5 billion of cash -- of our stock buyback. We would hope to invest that money in good projects, and I think we're going to be able to do that.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And one more clarification on the thought process for IEnova. Anything around the Zebra E structure in Mexico to think about here? Obviously, that's kind of maturing. And what does that mean for you guys one way or another? I mean, from your tax position in the country, probably doesn't mean much, does it?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

I mean, I think it offers some opportunity for financing. Again, for us, a lot of it is as it was with MLP, what's the best cost of capital. So Joe, do you want to...

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Debbie. Hey, Julian. We looked at this over a year ago when it first came out, and there were some issues with it, and we worked with the regulators around those. And so now it's -- I think that's sorted out. But I think it goes back to what
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Debbie. Hey, Julian. We looked at this over a year ago when it first came out, and there were some issues with it, and we worked with the regulators around those. And so now it's -- I think that's sorted out. But I think it goes back to what Debbie said. What may be the best source of capital for us to grow the business. And as you said we were just down there, and it makes us even more excited to own a large part of this business. So how we decide to fund it with debt and equity, well, we will take that all into account because of these are really good projects, and we really like the growth opportunity there. As to the [indiscernible] specifically, we just look at that as one of the options we have to grow the business. PEMEX would love to try to do something but they'd like to see the market kind of open up and it just hasn't evolved yet. But we stay very close to it.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
